name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I declare the session suspended on Thursday, 17 December 2015, to be resumed.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen, to our great dismay, the New Year has begun in a similar way to the old one: with murderous violence and deep sorrow.  Following the brutal attacks in Paris, Copenhagen, Tunis, Jakarta and elsewhere, a serious attack took place in the heart of Istanbul on 12 January 2016.  European Union citizens have been the victims of this terrorist attack. Ten German citizens were killed and nine others were seriously injured.  In Ouagadougou, more than two dozen people from at least seven countries died in a terrorist attack on Friday night, some of them seriously injured.  We mourn with the families and friends of the victims and wish the injured a speedy recovery.  But we must also live with the fact that terror knows no borders. We must repeat: it is aimed at our freedom and it threatens us all, whether in Turkey, Burkina Faso, whether in the Member States of the EU or elsewhere.  That is why we must not refuse to recognise that terror is an everyday danger. At the same time, however, we must not be intimidated by the cynical acts of murder, but must try to fight terrorism together on the basis of our democratic values, with the police, with the rule of law, but above all with greater cooperation at European level. I believe i miter to express sympathy for the victims and their families here on behalf of all of you.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: Mr President, before declaring the agenda approved, I would like to make the following observation: last week, in the Conference of Presidents, we discussed the issue of Denmark, whose Commissioner is also present here, although she has nothing to do with what is happening. This is a very worrying situation, because measures, which, in the eyes of quite a large number of us, constitute offences, are being taken in this country. The situation in Denmark is worrying, in the sense that measures are being taken, the final adoption of which is scheduled for 26 January, which, at least in the eyes of a number of us, seem to be at odds with the values of the Union. We discussed this in the Conference of Presidents and agreed on the following procedure: tonight - I say this evening - the Committee on Civil Liberties would hear from a representative of the Danish Government and, following this meeting, the coordinators of the Committee on Civil Liberties would meet and decide whether or not the time for debate in plenary is necessary. However, we note that we still do not know whether the Committee on Civil Liberties will hear from a representative of the Danish government. In any case, it certainly won't be tonight , which was agreed. So it will not happen tonight and it is certain that the coordinators will not meet tonight. In this case, it seems to me normal, Mr President, to provide a plenary slot to discuss the situation in Denmark, since we still do not know whether or not the Committee on Civil Liberties will decide, in its wisdom, to meet on this matter with a representative of the Danish Government. In other words, if we decide to play the clock, perhaps this Parliament will debate in plenary, but post-factum, that is, during the february I session period, in other words after the Danish government's decision. So as much - and I said this in the Conference of Presidents - I fully understand that the European Commission can only decide on decisions of the acts of law taken in the Member States, as much as I think this Parliament has a role of warning. I therefore believe that the debate must be held in this Parliament before the Danish Government and the Danish Parliament decide, rather than afterwards. And since the conditions are not right for the debate in the LIBE committee, I think that we must provide for it as a precautionary measure, at least in plenary, and if, fortunately, the LIBE committee were to meet and its coordinators feel that a debate has become unnecessary, we will cancel this debate in plenary.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Thank you, Mr Lamberts. I think that is clear.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: Mr President, if I may ask for clarification: is this a meeting either of the coordinators or of the whole Committee on Civil Liberties in the presence of a representative of the Danish Government?

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr Lamberts, I do not think there is any point in them meeting without a representative of the Danish Government. What should they discuss then?  I also had an opportunity today to make a telephone call with the Prime Minister of Denmark and ask him to send a representative.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I would like to express my support for your procedural proposal in dealing with this issue, that we are now calmly giving colleagues in the LIBE Committee the first right to examine this. However, I would like to say on behalf of my group that if we now spread such a hustle and bustle and actionism in every legislative work that is due at national level, as the Greens do in this case, then we will do more harm than good for the European cause. Because we have a democratically elected Danish Parliament, which is now in the legislative process and is simply expressing its vote. We should show respect for our Danish colleagues. They must first decide how to implement their asylum legislation, and then there is still the possibility that we in the European Parliament will discuss these issues. My group simply does not see any urgency on this issue.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I too support the approach that you have now proposed. I am also relying on us to have some information on this tomorrow. I would just like to say to Mr Weber that this is not a precedent and some normal legislative process. It is a question of whether we continue to respect the values of the European Union, and that includes the fundamental right to asylum. And the fundamental right to asylum does not include, for example, the confiscing of the property of refugees, of asylum seekers.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I think we are in agreement. I will be speaking to Mr Moraes this evening to ensure that such a meeting takes place tomorrow. (The order of business has therefore been adopted.)

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on Werner Langen's report, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the annual report on EU competition policy (A8-0368/2015) [2015/2140(INI)].

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the I have waited a little longer for those Members who are not interested in the subject to leave the Chamber. Today we are discussing Parliament's opinion on the 2014 competition report. Since we do not have legislative powers in competition policy, it is particularly important that we give our opinion on these decisions of the European Commission every year. I would like to begin by thanking the Commissioner, Mrs Vestager, with which we worked very well over the last year. Although the report concerns ten months of her predecessor Almunia's term of office and only two months of her own term of office, this report has discussed important choices that are important for further development. The report was published on 4 June. We adopted this report in the ECON Committee on 7 December with 40 votes in favour, 6 against and 4 abstentions. It comprises a total of 117 points addressed to the Commission, the Member States and the sectors, in particular the Commission. I believe that we must keep pointing out the importance of competition policy. The EU Commission has extensive powers to prohibit prohibited price fixing and impose fines, to prevent mergers or to impose conditions, to control, recover or prohibit state aid. And in all these areas, it is particularly important that the democratic legitimacy of this competition policy is questioned. That is why there are two proposals in this report that, as far as possible, the codecision procedure should be introduced in future as part of a treaty amendment and, in addition, that we should also ensure that the same services responsible for enforcement, penalties, are not responsible for the basic guidelines, and cooperation is important. I would like to mention a few of the points in this report that we have taken up in general. Firstly, it has been called for cartel penalties not to be imposed only on legal persons, as in the past, but also in future on natural persons who are responsible for the whole thing. Secondly, the emphasis on the digital economy has been highlighted. We need new models of assessment here, we need new criteria. That is where the Commission is involved, and we want to support it in this. I want to remind you of Facebook's takeover of WhatsApp. The purchase price was 19 billion U.S. dollars. The EU Commission has waved this through. WhatsApp reported last week that they now have more than a billion users. In other words, new criteria are needed here. The third issue is the issue of tax avoidance and unfair tax competition. Here I would like to encourage the Commissioner to continue to do so. Last week, a decision against Belgium was published, which granted special conditions to 35 companies. We await the lawsuits against Google, Apple and Amazon. That is why it is also important that the Special Committee has called for a common consolidated corporate tax base and that we have decided on automatic exchanges. However, it is also important that we look at the VAT Directive, because Amazon pays only 0.5 per cent in taxes in Luxembourg for its European sales. In addition, with the case of state aid, we have the problem that, in the legal evaluation of tax procedures, penalties go to the States, in other words to the perpetrators. We need to examine whether the legal basis is being changed, whether the Commission is making a proposal here that it is not those who caused this that will receive these fines, but those who have been harmed. And the best way would be to put all these things in the EU budget, as is already the case with other antitrust procedures. I know that there are legal problems. Finally, I would like to express my sincere thanks to all the members of the European Commission who have been involved intensively and to the shadow rapporteurs. I hope that, despite a number of amendments and split votes, the report will be able to obtain a broad majority tomorrow, so that competition policy can emerge from the corner of the stepchild of the social market economy and the internal market. All of us here in Parliament support your work and hope for good results, Mrs Vestager!

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all thank you very much for inviting me here today, and very warm thanks to Mr Langen, both for his introductory remarks but most of all for the substantial work that has been done with the report and in the co-work with the shadow rapporteurs. The very fundamental thing here is that we are together in this, making sure that competition law is enforced and that it is done in a way that supports the everyday life of citizens. One obvious point is that powerful companies who are successful do not misuse their power, that we keep the market open, keep the playing field level, and make sure that every company has a fair chance of making it if they can attract consumers.  As you well know, I have opened a public consultation on the work of the national competition agencies. We in the Commission, and therefore hopefully also you, are very dependent on their strength and commitment, as well as the decisions they take using European law. I hope very much that together we can strengthen the competences of the national competition agencies and I will do my utmost to make sure that Parliament will have full engagement in these efforts. I very much appreciate that you are focusing your attention on the work that we do when it comes to corporate taxation. I think this is very crucial to keeping the playing field level. If one company can pay very little or almost no taxes and another one just pays the taxes by the book, obviously there is a distortion of competition.  Last week we took a decision on the Belgian ‘excess profit’ scheme, declaring that it is illegal under state aid legislation. First of all, because it gives multinationals a selective tax advantage that their domestic competitors cannot get. Secondly, because instead of ensuring that profits are attributed to the right group company and taxed there, the system just exempted a proportion of profits from taxation.  With this decision we take another step forward in ensuring that we have companies paying their fair share of taxes. But of course we need to do that in cooperation and I very much appreciate the work done here in Parliament in the Special Committee on Tax Rulings but also in the Working Group on Competition. Keeping markets fair and open also relates to mergers. And here it is very important to have lively debates about how we apply our Merger Regulation. I think the report makes a very valuable contribution to that discussion and, in the end, merger control also relates to the consumer and the individual and making sure that the consumer can have affordable prices, high quality and, of course, choice. As the market has gone global, it is very important that our enforcement is global as well and I think it is very important that we do not give up on our European values but do our best to work with counterparts in the US, in China, in South Africa, in South Korea and in Canada, to make sure that these values of fair and open competition are the values that we work with globally. We work with that in the international competition network, in the OECD and in UN entities. I think this is very important, both when negotiating free trade agreements, where we are discovering anti-trust-relevant cartels and mergers, and when entering into state aid.  In conclusion, I would say that a lot of things have happened. It is clearly reflected in your report, Mr Langen. We have worked on making digital markets work better by launching a sector inquiry into e-commerce; we have had cases concerning Google and concerning Qualcomm; we have acted to protect the internal market for energy with our cases involving Gazprom and Bulgaria Energy Holding; we have launched the first ever sector inquiry into state aid, looking into capacity mechanisms; and we continue our actions against cartels affecting products that consumers use every day. We have reviewed major cross-border mergers as General Electric’s acquisition of Alstom in energy-related businesses.  But it all boils down to one thing – that we need very good cooperation with the European Parliament; we need strong support for an open, competitive and fair market. In doing that we can both serve the interests of the European consumer and of the European citizens.

name: Bendt BENDTSEN
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. Mr President! Firstly, thank you to the rapporteur, Werner Langen, for a good report, and with the limited speaking time I have, I would like to make a few comments on tax policy. The report recognises well the need for better management and coordination of tax policy so that we can avoid abuses. It is also necessary to create fair competition in Europe's internal market. It is bad for the internal market when tax policy is used aggressively and without transparency to provide better conditions of competition to large companies. We talk a great deal about small and medium-sized enterprises in this house, but it is precisely the large companies that are doing this thinking and being able to move profits where tax is not - or hardly - paid, whereas SMEs have to pay at box one. It is positive that the focus is now on creating fair conditions of competition by looking at tax policy and increasing transparency, both in the TAXE Committee and in the Commission.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I wanted to draw your attention to a number of specific points that are of particular interest to the Committee on the Internal Market, but not only. The first concerns the digital single market: we need common rules; we must quickly overcome the differences, country by country, precisely in order to give meaning to competition and not to make this instrumental and improper, just as state aid must be aimed, when it is there, at growth and development, in order also to give a quality to competition between individual companies.  But I would particularly like to insist on you on the tax side: today there is no uniform tax legislation in Europe, which seriously harms small businesses. As long as there is no obligation to report in every country what they do and what companies pay in taxes, we will have a situation of inequality that will end up giving a very heavy blow to the expectations and potential of small businesses. I believe that this limit must be rapidly exceeded.

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the We welcome the fact that Commissioner Vestager has brought a breath of fresh air to European competition policy. It is important and right that the Commission investigates the tax practices of multinational companies, that it sends a clear stop to illegal aid and 0% tax rates. The citizens of Europe should know that illegal aid is sanctioned through tax law in Europe. And the citizens should also know that the honest taxpayer in Europe is not being let down politically. Competition policy certainly has a crucial role to play here. However, the investigation of high-profile tax cases is not enough either. We urgently need to adapt competition policy for the fast-growing digital economy. A difficult market definition must not protect against antitrust proceedings or proceedings against market abuse. We call on you, Commissioner, to continue your strict approach to Internet giants such as Google swiftly and transparently. We want an effective, efficient and, above all, honest competition policy. We call for strict organisational separation within the executive and legislative departments of the Competition Commission. And we are once again pointing the finger at something that has always been of immense importance to us in an interinstitutional way, namely more legislative competence for the European Parliament in competition policy. Today we would like to thank the rapporteur, Werner Langen, who has done an excellent job. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I would like to thank Mr Langen because the prospect of taking in more of the large companies that pay little or no tax today is extremely important. I would like to ask Mr Balz: is there any possibility that this could relieve the burden on small and medium-sized enterprises? The truth is that we should take the average, and that should actually lead to a dramatic reduction in taxation of small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you very much, Mr Rübig, for this question. I believe that an opportunity must be created, because it is precisely small and medium-sized enterprises that are to be relieved here. If we want to press this policy seriously, it is ultimately important to take clear, targeted tax measures for this very important group of our small and medium-sized enterprises in Europe.

name: Alfred SANT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the competition report before us raises two main concerns. The first one is about the scope, the powers and the methods of DG Competition. Its remit amounts to one of the most powerful tools in the executive kit of the European Commission, indeed of the European Union. DG Competition has the power to set and change market rules within the Union affecting a wide range of economic and financial issues. It can, and it does, issue orders to governments and corporations, big and small, regarding decisions they have taken or need to take. It is run by competent technocrats operating under the overall mantle of the Commission.  In arriving at decisions the DG carries out inquiries and investigations following an opaque process of negotiations that happens mostly behind closed doors. Political, economic, social, personal and national factors enter into play. In this, being ‘big’ is of greater account probably than being ‘small’. There is little transparency and hardly any accountability.  Moreover, there is an overlap between those whose job it is to set the rules and those implementing them. The two roles of setting rules and of implementing them should be institutionally separate and both should adopt more transparent methods. There is an urgent need to review DG Competition’s modus operandi as well as to reform its organisation. The second concern that this report raises relates to how state aid rules are being applied to peripheral or isolated regions and islands. The latter should not be treated as if they belonged to the mainstream and better endowed centres of the Union. This approach cannot be justified by the argument that structural and cohesion funds already compensate for the disadvantages which these territories are burdened with; they do not. In such regions the sectors of communications, infrastructure, aid to SMEs, energy, the protection of traditional small-scale initiatives, among others, carry no systemic significance in the context of the continental single market.  To apply to these regions the same treatment as for the centre is helping to increase structural disparities between the centre and periphery of the Union. This should stop, not least when the states to which such peripheral or isolated territories belong already conform to the rules and procedures of the Stability and Growth Pact.  The operations of the Commission’s DG Competition require much deeper evaluation than can be provided by debates such as this in order to promote reforms and ensure transparency, fairness and accountability.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: for the ECR Group. Mr President! I believe that we all agree here today that a fair and free competition policy is a prerequisite for the functioning of a market economy. That is why I am also pleased that we have a Commissioner who dares to fight with the big companies, who are trying to put themselves above the common rules that are the prerequisite for the market and therefore the prerequisite for the prosperity and well-being of all European citizens.  Having said that, I have to say that I do not quite share the vision, the idea, the approach taken by my good Conservative colleague, Bent Bendtsen, in relation to tax policy. Many of the problems we are experiencing with the member states' use of tax policy can be dealt with precisely through competition policy, since it is a question of applying tax policy, which favours some companies over others. We do not need a common harmonised tax policy there. We do not need more EU regulation. What we need is a strong and resolute Commissioner, and we already have! That is why, Mr Bent Bendtsen, there is no need for all the harmonisation that your colleague in the EPP is proposing, and that is why, unfortunately, we in the ECR Group will also vote 'no' when we vote on this report later this week. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you for your attention. I had come forward in time and you missed me. I do not take it badly, but I am grateful to be able to ask the question. Mr Messerschmidt has just spoken kindly about the competence and assertiveness of the European Commission in matters of competition law, but at the same time said that we do not need any further rules, especially in tax law. Mr Messerschmidt, do you agree with me that the European Commission can only be as strong in the area of tax law, in the area of tax loyalty between Member States, as the rules it must enforce? The competence of the European Commission alone is not sufficient in this area if there is no common framework. That is certainly my view.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: Blue-card response. – There are not, and should not be, any exceptions to the general rule that all companies, large and small, whatever sector it may be, should be treated in accordance with the same rules. It is not legal for a Member State, either Germany, which is a large country, or Luxembourg, which is a small country, at least in geography, to treat competing companies differently. It has to be absolutely clear. And that is within the competence of the Commission. Where we say no, that is when you use that argument to say that you have to harmonise tax policy, be it corporate tax policy or personal tax policy, or whatever it may be. We don't want to be part of that! We believe that the tools already in the box are sufficient to ensure a free market. That, incidentally, was also the whole idea of the European Union - not a community-harmonised juggernaut, which I know many in this Chamber want.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all let me congratulate the Commissioner on the tax ruling investigations, and not least the investigations in Belgium. I recognise her work on this.  On the Google case, I welcome paragraphs 34, 35 and 36 of the competition report that will be voted on tomorrow. In my opinion, the Google antitrust case has to move ahead more quickly and the Commission should step up the pace. I have some questions about this, Madam Commissioner. The first one regards the Statement of Objections (SO) sent by the Commission to Google concerning its comparison shopping service: what is the situation? Can you update this House? Secondly, you have collected and received the new data you requested from Google and the complainants. What is the result? Is it satisfactory? Will it help you to take a decision by spring? And what about the other areas identified as problematic by the Commission – not only Android, but also other areas of search bias, such as local search? Given the fact that local search is the largest category of all searches, do you agree that an SO on local search is strategically a good next step? It seems that a local search SO presents a great opportunity to address many of the complainants’ issues at the same time. Do you agree?  I also believe that this report should have pushed more regarding fair competition in the aviation sector, notably with third—country carriers such as the Gulf States. I also have two questions for you, Madam Commissioner. Will the Commission impose a fair competition clause in future aviation agreements with third countries? Will the Commission ask for full transparency of accounts to check if state aid and subsidies exist?

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I thank the rapporteur for his work on the commitments and I trust the support of other groups for the amendments we have tabled. Competition policy cannot ignore the general objectives of European economic policy, such as cohesion and employment. You cannot have blind faith in markets as a solution to all economic problems. Competition policy must intervene against large private and financial oligopolies, because they distort market rules in their favor, from the field to industry. But it must also respect those policies that seek to democratize the economy under public control. Competition policy has often been used to dismantle and privatize the most varied public services or to support public investment, which is critical to industry and innovation, and we certainly oppose this. Nor do we believe that a 'competitive' market is a neutral institution. On the contrary, we consider that using the degradation of wages and working conditions as a way of lowering prices is an anti-competitive practice, as it degrades the social bases on which an efficient and fair market can be constituted. We believe in issues such as tax avoidance and value the Commission starting to go in that direction, but we hope that both investigations and sanctions on multinationals that do not pay their taxes will be increased so that competition policy is effectively deterrent.

name: Michel REIMON
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the As I have also shown in the speeches now, one of the central issues of competition policy in Europe is tax policy, tax competition between the 28 states – and one is tempted to say against each other.  The 28 governments are undermining each other's tax base to attract large corporations, and offering a few large corporations zero-point tax rates – a few percent. This cannot continue. This is rightly an essential position in this report and is rightly criticised by most groups here and amendments are being proposed. The main task of competition law is to prevent the formation of cartels. Why? Because cartels can have influence and can collude with each other. That is exactly what the 28 governments should do in tax policy. They should come to an end and try to make smart and cooperative tax policies together as influential lysmis as possible, rather than undercutting each other. We should cooperate, but we should not compete against each other. This is not just about the taxation of large corporations. It is also about the income base of our countries, our governments, the preservation of welfare states, the preservation of the education system and also the financing of current issues. That is rightly one of the essential points in this report. It is right that competition policy should be entered under the codecision procedure, that the European Parliament should be able to participate in competition policy in the future. We should press for much more say in this in the future. One more point would be highlighted: the digital world, the digital future. The report criticises Google's market power, especially the mobile device sector. Google was first named in this report last year. This year, several large digital groups are mentioned, whose market power is to be examined. I think that we should continue this practice next year and perhaps mention european corporations, whose practices we have to criticise, by name in these reports.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, this is a very long motion which by the standards of the EU certainly does contain some passages of good sense, but there is one key paragraph that leaps out and that may help to solve a riddle for British voters: why are so many multinational corporations so wedded to Britain staying in the EU? As paragraph 77 notes, ‘new entrants and SMEs doing business in only one country are penalised as compared to multinational companies, which can shift profits or implement other forms of aggressive tax planning through a variety of decisions and instruments available to them only’. The paragraph also ‘notes with concern that, all things being equal, the resulting lower tax liabilities leave multinationals with higher post-tax profits, and create an uneven playing field’. There we have it! The EU is a corporatist racket, and therefore British working people and small and medium-sized businesses alike would be better off out.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. In this report, we have succeeded in identifying two priorities of particular political relevance, namely tax and state aid law and, secondly, the digital economy. The rapporteur, Mr Langen, is particularly grateful for this. It is precisely in the examination of the LuxLeaks scandal that the first aspect, namely the financial and state aid aspect, will be of particular importance, because it will lead to a significant change in the corporate tax regime in some Member States with regard to multinationals. It will help prevent tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning and increase tax justice in Europe. And you, Commissioner, showed it again just last week with your saying, when you declared the Belgian special scheme, which allowed massive tax rebates on foreign exchange surpluses of multinational corporations, to be inadmissible. Prominent names include the largest Belgian brewer or the oil company BP or the German BASF. Celebrity names are among them, and the transaction volume you reclaim –the demand – is considerable. A further two investigations are pending, which come from a second area.  Digital economy: There will have to be significant changes in the area of merger control and antitrust proceedings, otherwise the market-changing position of digital companies will not be met.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). Mr President, misleading, worrying and a basic lie are contained in the report on competitiveness. Misleading concerns supposedly equal competition, but it always leads to the domination of monopolies. The concern is related to competition with Russia, China and in particular the United States, the digital economy with online sales of billions without frontiers, the automotive industry, transport, telecommunications, the media, food and agricultural products in view of the Transatlantic Agreement, and even the energy sector, where competitiveness means wars and refugees , state funding which is reduced in areas such as public health, education, welfare, but is not reduced for the banks, the recapitalisation of which the people pay, as well as the legal capital exemptions, despite the false criticism that is supposed to be made in tax havens.  But then there's the big lie. What is hidden is the condition of competitiveness, is that the reduction of so-called labour costs will automatically be ensured by the national competitiveness councils together with the European Union and governments. There is no good and bad competitiveness, because competitiveness always means popular sacrifices for the market economy, for capitalism. Instead of serving competitiveness, the people must declare war on it in order to regain their own power.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: – Mr President, I would like to say from the outset that I appreciate the work of the European Commission, the work of your colleagues, Commissioner, in the implementation of European competition policy. We must recognise that every case investigated is complex, requires professionalism and, as a rule, comes under the examination of European justice. However, I think a serious analysis needs to be done. How was it possible for the European Commission for years not to lean on tax practices which, here we see now, in the case of the investigation in Belgium, constitute violations of State aid. It is inadmissible that this has happened. It took a huge public scandal for the European institutions to become aware that we have a serious problem here. I ask the European Commission, I ask you to pay full attention to these tax practices wherever they are, in any Member State, and obviously also allocate the necessary resources to investigate them.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – I would like to highlight three issues in the very short time available to me. First of all, I would like to comment on the subject that many colleagues have already stated here, notably the tax practices and distorting effects of multinationals and the situation in the small and medium-sized enterprises sector. I will be very simple, and I would like to recommend this to the Commissioner. I believe that a lot of governments care about certain multinationals, but I think it would also be worth saying at the principle level in Europe that the small and medium-sized enterprises sector is just as important. I would even go so far as to say that although any government should grant tax relief to any multinational, it should be automatically extended to the entire small business sector. The other, this concerns my country, Hungary, this is the situation of the Paks nuclear power plant. Commissioner, you have dealt with this issue a lot, but the way I see it, the Hungarian Government is playing tricks here and is stalling. I would very much like to see a professional, legally unassaiable, but a real investigation carried out as soon as possible.  And the last thing that Budapest overturned today was Uber's. My question: when will there finally be a European, fundamental regulation of services at Community level?

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the This report contains many very sensible wordings. I strongly support the measures to be put in place in the area of equal tax competition, in particular the common corporate tax base and country-by-country reporting.  But there are also things in it that you can only shake your head about. For example, the pleasing demand that the European Parliament should have more influence over competition policy. That is precisely the wrong way to go.  Competition policy must be kept free of political influence. Frankly, it bothers me very much that the Commissioner, Mrs Vestager, has to carry out the investigations into the unfair exploitation of tax practices by individual countries under the chairmanship of President Juncker, who in turn is himself one of the suspects in all these events. We need an independent competition authority. We need the independence of competition policy in the European Union, and that is why we do not want the European Parliament to be influenced here.

name: Marco VALLI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in this annual report on competition there are a number of elements that we can support and common sense, starting with the Google case, the defence of whistleblowers, public country-by-country reporting, for which we are a waiting for a report shortly in the spring from the Commission. We want to see an awareness of the need for such measures. There is no mention of distortions of competition, which I think are fundamental, one of all the main problems is, of course, the euro, because it distorts competition by a system of fixed exchange rates between essentially different economies: the example of the German surplus on the balance of payments has been the most striking example of this for several years. On the state aid framework, okay for the Commission to sanction multinationals at last. The problem is that sanctions are then repaid to countries such as the Netherlands and Luxembourg, which have encouraged these elusive practices. One last time, even in this report, Juncker is not mentioned, which is the cause of these elusive practices: we should give him political responsibility instead.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Mr President, the European Union's competition policy is not a tool to safeguard the European Republic, because the Union itself, as the case may be, is biased for or against companies or companies. It distorts competition in the single market, implements targeted aggressive tax policies and practices, and does not avoid inconsistencies in its treatment at corporate and national level.  They accuse Google, for example, of abusing a dominant position. Very well, because there has to be control. At the same time, however, bribery scandals and illegal activities of companies such as German Siemens and Volkswagen remain in the doe.  In Greece over the last five years, the Troika, by abolishing all notions of a sovereign state, has intervened in the drafting of tax laws resulting in increased tax evasion and tax fraud by ghost companies engaged in wholly non-existent credit suffocation activities, the increase in austerity leading to poverty and poverty, as well as the worsening of the situation in migration, economic policy, fundamental freedoms and competition. You have achieved your primary objective: the full subjugation of nation states to the Europe of banks and oligarchs.  Your fear of the rise of nationalism is not, as you say, about the abolition of democracy, intolerance and homophobia. What you fear now is that national movements, gaining grassroots support, will eventually force you to pay for your anti-democratic policies.  (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Mr President, the promotion of a real functioning single market is one of the priorities of the European Union and also one of the areas on which most of us would easily be in agreement. That is why we should promote competition and remove distortions and barriers. If we do so, this will be to the benefit of our economies and our people.  Let me mention three areas in which we should make progress: the energy sector, which is suffering a market fragmentation, distortion and different levels of national support; the telecoms market, where we should maintain competition and allow the development of a vibrant digital economy; and transport – better road transport will mean huge benefits for people, as we can see, for example, in my country. On the other hand, let me ask that one be cautious about using the term ‘social dumping’. The fact that that someone is getting lower wages is disturbing, but this does not necessarily mean there is any social dumping, because of the different cost structure and wages in the economy. I would also like to highlight the area of taxation, where the Commission and Parliament have made substantial progress. We are missing only one thing – namely bold action taken by the Council. Lastly, let me thank the Commissioner and the Commission for their very robust actions and very courageous approach. At the same time, let me say that we are not calling for more sanctions, but for better rules and for respect for the rules.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur for this report, Mr Langen, for his work, for having drafted and agreed on a report I think is very positive. And I would also like to congratulate and encourage commissioner Vestager on the daily work, who is doing a great job which, together with Commissioner Moscovici's work to try to move forward on a corporate tax base, can help to shape a joint fiscal policy in the euro area as a whole , to turn a back on the euro and the euro area as a whole. In any event, I would like to ask Mrs Vestager about the mid-December judgment on the tax lease system of the Spanish shipyards. Because this investigation, which opened in the last legislature, has had very negative effects on shipyards in my constituency, Asturias, which have had very difficult, very difficult times, stems from that investigation, and have managed to get ahead and maintain a very high level of competitiveness, and now they are looking forward to new markets to be able to offer their ships, their vessels , to all global markets. But it is true that this investigation — and the judgment we knew, which somehow paralyzed and criticised the Commission's work — has been a very hard stone on the road in recent years, and I would like to ask Mrs Vestager whether she has drawn conclusions from that judgment and what we can tell the Asturian, Spanish, Spanish shipyard sector , for the future.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, zero euros, this is how much corporate taxes the five largest investment banks in the world paid in 2014 to the UK. I do not need to tell you why losses are recorded in London and profits are recorded in Luxembourg. This has to change. Eu competition policy will not work if competition is not fair. Thanks to the Commission's reports, the most outrageous tax piglets have now been brought to light. However, this is only the beginning. The EU needs a single corporate tax base and more transparency in business results and the taxes they pay. In this way, we can prevent the tax base from eroding and guarantee fair competition.

name: Brian HAYES
text: – Mr President, can I congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Langen, and also congratulate the Commissioner on her speech to Parliament this evening? It is crucially important that we have a fair competition policy to ensure that the single market works for everyone. We have to make sure that if dominant players are abusing their position then we have a strong position against that, and I very much agree with what the Commissioner said this evening in terms of adapting more power to national competition authorities. It is really important that more power be vested in the 28 competition authorities, and that they can go after bad practice wherever they see it. I also agree with her that we need global enforcement, especially at an OECD level. My concluding remark is that, where investigations are taken up by the Commissioner and her DG, it is crucially important that they are brought to a speedy conclusion. It is important that they are evidence-based and that they are legal-based, not based on political rhetoric from this House or elsewhere, not based on an anti-US bias, which sometimes is heard across this Chamber, but are based on fact and evidence, not based on supposition. I think it is crucially important – as the point was made some time ago – that where those investigations are taken up they are concluded in a timely way. It does not help competition policy in Europe for extended investigations to be taking place over a four- or five-year period. I greatly respect the Commissioner, as she knows; we worked in a previous life together. I also know that many of these cases were taken up by her predecessor. It is now time to resolve them for competition policy, for a fair industrial policy and for a level playing field across the European Union.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Mr. President, thank you. I applaud the Commissioner and congratulate my rapporteur Colleague Langen on her excellent report. Strengthening the single market is the cornerstone of the European Semester, an investment plan and a plan to grow and develop employment in the EU. There is still a lot of work ahead of us regarding building a single market – from building a digital single market, e-administration and implementing new public procurement rules, through the Energy Union, building a single capital market and banking union to the most important thing we are discussing today, further developing competition policy as a cornerstone of the development of the single market.  I thank the rapporteur for the important proposals that I think need to be adopted and included in the rules. For example, in antitrust procedures, the rules on fines should definitely be extended to those responsible natural persons. I fully agree that state aid to banks should be conditional on their lending to SMEs. Opening sources of financing to entrepreneurs to modernise business and innovation is a precondition without which we will not initiate stronger growth in Europe.  Likewise, the Role of the European Parliament in competition policy matters needs to be completely changed. We are looking for an active role, adjoining and involvement in investigative procedures.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to say that I absolutely echo what my colleague Brian Hayes said. Secondly, I would like to focus on the position of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) and mention three points from our report, which the rapporteur took on board.  One of them is innovation. Competition and innovation are interconnected and both are crucially important for economic growth and prosperity.  E-government and e-governance are instrumental in the efficient monitoring of infringements and for ensuring transparency in both the public as well as the private sector.  Last but not least, the smooth functioning of competition in e-commerce not only contributes to economic growth but also means lower transaction costs as well as lower prices and a greater range of choice for consumers. The digital economy and the transformation of traditional industry into digital are among the most promising growth sectors for the EU, and the only way we will be able to unify online and offline trade is if we have and implement EU competition rules. This is something we should aim to do as soon as possible.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Mr. President, competition policy is an important instrument of action in the European Union's internal market. Excessive concentration of economic and financial power should be prevented for the benefit of a small number of individuals. The new objectives are often not achieved in practice due to oligopolial and monopoly activities.  Annual losses due to the existence of cartels are between EUR 181 billion and EUR 320 billion, which is around 3 % of the G.D.P. of the European Union. We need an immediate upgrade of the existing legal framework to implement this important policy. A particularly sensitive issue is State aid: they must not be used illegally, anitcompetitively and protectionistly.  But when it comes to state support for peripheral regions and islands, flexibility needs to be increased. I welcome the decision to include social assistance for the transport of residents from remote regions in the general block exemption regulation. The same principle should be applied in Croatia, where the pilot project of the emergency helicopter medical service was recently halted despite the high number of interventions; about 30% of the inhabitants of Croatia unfortunately do not have the same availability of urgent medical care.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the European Union must abandon bilingualism and evasiveness and immediately apply the rules of law for the protection of free competition and the prohibition of State aid in the case of the Leonteian concession of Greece's fourteen regional airports to the State-owned German company Fraport. Because with the control of these fourteen regional airports, Fraport, which simultaneously controls Frankfurt Airport, Burgas Airport in Bulgaria, Ljubljana Airport in Slovenia, is gaining a dominant monopoly position in airport management in the European Union and Greece. Fraport now controls, through Lufthansa, which is its shareholder, the movement of tourism in Greece, Bulgaria and Slovenia. It also takes eur 500 million in violation of European Union state aid rules as a dowry for projects carried out at the airports of Thessaloniki and Chania. Does the Commission hear this? If so, what does it intend to do?

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, we need more Europe. At a time when many are saying that we need less Of Europe, I am clear and confident that we need more Europe to solve many problems in our European Union.  The topic we are talking about now – the protection of competition and everything that is happening with multinational companies that are trying precisely because of non-unity policy, tax policy and other policies, because of the disunity of the Member States and the inability of the European Commission to react at all times, shows that we need more Europe. Especially when we talk about the digital market, or as the energy market has been mentioned by the way. I think that's where everything you said, Madam Commissioner, was clearly stated that we need more Europe.  In this context, my support for this report, you and your efforts as Commissioner to strengthen the Single Market, is also supportive.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to ask the Commissioner a specific question, particularly in relation to competition, unfair competition and State aid. In particular, it concerns a company, the largest steel works in Europe, ilva, which is located in the city of Taranto. I therefore ask you: what decisions does the Commission intend to take because the citizens, committees, associations and the 5-Star Movement, through its spokespeople, have continually sent reports, dossiers denouncing unfair competition from this company and State aid that we completely deny, because it is a company kept alive by an unconscious and irresponsible Italian Government.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – Compliance with the competition rules is the basis for fair competition on the global market. It's easy to be better, and it's easy to make bigger profits if you don't respect the rules of the game, if you're avoiding paying taxes and getting unauthorized help from the state. All that benefits these companies is harming us, consumers,. That's why we usually pay a higher price and get worse services. The distortion of this market due to cartel arrangements means a loss of at least three per cent of GDP for the European Union each year, and tax evasion and fraud take away as much as a billion. A particular challenge recently is the digital market. For this reason, we will also need to adapt the competition rules. I consider it very important, as the Commissioner mentioned, that we also have independent institutions at national level, and I therefore welcome the debate that you are opening up. And, of course, thank you to my colleague Langen for his excellent report.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: – Mr President, the purpose of European competition rules is to ensure equal and fair conditions for all businesses, regardless of their size or marketing capacities, through which they can reach consumers. Therefore, even from the point of view of a fair market, possible differences in identical products raise a number of questions. It is necessary to ask whether, in the case of so-called dual quality, consumers' expectations are being met, and also how their decision-making is determined by the brand under which the product is different.  I believe that the European Parliament will repeatedly support the provision calling on the Commission to investigate possible differences in the composition of branded products and to assess whether it has negative consequences for the functioning of the internal market and also for the competitiveness of its actors, especially small and medium-sized enterprises. I would like to thank my colleagues in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection and in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs who supported my amendment. I believe that the Commission will finally take this issue seriously.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. President, this report unfortunately follows the latest trend and promotes a Union-wide repressive tax policy and for this reason I cannot support it. However, I welcome some positive recommendations such as on the development of e-government or on unfair and illegal clauses and practices used by the banking sector in consumer contracts. The latter in Croatia has caused great trauma for tens of thousands of citizens. Namely, there are serious indications, but also some judgments of Croatian courts, about how banks unfairly led citizens to take out loans in Swiss francs, which later, due to large fluctuations in the exchange rate, brought more than 50 thousand Croatian citizens to the very brink of poverty. These are banks owned by European banks and that is why this is also a European issue. If we want a homogeneous and stable common market, we must seriously address these immoral practices that exploit the political-legal lability of young European democracies.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, I wish to thank the Commissioner and our rapporteur, Mr Langen. I am very happy that this report deals with real bread-and-butter issues, and I am referring here to the remarks in the paragraphs on the food supply chain. This is an issue that the Committee on Agriculture is working very hard on. We have concerns around unfair trading practices, and I suppose there is a question, Commissioner, of when unfair trading practices become anti—competitive practices. The issues for us are around the sustainability of the food supply chain in a situation where the suppliers of inputs to agriculture are becoming more concentrated, the processors of agricultural products are becoming more concentrated and the eventual retail markets are in the hands of a very few. This is about choice for our consumers as well as about fairness for our producers. I hope, Commissioner, that you understand these points that I am making and I know that tomorrow we will have an opportunity to exchange views in a meeting on this issue. This is an important matter.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Langen for a great report and Commissioner Vestager for great work in ensuring a level playing field when it comes to competition; that is very important.  There is one thing I would like to raise today, and that relates to the different agreements between Member States and multinational corporations. When you reach a finding and establish that these deals that have been made are illegal and that tax revenue has to be paid back, it is a little bit of a provocation, I think, that the tax revenue that has been stolen from other Member States by these tax agreements between Member States and multinational corporations are not given back to the Member States they have been stolen from but that it is actually given to the Member States who have made this illegal tax agreement. So, I would like to ask the Commission whether it will propose new legislation that will ensure that the ones who are cheating are not being rewarded afterwards; that the cheating Member States should pay back the tax revenue either to the Member State they cheated or to the EU budget, so that they will receive a real punishment and not a reward.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you very much. I almost wish that you could see the notes that I have taken both of the general remarks and the very specific questions. I would like to try to go through a number of the questions being raised, but this is a very good illustration of why I very much appreciate the meetings, for instance in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON), where we have more time to go in depth, and also with more concrete questions. Starting with the question from Mr Fernández, this case is still under assessment. Of course we are working with it as fast as possible in order to finalise it but I cannot go into the detail now since the investigation is still open.  When it comes to the question of remote areas and public services I think it is very important to pay attention to the rules that we have, both in the general Block Exemption Regulation and in services of general economic interest, because it preserves room for national governments to make sure that they can have a public sector working as they wish , decided by the national democracy. My second point is that within this set of rules there is room for special treatment of remote areas for obvious reasons, because we are differently situated here in our Union. When it comes to the matter of Paks it is very difficult to say at present what will come out. You probably know that we have formally opened investigations to see if there are state aids involved and, if that is the case, whether that state aid can be justified. These investigations have only just opened and therefore it is very difficult to see when they will end. But of course we will look into this. On the question of the food supplies chain raised by Ms McGuinness this is, as you say, a very important issue. On this we are working very closely with the national competition agencies and we are trying to promote a new set of rules that enables producers to help each other, to gain more strength when it comes both to the inputs but also to reselling into the retail chain, because basically enabling the different parts of the supply chain to be strengthened is part of that goal. I think we are pursuing that together.  A lot of Members have addressed the question of taxation. When it comes to the question of recovery, raised among others by Mr Kofod, I understand why you feel that this is a provocation. I think we have to find solutions outside of the state aid regime, because basically, since state aid control was invented, the rules have been such that the state that has been given the favourable ruling has had to effect recovery from the businesses in question. So maybe a broader debate would be in place. Best, of course, would be that there would in the future be no question of recovery if companies pay the taxes that they are supposed to pay – not only the majority as today, but every company.  I very much appreciate the broad view taken that we need the strong cooperation also with you on the legislative part, not only on the automatic exchange of information, and on discussing a corporate consolidated tax base eventually, but also in making sure that we hopefully can approach a situation in which profits are being taxed where they are being made. I hope that can be a unifying goal in the processes, going forward. When it comes to taxation as such, I very much appreciate the very strong cooperation with this Chamber and the strong support from this Chamber. I think it is a question of levelling the playing field and I think it is a question of being able to address all those businesses who just pay their taxes. They should know that there is someone looking after the level playing field, ensuring that those who do not pay their taxes actually will do so. A number of you have addressed the question of how we work within the competition field. We try to do our best to be transparent, to publish decisions as soon as confidential information has been taken out, to be much more transparent when it comes to state aid as such, empowering Member States to take many more decisions by themselves. The other side of that coin is to be more transparent about how taxpayers’ money is actually being used.  I am very much engaged in the work to empower national competition agencies, and I hope that we can work with this together, because the strength of the national competition agencies is also the strength of competition law enforcement. I think more than 80% of the decisions taken over the last 10 years have been taken by national competition agencies and that is a very good illustration of the need to strengthen these bodies in order to be able to work for national citizens. On digital developments I very much appreciate the broad recognition of the fact that we are digitalising our economy. It is not just a question of a sector, it is a digitalised economy, digitalised government, digitalised services in general. I hope that our concrete casework will enable businesses to guide themselves when they digitalise.  On the Google case, as asked by Mr Tremosa, we are now in the process of analysing the responses that came from the Statement of Objection. This is a very data-rich response that we have got, and of course we will do our best to analyse this with an open mind, as we should in a Union based on the rule of law, and therefore of course there will be no such thing as a strategic Statement of Objection. If there ever is a Statement of Objection, for instance in the Android case, it will be purely based on the facts of the case and the evidence of the case.  Which is also a good note on which to recognise what was said by Mr Hayes, that we truly need to make sure that companies know, governments know, that when we enforce competition law we do that in a purely fact-based way, with an open mind, very stringently and always remembering – at least I try to do this on a day-to-day basis – that this has to stand the test of our courts , because competition law enforcement is no stronger than the processes, than the rules and how we actually implement the processes. I very much hope that we can continue the structured dialogue that we have been having. I very much appreciate how we have been working with Mr Langen both on this report but also in general, and I hope to be able to come back both to the ECON Committee but also, of course, to the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and Other Measures Similar in Nature or Effect (TAXE2) in order to go into depth with a number of these question that have been raised.  Having said that of course I recognise that there are a number of concrete questions that I have not been able to address, but I do hope to have a second chance to come back to that. Thank you very much to the rapporteur, thank you very much to this Chamber for a very constructive debate tonight.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to thank colleagues for supporting a good competition policy, albeit with different priorities. I would like to thank the Commissioner for taking all the suggestions here, because fair competition benefits consumers and taxpayers. The independence of the competition authority is important so that it can combat and abolish power concentrations and ensure market access. Transparency is just as important. I would like to reiterate what you said, namely that cooperation between competition authorities at national and European level can probably be improved– particularly in the border areas that we have discussed. For example, in the food chain, where national responsibility is usually there because the market shares of retailers in Europe are well below the usual threshold.  I welcome the fact that you believe that further sectoral investigations are useful and necessary. The question of whether the staff is sufficient for this is something that we, as budgetary legislators, must also ask ourselves here. In aviation, or wherever, as the honourable Member has suggested. I would like to make a correction: Mr Marias is so arrested in his fight against Germany that he no longer knows the facts. Fraport is a state-owned company owned by the state of Hesse and the city of Frankfurt, not Lufthansa. Lufthansa is the largest user in Frankfurt, but the claim that Lufthansa now dominates everything because Fraport makes service contracts is pulled by the hair and fits into Mr Marias' world view.  However, I would also like to put some demands into perspective, because competition policy may be overwhelmed. Social dumping cannot do it alone, or because, for example, we have already dealt with the Committee of Inquiry in another form. The Commission, and this is my request, should take the decisions we take tomorrow seriously with a very extensive follow-up assessment. We should also not place too much emphasis on the contradictions that have been expressed here, for example by the ECR, at the heart of our decision. A large majority tomorrow would be a clear signal of support for the Commissioner and for a sensible competition policy.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the If we continue mr Marias' game, we will never finish. In this case, I expressly reject the opinion.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The point is that I also understood, when Mr Marias spoke, that he was referring to that company that may be related to the state that you mentioned. He didn't say he belonged to Lufthansa. He mentioned Lufthansa in parallel with that company, in the same case. That's what I understood. So with this, I explained, if you were paying attention. Please talk together afterwards, because we cannot open the discussion now.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, I am asking for the floor, on the basis of the Rules of Procedure, because my colleague has made characterisations. He said I'm fighting Against Germany.  Firstly, I do not have nationalist views and I wish to stress this to my colleague. I am possessed by a spirit of resistance against the Neo-colonialism that this German policy wants to impose on Greece. Secondly, what I said was that Fraport is a German state-owned company and that it now monopolises the movement and control of airports through Lufthansa, which is its owner. I didn't say Lufthansa was dominant, I said it was a shareholder in Fraport. You now also control the movement of tourism in Greece. I therefore ask the Commissioner, will you allow this? Will you finally take steps to stop illegal competition and, above all, to stop illegal state aid? Five hundred and twenty million euros has been taken by this company. That's the reality. Are you going to intervene on state aid prohibition issues?    (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Gabriel Mato, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a multiannual plan for the recovery of bluefin tuna stocks in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean and repealing Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. 302/2009 [(COM(2015)0180 – C8-0118/2015 – 2015/0096(COD)] (A8–0367/2015).

name: Gabriel MATO
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner, we are discussing the proposal to incorporate into EU law the measures of the multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and mediterranean, approved by ICCAT at the meeting in 2012 and 2014.  As you know, since 2006 there has been a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna which plans to be completed in 2022 and fishermen have made an enormous effort to adjust their respective catches to the reduced catch volume, complying with the strict conditions set out in the plan.  As a result, bluefin tuna biomass recorded a very positive trend in 2008 and in 2014 the regional organization decided to increase the volume of catches initially set until 2017, as there are solvent scientific data showing that populations are at a healthy level of abundance.  In my opinion, the dramatic recovery seen in bluefin tuna stocks in recent years could justify a ICCAT decision to further increase these volumes, and we have asked for it. It is difficult to explain to fishermen engaged in artisanal fishing for bluefin tuna in an absolutely sustainable way – as is the clear case of the Canary Islands, for example – that within 24 hours of opening the fishery they have to withdraw because the quotas are absolutely finished. The legislative initiative we are discussing today is intended to ensure the uniform and effective implementation of this plan throughout the European Union.  The proposal contains technical measures, such as those relating to transfer and introduction operations in a live bluefin tuna cage, including measures relating to the use of stereoscopic chambers to estimate the quantities of bluefin tuna and releases, catch declaration requirements and the implementation of ICCAT's regional observer programme. In general, the Commission's proposal correctly transposes iccAT's relevant recommendations and we believe that in certain cases it goes a little further than what is decided by ICCAT. I would like to recall that the objective of transposing ICCAT recommendations is their uniform application throughout the European Union. It is therefore not intended to start a new debate on what has already been decided. The uniform application aims to ensure a level playing field for all operators involved in tuna fishing, including, in particular, third-country operators. Otherwise, if different rules apply to foreign fleets, all efforts made and all restrictions on fishermen in the European Union will have been in vain.  On the other hand, and this is a very important issue, the Commission proposes to transpose future amendments to this recovery plan through delegated acts, and here we do totally disagree. We believe that the transposition of these recommendations should remain a shared competence between the European Parliament and the Council within the framework of the ordinary procedure and should therefore be adopted in codecision. I have always called for this Parliament to have this codecision and not to attempt to infringe or use practices to try to circumvent Parliament's intervention.  Finally, we welcome the fact that ICCAT's recommendations take into account the specific characteristics of the different tuna fishing gear. In this context, it is necessary to emphasize the role of artisanal fishing gear – such as those used in the Canary Islands or as traditional almadrabas – in the conservation of populations. That is why in this report we place particular emphasis on this allocation of quotas and that particular attention should be paid to traditional activities. I conclude by thanking all the Members who have participated in the amendment process to improve this report and I hope that we will finally have a document that is satisfactory to all.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank Mr Gabriel Mato. The Commission very strongly appreciates the draft report as prepared by the rapporteur, Mr Mato. It is obviously the result of a very good understanding of the issues which surround the status of bluefin tuna, a very important species. It provides a very valuable contribution and also some positive suggestions for the modification of the initial proposal. It is also important to remember that this proposal aims, as has already been explained, to transpose into EU law measures which were already adopted by ICCAT, the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna. They were adopted in 2014, and they have been applicable to Member States and operators since July 2015. It is important to say that this recovery plan has been very widely acknowledged as a success story, and the stock of bluefin tuna is well on its way towards recovery. Having said that, there is and there can be no room for complacency. We still need to continue to give priority to the sustainable management of this important stock. Measures adopted in the recovery plan by ICCAT are therefore crucial. Many of the provisions of the recovery plan are directly applicable to all our Member States. However, transposition is needed to ensure that the provisions applicable to natural or legal persons are also complied with in the European Union. This is necessary to ensure that compliance is there – the compliance of the Union with its international obligations – and it is also there to maintain the EU’s credibility in sustainable fisheries management. While this report largely meets our expectations, there are still some divergences. This is the case regarding the interpretation of the competences of the respective institutions when transposing provisions from the Regional Fisheries Management Organisations (RFMOs). However, we are confident that they can be solved.  Regarding the provisions for the empowerment of the Commission to adopt delegated acts, the Commission strongly believes that due to the frequent amendments of the recovery plan in ICCAT, this is a crucial element within the proposal. Why? Because such delegated acts are required in order to swiftly incorporate into EU law any future amendments of the recovery plan at ICCAT level. These amendments are bound to, and do, occur regularly. In these cases, going through the full ordinary legislative procedure very often impedes us from implementing new measures in time to ensure the European Union’s compliance with our international obligations. The adoption of delegated acts by the Commission provides the possibility to accurately and, most importantly, rapidly transpose ICCAT measures into EU law by amending only the non-essential elements of the legislative acts. This requires appropriate consultations including consultations at expert level. It also requires the timely and appropriate transmission of relevant documents to the European Parliament and to the Council.  The Commission also believes that it should be empowered to adopt implementing acts. This is justified by the frequent need to establish how certain measures of the recovery plan should be implemented at the level of the EU. We need this to achieve a level playing field for the Member States and also to ensure the effectiveness of the same measures. This is particularly relevant for control measures introduced in ICCAT whose interpretation could be different amongst different Member States and which are directly linked to the respect of quotas and other international obligations. The Commission’s proposal for a regulation on the multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna provides a very balanced and effective follow-up to the ICCAT agreement. The report of Mr Mato, I will repeat, is a very valuable contribution and I look forward to hearing the views of this Chamber.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate Mr Mato and I would like to support this new proposal that aims at transposing into European law measures under the Multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan in the eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean as adopted by ICCAT.  In order to rebuild tuna stocks, we need to follow certain steps. First of all, we have to set up a gradual reduction in total allowable catch levels. This is very important. But we also need to impose stricter fishing within certain areas and time periods and new minimal sizes. This is also important. Finally, we have to reinforce the ICCAT scheme of joint international inspection.  I agree that the rules should be applied in a uniform way in order to ensure a level playing field for all engaged in tuna fishing including, and most importantly, for non-EU operators. Otherwise, if we think about it, if we apply different rules to foreign fleets, all efforts and restrictions applying to EU fishermen will have no results and it will seem that we are actually penalising our own fishermen. We have to make sure that we do not penalise our own fishermen by imposing on them stricter measures. With that, I would like once again to express support Mr Mato’s work on this file.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today I do not just want to talk about the transposition of the ICAT recommendations, with which we agree, and also with Mr Mato, who is the rapporteur, we discussed at length among the groups in committee. In my opinion, we have the opportunity to address important issues relating to tuna, both as regards the ecology of the species, in terms of the recovery of stocks, and the socio-economic factors linked to it, in particular, its fishing. As we know, the European Union, together with the Member States, is a contracting party to ICAT and in 2014, combined with Genoa, that my city, at the ICAT annual meeting, welcomed the news of the positive data on the state of good health of bluefin tuna and, there, a 20 % increase in the quotas allocated to the contracting states was decided. The quotas for bluefin tuna are laid down in the ICAT, but the distribution criteria are decided at the discretion of the individual Member States.
