Unfortunately, in very many cases only a few shipowners benefit from these quotas, while small-scale fishermen are substantially excluded, despite an increase of this 20%. Not forgetting that, if a bluefin tuna is accidentally caught, the small fisherman is in danger of being severely penalised. A fairer distribution would therefore have been expected, and for this Group of the European People's Party (S&D) it has tabled an amendment denouncing the current monopoly mechanism for large shipowners and calling on the Member States to review the system of bluefin tuna fishing quotas more fairly.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. – Mr. President, fisheries as an economic branch today depend more than ever on the balance between the social sustainability of the fleet and the conservation of fish stocks. Protecting our marine resources is essential for the future of fisheries, but these futures cannot be without fishermen who, despite restrictions, must continue to see their economic interest in this activity. I think that in this report we have recognised well the need for this balance and that is why I am particularly honoured to have been able to work on it with Rapporteur Mata and other fellow shadow rapporteurs.   After the restoration of bluefin tuna stocks as a direct result of many years of restrictive measures and recovery plans, we are now finally able to increase the quotas for tuna fishing in 2016 and thus have a positive impact on the growth of exports, but also on the earnings of fishermen who catch small blue fish that feed on tuna from farming.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank Mr Mato for the work he has done and we support this report because he continues to delve deeper into the plan for the recovery of bluefin tuna in the Mediterranean, on a posibilistic and successful scientific basis. The progression of biomass certifies this and encourages it to compensate for the effort made so far by a sector with a more generous TAC. Not for nothing, in 2012, to recover the species, it lost 58% of the fishing capacity available to it before this process was launched. We also believe it is essential that fleets operating in the Mediterranean, whether European or third-country, operate on an equal footing. The European sector cannot be penalised to the detriment of third-country producers when iccAT negotiations fail and especially when activity occurs in the same ecosystem. Finally, we are committed to total support for traditional and small-scale fishing, such as the Canarian one, and we claim its most characteristic arts, such as almadraba, which offer great selectivity and are environmentally efficient. We are committed to more control and to be stricter for different sectors, but we do not agree with expressions that criminalize those operating within a regulatory and control framework designed to combat unsofiable practices by all operators. Finally, and from an institutional perspective, we also support Parliament's role in transposing the recommendations of the regional fisheries management organisation, because we bring transparency, balance and legitimacy. The opaque negotiations on fishing quotas in European waters, as indicated by the Lisbon Treaty, are an eloquent example of what happens when these processes move away from citizens and their legitimate representatives. That is why, Commissioner, I hope you will listen to all the interventions in this Parliament, so that we can exercise our competence with joint work.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Bluefin tuna is perhaps the most famous endangered species we know of and that is a dubious honour. In 50 years, the number of bluefin tuna has fallen by almost 90%. As a result, the species has been brought to the edge of the abyss and the reason for this was the serious overfishing that has taken place for decades. Overfishing, largely due to the subsidised overcapacity of our European fishing fleet. In 2006, measures were taken to reduce overfishing and protect tuna. But while it seems to be working somewhat, there is still no reason for euphoria.  Because if the number of tuna drops to almost zero and then that population doubles again, then you have twice as much as zero.  Bluefin tuna is still listed on the red list of endangered species at the hands of humans and many organisations warn that it is too early to fish more for tuna. And that is exactly what the rapporteur and the European Commission want: more fishing! We are not even talking about the bycatch of other species, all species which, like tuna, are facing a gruesome death. The Party for Animals does not agree, because those who decide to fish more for endangered species are committing predatory attacks on our planet and thus on future generations. I also believe that agricultural subsidies and fisheries subsidies should be abolished.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, our delegation is in favour of these reports or on which we have worked together with our colleagues and the rapporteur, Mr Amato, because it is important to take on board the indications of the ICAT, which has shown that it has worked well in recent years and because it is important to frame it with European legislation. Until the end of the last century, tuna was only fished in a traditional way, then it became an industry and the resource collapsed to 3%.  The quota system, which has been included, seems to be working at the moment – as Commissioner Vella says – and so the direction taken seems to be the right one, although Perhaps I share the concerns of those who say that it is premature to increase quotas. Quotas, however, work at the environmental level, but apparently do not work as far as socio-economic aspects are concerned. There is also a problem of social justice: traditional fishing has remained marginal and we will therefore support the amendment tomorrow, although we do not like it very much in form, tabled by Mrs Briano because we think that this injustice that has arisen between those who do not have any quota and those who hold large quantities of it is still to be settled. This is a problem which may not be in the right place to discuss it, but Parliament can take this opportunity to make its voice heard on this point too.

name: Ulrike RODUST
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Big fish with small fishing - that's possible! This is particularly true of bluefin tuna in the East Atlantic and the Mediterranean. Small and small-scale fishing generally has a good reputation in terms of its selectivity and its low impact on marine ecosystems, as well as in terms of low energy consumption. In the basic regulation, we have provided for appropriate provisions for this fishery. However, in order for these fishermen to be able to hold the helm, they must be adequately resourced. In accordance with Articles 16 and 17 of the basic Regulation, each Member State shall decide how to allocate its fishing opportunities to vessels flying its flag. Transparent and objective criteria will be applied. But not only that. Fishing techniques with low energy consumption and high selectivity are to be promoted. The Committee on Fisheries has already raised the flag in its vote on this multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna, and it has yet to be waved sufficiently. That is why the S&D Group is calling for a review of the existing distribution systems of the Member States and for adequate integration of small and small-scale fisheries. We see as a red cloth the often lack of transparency with regard to the distribution criteria. I therefore welcome the fact that the fishing plans to be submitted annually by the Member States under this recovery plan must list the distribution of quotas by group of fishing gear.

name: Czesław HOC
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Each of us knows that bluefin tuna is a particularly valuable fish, it is a peculiar gift of nature. Some describe it as a floating living gold mine moving at breakneging speed – so it is necessary to create a wise and prudent policy for this species of fish to last forever. It is not so good at all, because we know that this species is on the endangered list, which is why the European Parliament not only has the right, but also the obligation, to transpose the provisions on the multiannual plan for the recovery of tuna stocks.  A few brief observations – firstly, the legislation must be clear, coherent and unambiguous in terms of conservation, recovery and fishing for tuna. Secondly, enforcement must be strict for all tuna operators, including, and perhaps above all, for entities outside the European Union. The third brief remark is the maximum reduction and even the elimination of illegal, even criminal tuna fishing.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Madam President, we welcome the inclusion in this report of a specific reference to the traditional art of almadraba. It is a positive step in recognizing the strategic importance of this fishing art for sustainable management of bluefin tuna, a truly fundamental natural resource for the fishing communities that exploit it and for the ecological balance of our seas.  This report is also a warning to governments such as Spain, which has traditionally marginalized the almadraba in the allocation of quotas for bluefin tuna, ignoring the indications of European regulation.  The text we will vote on tomorrow points to the sustainable nature of this art and the need for it to be supported to ensure its socio-economic viability. We hope that the report will serve to get a turn in favour of this art, which, among other things, does selective fishing in sizes, which is employment-intensive and sustainable and environmentally friendly, because we want to live almadrabas in our seas.

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: – Madam President, well tonight we are talking about the disastrous level of bluefin tuna stocks, quotas and commercial fishing methods.  Not one person in this room has mentioned angling, and I think our whole approach to fisheries simply is wrong. We have a quota system for most of our species, which of course in mixed fisheries has meant decades of discards on a truly horrendous scale. And whilst I, and everybody else, want a proper, sustainable commercial sector, we are massively underestimating the power of recreational sea angling to bring good – not just economically, but also the environmental benefit of our stocks not being hammered in the same way. In the United Kingdom, just anglers targeting bass alone bring in GBP 200 million a year to the UK economy – far more than the level of commercial landings. In America they have got this right. They recognised on the East Coast that the striped bass was an asset. After a complete moratorium they now regard that stock as primarily an angling resource which has led to a massive boom in jobs and boatbuilding and all those East Coast coastal communities benefiting massively.  But what have we done with our declining bass stock? We put a total ban in place for anglers, with after 1 July a derisory one fish limit per angler, whilst at the same time allowing the small commercial boats to use gillnets to catch 1.3 tonnes per month each. What we have done is wholly disproportionate, and frankly we are punishing anglers who did not cause the problem.  And we did it, Commissioner, through a regulation that you, a Maltese bureaucrat, proposed, that was nodded through the Council of Ministers, that was not debated in the European Parliament Committee on Fisheries, not debated or voted on here, certainly not debated on in the British Parliament, and that will turn now ordinary people into criminals if they pursue their Magna Carta rights.  And I hope that all 800 000 UK sea anglers say ‘damn the European Commission’ and vote for us to get back control and management of our own waters. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Richard CORBETT
text: blue-card question. – Mr Farage, as you know, the common fisheries policy went through a major reform recently, hailed even by Greenpeace as a good reform. At that time, you were a member of the Committee on Fisheries of this parliament. I believe you attended, in two and a half years, just one or two meetings.  At a time when all these issues were at stake, where major battles were going on, do you not think that any remarks you have about the common fisheries policy would have perhaps a bit more credibility if you actually bothered to do your job and show up to the meetings of the committee that you are a member of?

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: blue-card answer. – Nice try, Mr Corbett, but clearly you were not listening, old son, were you? If I had attended every single meeting of the Committee on Fisheries for all the years I have been in this Parliament – I am not a member of the Committee anymore – there is nothing I could have done to help up to 800 000 people from our country who go out and target bass for their leisure activity. They provide jobs in coastal communities, they provide jobs in tackle shops and tackle manufacture, they provide, in many cases, the real important backdrop for harbours and coastal communities. This ban was brought in without it being debated in the Committee on Fisheries – so there is not much point going there – and without it being debated or voted on in this Parliament. It was done by a regulation put forward by a Maltese bureaucrat we cannot vote for and we cannot remove. Mr Corbett, what I want is for us to have a proper, functioning democracy and then we can discuss how we manage UK stocks. Nice try. Bad luck, old son.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Madam President, I would like to say, first of all, that we agree with Mr Mato's report on the implementation of ICCAT's recommendations. But all the speakers, with some exception that I do not want to recall, have emphasized two fundamental issues and I would also like to join this debate. One issue: uniform and effective application. Of course. But everyone. And what is happening, what fishermen criticise, is that the European Union, the Member States, do make this application uniform and effective, but not the third countries. And that in the Mediterranean causes a lot of problems. So take note, Commissioner, too. The bluefin tuna stocks are recovering and I'm very happy. But to the fishermen who have fallen, to the small-scale fishermen who have fallen, we will no longer be able to recover them. Monopolies in the distribution of bluefin tuna in the Member States must therefore be ended. You intervene in these States, like mine, in Spain, where you do not benefit small arts such as almadrabas, which are now contained in this report.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: – We are talking today about the tuna recovery plan and its transposition into European rules. It looks good. I congratulate the rapporteur on the very pure way in which he has handled it. I believe that we will be able to reach agreement with the Commission in a number of trialogues.  This is a hopeful development, but on the other hand, I am very concerned about the other fish species in the Mediterranean. Almost all these species are severely overfished in the Mediterranean. The hake, for example, is estimated to be 10 times as much caught as is justified. Ever younger hake is caught and therefore no longer reproduces sufficiently. This phenomenon occurs in several species of fish. I therefore ask Commissioner Vella: come up with a rapid recovery plan for hake in the Mediterranean, but also show ambition for all other species in the multi-annual plans for the Mediterranean. After all, this sea is going to break down in that way and so is the fish in this sea.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: Thank you, Madam President. Commissioner, it is always a pleasure to have you here with us. I would also like to greet the rapporteur, Gabriel Mato. He has done an important job and he refers to Parliament a number of decisions which, as he rightly points out, belong to us. I want to reinforce the amendment proposed by the Socialists and Democrats, which stresses the importance of combating monopolies in fisheries. Although the internal allocation of quotas is an extension of the States, it is up to the European Union to make a positive commitment to artisanal fisheries such as those practised in regions such as the Azores and Madeira. If we continue to benefit the major initiatives, we will strangle jump and pole fishing, such as that in the outermost Atlantic regions.  I reiterate the need to respect scientific recommendations and use the precautionary principle without parsimony. Too many fish aggregation devices continue to be used in tuna fishing without serious environmental impact study.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I shall focus on just two points. The first concerns the issue of so-called delegated acts: the Commission proposes to transpose future amendments to the bluefin tuna recovery plan in the Eastern Atlantic and mediterranean by means of delegated acts, but if this were to happen, Parliament would no longer have any chance of having an impact in the ICAT. In my opinion, however, the transposition of the recommendations of regional fisheries management organisations must remain a joint competence of Parliament and the Council under the ordinary codecision procedure.  The second point concerns quotas for bluefin tuna fishing: it is not clear why the diversification of quotas for each vessel should only refer to the quantity caught in 2000, nor how this quota can in fact be to the exclusive benefit of some fishermen to the detriment of so many other operators, especially the small ones. The bluefin tuna quota mechanism must be freed from the monopoly of large shipowners, favouring more sustainable fishing systems and in favour of small and medium-sized enterprises. As the S&D Group, we have tabled an amendment calling on the Member States and ICAT to review the current system and I ask my fellow Members to support it.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, tuna fishing in the Mediterranean and atlantic is of particular importance as, among other things, it contributes to job creation in many countries, both within and outside the European Union. In 2006, ICAT established a multiannual framework ending in 2022, with the aim of restoring tuna in order to reconstitute tuna stocks in the Atlantic and Mediterranean. In Greece, fishermen have been badly damaged by the memorandum. As of today, they are escalating their fight against tax looting and anti-insurance resalto to their meager incomes, excluding the port of Volos and Nea Mechion in Thessaloniki. At their side are the fishermen of Paggaio, Crete, Fthiotida and are preparing a warm January against the Troika and the lenders. Greek fishermen will not accept the agricultural memorandum that is tearing their lives apart, their families, their businesses. They demand a fair reward for their labor, they demand reconstruction of the primary sector and they will fight together, on the basis of their righteous demands, for their own survival.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: I think we have a problem with the English interpretation, so if this can be resolved...  (Interjection from Mr Marias) We understood you perfectly, sir. I can assure you of that.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are delighted that thanks to the attention and measures of the European Union and ICAT, the precious bluefin tuna species is once again inhabiting our seas. A precious species in every sense because it is also commercially coveted and is, of course, also the subject of a monopoly in the Mediterranean Sea. This is the case, for example, in Sicily, where some large shipowners use the migratory flow to channel tuna into their nets, which are then marketed in Japan. The result is that the tuna that arrives on our tables is now yellowfin, coming from the Pacific, while our fishermen, the Sicilian ones, are forced to divest their boats. We need to protect small-scale fishing, traditional techniques, old tuna, all sustainable systems, which are disappearing; it is a heritage that must be protected, as much as the precious bluefin tuna.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, blue-tailed tuna is an endangered species and regardless of what we have positive examples of recovery, favourable data in recent years and what are now trying to increase quotas, ioak I would like to urge the Commission, you Mr. Commissioner, to be vigilant. After all, blue-tailed tuna is an endangered species and the way it is intended to use all that in the Mediterranean and the Atlantic today and in the future in such a way that great monopolists exploit tuna, I fear will put us in a troubled situation. That is why I invite you to consider a joint study of all stocks of key fish species in the Mediterranean and Atlantic, not just to talk about individual species, as this is the best approach to how to protect both blue-tailed tuna and other species.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, the multiannual bluefin tuna recovery plan has enabled the positive development of their stocks. The biomass of this species has been trending positive since 2008. In 2014, the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas therefore decided to increase the TAC by 20% for the 3 years following 2015 to 2017. For our part, we are following the criticism of a system of fishing quotas that penalises the most sustainable small-scale fishing for the benefit of the major shipowners of the main European fishing powers. It is important to recognize the role of handmade frames used in southern Portugal, in the Algarve, their potential and selectivity. It is also important to recognise that island fishermen who use the art of jumping and pole vaulting and who are now passing bluefin tuna without fishing, it is important that these sinners are given their right to fish for this species, especially now that the catch limits are adjusted to improve the resource, which, for example in the case of fishermen in the Azores , would only partially compensate for the damage resulting from sharp falls in the quotas of another species.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – The package of measures before us is, of course, a continuation of the multiannual framework for the fight to preserve bluefin tuna stocks, and it must be said, of course, that it is crucial that the legal rules should also be unified with the international obligations that the European Union has under numerous arrangements, and, above all, to protect, as I say, European fishermen. However, it is of course necessary to pay attention to what is to happen, it has also happened in this part, great monopolies of fishermen have occurred, and in this way the small and medium-sized fishermen who are most affected are the most affected, which are actually disappearing from this traditional one, even if I say the most ecological way of catching them. I think that each Member State, of course, has the possibility to split the quotas among fishermen, but here it is particularly important to report and control so that, by increasing quotas, we do not return to the dangerous waters of this fish.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, again I would like to thank all the honourable Members for their comments and questions which shows that we have found a clear and common ground in order to proceed further with this proposal. I also appreciate the fact that there is general support from the honourable Members of this Chamber. The Commission would also like to recall, as every one of you has done, the sensitive nature of bluefin tuna in international fora and the particular responsibility of the EU in doing our part in ensuring its sustainability. Having the largest share of the quota, we also carry the responsibility in that we have the largest number of operators and therefore the EU does have a central role to play in the management of this very important stock.  This proposal is essential in order to accurately transpose ICCAT decisions, measures adopted in ICCAT a few years ago, into Union law. The resulting regulation would ensure legal certainty regarding the obligations of the operators, all the operators, and as a result facilitate the implementation of the measures and the compliance of the Union with its international obligations. I would like to go through some of the comments that were made. Mr Mato, Ms Briano and Ms Bilbao Barandica, and almost everyone, have stressed the role of artisanal fisheries. Yes, it is true that the Commission largely shares the interest of Parliament in preserving ancient traditional fishing methods. We also believe that the drafting of the text as put forward in the draft report is not always appropriate and can be misleading.  Coming on to tuna traps, which were also mentioned: tuna traps are not the only sustainable gear for targeting bluefin tuna, or the only gear providing significant employment opportunities. This is not reflected in the proposed amendments to Mr Mato’s report .  As to whether the Commission agrees to include suggestions to allocate additional specific quota or to establish, or even break down, the quota allocation between gears: yes, I think that this should be reassessed in the light of the specificities of the fisheries in each Member State.  Individually, there were some comments with regards to the almadraba, which I mentioned goes along with the artisanal fishing, and that we need to go for the more environmentally friendly and the most sustainable methods.  With regard to the points mentioned by Marco Affronte who highlights the importance of this stock for European fishermen, I appreciate that this is the right way to move. We mentioned, a lot of us mentioned, the socio-economic aspects and I think that correct management is the only way forward to protect sustainability and the long-term sustainability of the socio-economic aspects.  I also agree with Ms Rodust who said that the quotas should be transparent and so on. I believe that this is something that all the Member States should aim for, along with the need for high selectivity, low-energy consumption and, again, small scale. This is the part that the small-scale artisanal fishing could play in all of this. I also agree with many of you who said that we should agree that things are not as good as we would like them to be, and that is why I said there is no space for complacency. Yes, we have made progress, but there is still a lot of progress to be made.  Ms Aguilera García mentioned the uniform and effective level playing field and more distribution towards the small fishermen. I took on board Mr van Dalen’s point about the conservation plan for hake, I think that is something that we can discuss.  With regard to the environmental impact assessment (EIA) on collective fishing gear mentioned by Mr Serrão Santos, that is something that scientists do take into account but if need be it should be more enhanced as well. With regard to the mention of the need for delegated acts, I think this is a crucial element of the proposal because there will be frequent, very frequent, amendments of the ICCAT recovery plan and these amendments will need to be put into European law swiftly. Going through the full ordinary legislative procedure will not allow us to act in time. However, these delegated acts will make it possible to act fast and transpose ICCAT measures relating to non-essential elements of the legislative acts into EU law. I think this was mentioned by Mr Caputo. With regard to accuracy and the positive data of recovery, we still need to be very cautious. I think Mr Jakovčić and others mentioned this. Mr Ferreira also spoke about better distribution. Renata Briano spoke about the stock and its socio-economic impact, and yes, the quotas are there to be distributed by the Member States in a more fair way. I think it is important that RFMOs are transparent and more representative. With regard to Mr Farage, unfortunately today we are discussing tuna, and sea bass is not under ICCAT. However, I would still like to point out that I agree with you that anglers are contributing highly to the economy of many of the European states. You mentioned 800 000 in the UK, there are some 1.3 million anglers in France and a high percentage of the sea bass is actually being caught by anglers. Since they are benefiting, I think they should also take on the responsibility. With regard to our proposals on sea bass not being debated, I do not agree with you. We have been discussing this and we have been urging all the Member States involved to come up with an agreed plan.  With regard to the contribution from Ms Hazekamp, I agree that even though we have made some improvement on recovery this species is still threatened and we do hope that ICCAT will continue to take this into consideration. Overall, I would like to thank all the Members of this Chamber for your contribution and I would like once again to thank the rapporteur Mr Mato, and this Chamber, for an open and a very productive discussion.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, thank you Commissioner and, above all, thank you to all the Members who have surgery and who in one way or another have helped to improve this report. And thanks also to those Members who have used the shift to disrespect the Commissioner, which I strongly reject, and who have used their time to talk about very different things. In any case, thank you because it's good to listen to everyone. There are two fundamental issues here: one is quotas. Firstly, we are talking about the fact that good work has indeed been done by fishermen and stocks have recovered. That requires an increase in quotas. I think so. And it is also true that the other important part is how this quota-sharing is done and that is done by the Member States. It is true that it is not a question of this Parliament, it is not in this report that it has to be, but it is a political option. It's a very clear message. We believe that a better allocation of quotas has to be done, benefiting small fishermen. I'm not going to demonize the big ones, but I do think we have to benefit and be fairer to the little fishermen.  That is why we clearly share that position and have already included it in a compromise in the text itself. An amendment is now being tabled that goes further, but deep down what is intended is simply that there should be a fairer allocation of quotas.  And then we have a problem, Commissioner. We will not understand each other, and we understand each other many times, on the subject of delegated acts. I believe that you, the Commission, are not an example of rapid transposition, and we have many examples, and I believe that this situation cannot be used as an argument or subterfuge to eliminate Parliament's powers. There they will find us in front of us, I say this clearly: we understand that the system to be applied has to be the ordinary procedure, there has to be codecision. We can put all the push for things to be done quickly, but under no circumstances are we going to give up our powers, and I think you have to understand that clearly. In that sense, I'm sure we'll understand each other.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 19 January 2016. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. – Firstly, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on his work and to welcome the Commission's proposal to include all measures on the bluefin tuna recovery plan in a new regulation. It is important that this regulation takes into account all links with the new CFP (Common Fisheries Policy), in particular as regards the possibility of derogation based on international commitments, but also the landing obligation. However, I would like to remind the Commission of the status of co-legislator and guarantor of the democratic control that the European Parliament has. Parliament must be involved in any decision to amend the plans to restore tuna in the Atlantic or Mediterranean, so we cannot accept the delegated acts proposed by the Commission. Any change must be made by codecision. In conclusion, I would like to stress the importance of promoting small-scale fishing. Member States should pay close attention to non-industrial fisheries because it is more sustainable and guarantees employment in coastal areas.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the debate on the Objection pursuant to Rule 106 on emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles (Euro 6) (2015/2988(RPS)).

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Vice-president of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. – Madam President, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI), I would like to present this Objection pursuant to Rule 106 on emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles, the Euro 6 standards. Air pollution causes over 430 000 premature deaths in the EU every year and costs up to an estimated EUR 940 billion a year as a result of its health impacts. In particular, nitrogen oxides (NOx) are major air pollutants which cause, inter alia, lung cancer, asthma and many respiratory diseases, as well as environmental degradation such as eutrophication and acidification.  According to the EEA, NOx emissions are the cause of at least 75 000 premature deaths in the European Union yearly. Diesel vehicle exhausts are a major source of NOx in urban areas in Europe, and the Euro 6 limit value for NOx emissions from diesel vehicles is 80 mg/km under so-called normal use conditions. The draft measure, the subject of the objection, aims to establish the so-called real driving emission requirements to limit the tailpipe emissions of light passenger and commercial vehicles. The motion for a resolution considers that the draft Commission regulation would result in a de facto blanket derogation from applicable emission limits, which is not compatible with the aim and content of Regulation 715/2007 and exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Regulation 396/2005. The ENVI Committee objects to the draft measure, in particular because it would allow vehicles to emit 168 mg/km of nitrogen oxide in the real driving emissions test, applicable to all new vehicles from September 2019, which means four years after the entry into force of the Euro 6 80mg/km limit value.  Surpassing the regulation by 110% is something that deeply undermines not only the regulation itself but also, I believe, the credibility of the regulating EU bodies. The resolution therefore calls on the Commission to withdraw the draft regulation and submit a new proposal by 1 April 2016 at the latest, introducing a real driving emissions test that would ensure the effectiveness of emission control systems.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, today we are discussing the introduction of the new emissions testing procedures for cars in the EU. As you know, we have been working on this issue for quite a long time, but of course the Volkswagen revelations gave action greater urgency. So I want to focus today’s debate on the impact of the decision that has been taken. We know that laboratory tests are not reliable. Currently, the real NOx emissions by diesel cars are, on average, 400 mg/km. That is 4-5 times higher than the legal emissions limit of Euro 6 cars. That is why we have prepared some substantial changes to the regulatory framework. Of course, it was demanding, but we have come up with a solution that is unique and fit for purpose. We will be the first in the world to introduce emissions tests on real roads under real driving conditions. Our solutions will change the current measurement systems completely. It will no longer be possible to cheat in emissions tests. Member States have reached a compromise. In the first stage emissions will be reduced to 168 mg/km by September next year and then, by January 2020, the limits will be reduced still further to 120 mg/km. You are well aware that the initial Commission proposals were significantly more ambitious. I said on many occasions that I wanted more stringent ‘conformity factors’, but we could not convince the Member States. Still – and I want to underline this – I consider this agreement substantial progress because we are halving the NOx emissions of diesel cars currently on the streets and, at the same time, we are forcing the automotive industry to speed up efforts to make cars cleaner and respect our common environmental goals. This is why we need the new rules as soon as possible, and this is why we need – and ask for – your agreement on the Commission’s proposals on introducing real driving emissions tests in the EU. But, as I have also told you, we will not stop here. The real driving emissions tests are only one part of the package. We want to bring down NOx emissions as much as possible. Ultimately, if technological development allows, we want the cars to achieve the legal limit of 80 mg/km. That is why the legal proposal on the real driving emissions test procedures suggests a so-called annual revision clause. This means that, from 2020 onwards, the emission limits can be adjusted if technology improves. Each year, the Commission will assess the portable measurements technology: this is the technology which actually measures the emissions under real driving conditions. If this technology improves and allows for more exact emission measurements from 2020, we will have the legal possibility to bring the limits down further, to 80 mg/km. We intend to start this work already by the end of this year. It is possible to do so within this time limit because manufacturers design their vehicles well in advance of their production, so the vehicles on the roads in five years’ time are being designed today. That is why the existence of the annual revision clause provides legal certainty and an incentive for car manufacturers to design their cars with much lower emissions than the current limit. Let me now come to the rest of the package. In the course of this year, the Commission will propose a third regulatory package on real driving emissions testing to increase transparency. The idea is that the conformity factor of each vehicle is shown in its certificate of conformity: the consumer will be fully aware of the emissions performance of his/her vehicle. Further, I promised to improve the type approval system and strengthen the independence of the control bodies. I will propose the text for the College discussion next week. The new rules will clarify and strengthen the recall system and safeguard procedures. The Commission will be given the powers to intervene and comment on the corrective measures taken by the Member States. The system of exchange of information and cooperation between enforcement authorities in the Member States will be reinforced. The Volkswagen case also showed that Member States do not react in a very coordinated manner, so I intend to force Member States to carry out market surveillance and controls of vehicles brought to the market. The quality and independence of the services responsible for approving vehicles will be strengthened. This means more quality checks, better cooperation and more and stronger tools to enforce the rules. We need to restore the confidence of our citizens in the type approval system and the car industry as a whole, as we have all agreed a few times before. This is why we urgently need new rules on type approval and emissions testing to be in place. Last, but not least, a few words about Euro 5/6 proposals: the Parliament and Council are currently negotiating some revisions of the Euro 5 and Euro 6 legislation, which is also the parent legislation to the act on introducing real driving emissions. In this context, the delegated powers to be given to the Commission are being discussed. Our objective is to have a very smooth and rapid implementation of the new real driving emissions procedure in the future. We are ready to work together with you, and of course with the Council, to find a balanced solution because we want to achieve our environmental objectives and we are determined to respect the institutional balance. I know this is also important to you. I hope that my commitment is very clear to you. I want to tackle it in a very coherent and comprehensive way. I will be demanding and decisive towards our car manufacturers if they do not play the game. I am confident that this new framework will restore the effectiveness of our legal system to protect both consumers and the environment.

name: Ivo BELET
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – What is at stake here? We all know that. We want harmful nitrogen oxide emissions to be reduced effectively and as quickly as possible. Today - and the Commissioner has just confirmed it - a Euro 6 diesel car emits on average 4 times more nitrogen than the legal standard we adopted a few years ago and which has been in force since last year. So those emissions have to go down. We all agree on that. Secondly, the new test, the Real Driving Emission Test, which determines how many cars emit in real driving conditions, must now finally be introduced. There is an agreement on this, which is essential. We've wasted enough time. That test must now be introduced.  We welcome, of course, Commissioner, that you here are committed to coming up with a legislative proposal in the short term on additional supervision of national type-approval, on this homologation. It is essential that national control can be independently and robustly verified. I also refer to the discussion on delegated acts and implementing acts.  Parliament wants to be directly involved in future revisions. We explicitly ask that this be done through delegated acts and not through implementing acts.  And finally, smart car manufacturers are obviously not waiting to respond. They are taking flight ahead and they are starting to adapt their cars today using the smartest technology in the interests of the public health of everyone in Europe. (The speaker is prepared to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules)).

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. – I myself, as a member of the Committee on the Environment, am in favour of tightening up and complying with the rules, but would I like you to help me decide whether the rules were too strict or whether the industry was delaying compliance?

name: Ivo BELET
text: "blue card" answer. I do not know if that is very relevant here. The most important thing is that we draw conclusions as quickly as possible today from the past situation and from the scandals that have occurred. What is important is, first of all, that the nitrogen oxide goes down as quickly as possible. We have a commission of inquiry to find out what went wrong. One of the conclusions will undoubtedly be that the control of type-approval should be tightened up, that there should be an independent robust check on type-approval. We need to focus on what went wrong. This will become apparent during the work of the Committee of Inquiry. We must now focus on how to get the nitrogen oxide down in the interests of the public health of all of us and the sooner the better. (The speaker is prepared to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules)).

name: Bart STAES
text: "blue card" question. Mr Belet, what will your group's attitude be when we have to vote on this objection in two weeks' time? Will your group choose the public interest? Will your group opt for public health? Will your group choose a real approach to the problem and ask the Commission to come up with a real proposal? If you do not choose, you will choose to increase the existing standard of 2007 from 80 to 168 mg per kilometre and to 120 mg from 2021. What will your group do?

name: Ivo BELET
text: "blue card" answer. – Thank you, Mr Staes for this question. What our group will do, of course, is to opt for public health. You have heard the Commissioner: today the average diesel car, a new Euro 6 diesel car, emits four times more than the legal standard we adopted years ago.  What we are aiming for is that in a year and a half and then two and a half years later we will go to a substantial reduction, first halving the situation as it is today and then two years later towards a further reduction in nitrogen oxide. We need to look at the emissions of nitrogen oxide today in actual driving conditions and then what the decision is as it is before. This means that there must be at least a halving in the short term and that we will then phase out the following years. That is the path we are going to choose.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Following on from previous speakers, I do not need to argue why it is important that we finally get the Real Driving Emission Testing. But I want to be very clear, Commissioner. Our group voted in favour of a postponement and ensured that you have time - not much time - to come up with a better proposal than what you have presented today. You have said good things, I do not doubt your good intentions, but there must be a more ambitious proposal.  What is unacceptable is that some technical committee is taking a decision that lowers the Euro 6 standard, which we all agreed here with the Commission ten years ago. We want you to think carefully and come up with a better proposal. In particular, achieving the conformity factor of 1 is extremely important because then we respect the standards that we have democratically agreed. So you have a little time. I suggest you come up with ambitious proposals.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I think we are all agreed that what we want is better air quality. We want an end to one-off laboratory tested type approval and we want to bring real-world driving emissions testing in as soon as possible. Of course there are many technical details to be agreed, but the fundamental agreement is on the table from the 28 October TCMV meeting. That agreement represents a real change. By 2020 we will have a guaranteed conformity factor of 1.5. When you consider that some vehicles coming on stream now are probably emitting up to five or six times the 80 mg limit, how can you turn down the opportunity to limit that to 120 mg? People in Europe with respiratory problems caused by pollution deserve that. I know we all want a conformity factor of 1 – of course we do, and I would like to see a commitment from both the Commission and the Member States that this will be reached by a specific date. Supporting this objection will not get us that. It will merely create a delay that could stretch into months or even years. That is a delay in health improvement for tens of thousands of Europeans. So let us use this opportunity to get round the table and agree when we are going to get to that conformity factor of 1, get the Member States to agree to it too, rise above the interinstitutional stand-off and achieve results for our citizens.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Thank you, Commissioner, for your contribution. First of all, I would like to stress - because we must not lose sight of this - how strongly this issue is being felt by the People of Europe. People want clean air and people are really tired of being fooled by the car industry.  Secondly, this is the Commission which has better legislation as a top priority. If this decision is an example of something, then it is not of better legislation. The current decision is not based on any impact assessment and none of the Member States dare to be politically accountable for this decision. I think it is telling that the Council is again completely absent. The Member States point to Brussels as the responsibility for this decision, but it is the Member States that we have to blame for the fact that clean air does not become a reality for our citizens for the time being.  Third, I'll get back to that clean air. It's a fundamental right for people to have clean air. But I would like to ask the Commissioner how the drivers of our European cities can generate clean air for their citizens if dirty cars can continue to drive around the cities in this way. How, Commissioner, is that possible? A city like London had already exceeded the limit of nitrogen oxide for the rest of the year on 7 January. On January 7th, past the limit for the whole of 2016! How can a city like London ever use these kinds of decisions to give its citizens clean air?  And finally, in the Netherlands in the year 2015 a word of the year was chosen: "cheating software". That was the word that was coined to name the practices of the car industry. With the way in which the Member States in particular think they can do politics, we will get an even worse word next year. And that word will be "sleading politics."

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, around half of EU citizens live in cities where transport is the biggest factor affecting air quality. Poor air quality in the European Union causes more than 430 000 premature deaths every year and an estimated EUR 940 billion a year in health costs. When we talk about air pollution, we are talking about a really significant problem. How, then, can it be that emissions of nitrogen oxides from transport cannot be controlled? When the emission limit laid down in the Regulation is 80 mg per kilometre, it shall be 80 milligrams per kilometre and not first 168 and subsequently 120 milligrams. Such exceeding binding emission limits far exceeds the implementing powers provided for in the Regulation, and it is imperative that this proposal for a regulation be withdrawn.  I do not think I hallucination when I say that during these years emissions could have been controlled and emissions measurements and type approvals would have been reliable. In the EU Member States too, one could imagine that there are more sensible destinations to spend than to pay billions for the health effects of poor air quality. I am still waiting for a new, more ambitious proposal for a regulation that will safeguard people's lives and health.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for explaining the proposal once more. I am a bit disappointed by that, Commissioner, because I expected to hear what potential change you can see in the proposal and what I get from your speech is that no change is possible any more.  What was agreed by the Member States, who indeed are not present here, is that all vehicles can emit up to 168 mg/km until 2019 – you mentioned only the date for new models, but if we discuss all vehicles then it is 2019. You know that very well. You are also aware of the 1.5 conformity factor, which means changing our standard from 80 to 120 and that only starting in 2021, although already in 2007 we as co-legislators decided that it should go to 80 in 2014. That is what we did in co-legislation.  What they are doing now in a technical meeting is to say that this value can move to 120 until 2021. Even if you are on the side of the car industry, you cannot accept that a technical committee is adjusting what we decided as co-legislators.  It is important to realise that already we can improve much more. Today in the Flemish news, Mr Belet, it was mentioned that Opel, for one car and with a simple software correction, went down from 750 to 200 in just one day, and you are agreeing now that they have time until 2021 to water down a proposal that was decided in 2007. That is what you are going to agree upon.  Commissioner, the Social Democrats asked a very clear question: will there be a new proposal on the conformity factors – yes or no? We demand a clear answer tonight.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Italian delegation of the 5-Star Movement will also support the objection because we are faced with a deception, because we are being offered the RDE package as a great step forward, as a very ambitious and unique measure in the world. It is a pity that, in fact, how ambitious can a package be ambitious and a great step forward that will still allow vehicles to pollute much more than the permitted limits? And one thing we must remember: companies, the automotive sector, have had seven long years to be able to prepare themselves, to comply and to respect the limits in real driving conditions. Unfortunately, this has not been done and we cannot afford to go any further. The Commission must propose an appropriate, serious measure as soon as possible and to protect people's health.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this is a very unpleasant dilemma to deal with. On the one hand, the European Commission has a good idea: to relax the emission requirements for light vehicles. Whether volkswagen case or not, we must admit that the constraints on the European automotive sector are enormous, and, in a context of international competition, unlimited opening of trade borders, industrial collapse and soaring unemployment, let us admit that the Commission is, for once, defending our interests.  On the other hand, the Commission is acting in its favourite way: bypassing Parliament. It is true that our institutions must be based on trust, transparency and accountability, and this Parliament should have been able to shoulder its bureaucratic excesses.  But the time is serious, the economic war has indeed begun, we must act, which is why we will oppose this objection.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. It is true that, according to the European Commission, 400 000 people die prematurely every year because the air is polluted. In many municipalities, towns and cities, those responsible have difficulty in complying with the EU's aviation pollution standards. That is why the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats has always advocated the elimination and reduction of pollutants at source. Of course, this also includes the cars. That is why we want a solution to real drive emissions.  It cannot be the case that the test values in practice have virtually nothing to do with those in the laboratory and that additional problems arise as a result. But the question of what follows from this general statement is not so easy to answer. A majority in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Social Affairs said that the proposal is not strict enough , which is why we reject it. In my personal opinion, there are also reasons for this, particularly because the GROWTH Directorate-General GROW originally proposed stricter values – 1.6 and 1.2. But we can only say yes or no.  I know from many discussions, including from committed environmental politicians from the Council of Ministers, that if we reject the proposal, we will automatically get a stricter one, but we may not have any result at all.  That is why the GROUP of European Democrats is in favour of a compromise that helps people, health and local authorities, but which also gives us a certain degree of planning certainty. An important part of this compromise should be that we have stricter controls on type-approval and also on vehicles already on the road. I hope that we will be able to agree on this in the next two weeks.

name: Matthias GROOTE
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The cities in Germany – in the Member State from which I come – have massive problems in complying with air quality limits. What am I supposed to say to the mayors in the German City Council, with this proposal as it is before us here? We have here deteriorating factors that undermine legislation, actually bringing it back from Euro 6 to Euro 5. That is why we are asking ourselves, if there can be a compromise at all, for which I am working and which I also want: when does it stop with conformity factors, with deterioration factors? What can I answer to the mayors? Should it take 20 years, from the 2007 to 2027 legislation, or what end date did you actually imagine, Mrs Bie-kowska?  Do you also see that the Commission may also run the risk of being sued if it is complied with air quality limits, as it does with endocrine disruptors? Do you see the danger that something might roll over you, or are you calm about that? As far as the Council is concerned, if the issue is so important here, if we take the trouble to discuss it here, I must honestly say that the Council is not here, it is outrageous!

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Reducing nitrogen oxides is certainly an objective that united us all, and all the speakers here have said this today. Nevertheless, we have also heard a great deal of automotive industry bashing today. It is not the fault of the car industry that the rules are as they are at the moment, namely that we end up getting type-approval in the laboratory, even though cars are very rarely driving around in laboratories. It is not a fraud on the part of the car industry, as many speakers have said here, but it is simply the inability of politicians to provide and demand realistic tests for the car industry. If we can agree on this in the future, then I believe that we have indeed achieved something. However, as Mr Belet rightly said, he spoke of the intelligent car industry, and hardly anyone has spoken about the intelligent European Commission here.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: Madam President, and the most beloved Commission, i.e. the European Parliament, i.e. the European Parliament, i I was going to start this time by asking a simple and fundamental question, which everyone can think about. What is the point of a democratic legislative process if it is undermined by people who are actually civil servants? Is it not precisely the undermining of the basic democratic principles that has now led the Commission to call Poland and we call the Commission? The Commission's so-called old solutions to allow emissions to run far beyond borders have now come to a logical end. Indeed, one could imagine that Volkswagen would never have been lured into the salacious path of fraud if the EU had had a Commission that had defended the legislator's intentions a little more upright. In this particular sense, the Commission bears enormous responsibility, from which it is now trying to meander by declaring that this is delaying all programmes. Thank you very much, but not for your work.

name: Karima DELLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the decision taken last October is outrageous. In secret, the Heads of State and the Commission granted permits to pollute car manufacturers. They will now be able to exceed pollution standards by 110% until 2020 and by 50% thereafter. It is outrageous and now Parliament says it is illegal. In other words, it is a total violation not only of European legislation, but also of the European Parliament, which is the co-legislator of pollution standards to protect the health of citizens and serve the public interest. We are not in the service of the car lobby! Rather than be complicit in the lies of the car industry, it is time for Parliament, the Member States and the Commission to choose the side of consumers, citizens and the planet. The outrageous decision is due to be rejected as early as next month. I call on states and the Commission to do the same and finally look at the implementation of genuine independent probate controls and real real tests under real conditions, and this as soon as possible.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the scandal that rocked the German car industry last September has revealed worrying imbalances between pollutant emission standards and industrial reality.  I share the concern of the drafters of this motion for a resolution about the cost of pollution on public health and the inadequacy of the standards in force. This text proposes, however, an additional twist to an industry already struggling, by postulating this dogma: the race for pollution-free growth is at hand, with the good advice of political ecology. A dogma that has done its time!  Let us reaffirm that this scandal has been to the benefit of American industry and to the detriment of European industry. Let us also reaffirm that the reduction of polluting emissions will be achieved with the reduction of international flows, the relocation of the economy, a certain form of "de-demonization" that no one - starting with the political environmentalists - wants to mention here.  On the whole, the Commission's text is a lesser evil, for the best is the enemy of the good.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: Madam President, we all recognise that the automotive sector must make serious efforts to limit emissions of polluting gases into the atmosphere and, among other things, NOx emissions. The tests that have been done so far in the laboratory really lacked transparency and honesty, this is not acceptable, because our citizens must know the truth about the quality of the air they breathe. This is why the introduction of real-world driving tests, mandatory for all car manufacturers, is a major step forward.  But as far as I am concerned, I will object to that objection. A vote in favour of the objection to the Act adopted by the Commission would significantly delay the implementation of these tests, which are both better, much more reliable than the previous ones and which do not yet exist anywhere else. It would therefore be irresponsible, both for the environment and for the automotive sector, to postpone the implementation of these tests to the Greek calendars. We want to strike a balance between protecting the health of our citizens and preserving the future of the European car industry. The adoption of the objection would then be the absence of an immediate solution and the status quo, while the rejection of the objection will be the beginning of the solution. In four years' time, there will be a compliance review, which will allow us to be even more demanding in terms of reducing emissions from the automotive sector, but this will only have to be done by accompanying this sector in this transition and ensuring that values are strictly respected. It is a question of trust that must be restored among our fellow citizens and the future of our automotive industry, which is an important pillar of our economy. We expect the Commission to adopt strong measures in this regard, in order to better monitor the implementation of these tests, and to make them more independent.

name: Michael CRAMER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We have known for years that it is being cheated, that it is being lied about, and that it is being cheated. That is what we have said to the Commission, and we have told the Member States. Nothing happened! And it wasn't a question of technology, the technology exists. It was a question of money to be saved. Especially in the case of diesel vehicles, which are heavily subsidised in many countries. Nevertheless, it has happened. In Germany, a litre of diesel is 18 cents less than gasoline, and diesel cost 1.49 euros in 2012, now less than 90 cents. That can be changed! When, if not now? You have to go in that direction! The honest must not be the stupid one! Not everyone has cheated, lied and cheated. They were also those who have complied with our laws, but they must not be punished. Those who have cheated, lied and cheated must be punished. Therefore, we must not exceed the limit values that we have agreed on by common accord, and the Commission's proposal must be rejected!

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, I would like to make it clear that no one is questioning the reduction of nitrogen oxides. On the contrary, we all agree on this, we must achieve this and we must achieve this in a goal-oriented manner. However, Mr Cramer, today is not about compensation for affected citizens, although this is, of course, another important issue. Today, the question is whether we reject the implementing act proposed by the Commission or whether we accept it. I believe that we must now also be realistic about rejecting it, as you recommend, then it is not certain that the environment will be better off and that we will achieve more, because there is a risk that the next piece of legislation will come much later. That is why you should explain why you want to take the risk, and not why we believe that it is an admittedly unsatisfactory step, but the best step we can take now. I would therefore ask you to reconsider whether you can take part in this.  I understand that this is not, of course, an easy step, and I understand the principle that you have mentioned. We don't want the honest to be the stupid one. We, too, want what is written on it to be in it. There is indeed a whole range of improvements that we need to get there. Unfortunately, however, not only in the registration process for cars, but also in other areas, it will be a matter of adapting market supervision to modern conditions, of the Member States working better together and of ensuring that, not only in the case of cars, that what is on it is also in the end. The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats wants to fight for this, and there is much to be done about this, not only in the area of car registration. I believe that the Commission, Commissioner, is working successfully to find a solution whereby, if we adopt the implementing act now, we will create opportunities in other areas to achieve objectives that unite us all. I would therefore ask all Members to adopt this implementing act.

name: Seb DANCE
text: – Madam President, the committee whose decision we are here discussing took that decision on the same day that we as a Parliament took a very clear decision for ambitious targets with national emissions. This was sold to us as a technical change when in fact that change was political. Dirty air kills. We are only now coming to know the full extent of how much dirty air is killing our citizens. We have known since 2006, but there has been a discrepancy between laboratory tests and real world emissions. Indeed, the Commission itself acknowledged this in 2011. We cannot have a situation where, nearly a decade after initial reports, we have to choose between the delay of badly needed real world driving emissions tests and between the standards that have already been decided between this Parliament and the Commission. Commissioner, we cannot have any last-minute decisions made behind closed doors. We must come out of this process with a fair and consistent pathway to cleaner air, with the agreement, and the accountability, of this Parliament.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: This evening, we must not ignore the fact that 2015 has been a bad year for the European car industry. Consumers and governments have a right to honest information and clean air. The central question for me tonight is: how do we solve this in the coming years? My colleagues Belet and Liese have already outlined the EPP approach. We are going for a tight timetable on RDE emissions.  The second is: supervision of national test institutions and type-approval. Can the Commissioner give a clear timetable tonight of what she is going to do, with concrete steps? After all, I can well imagine that colleagues on that side have lost patience. But we also have to be realistic. There is an employment perspective that can easily be crossed, but we should not do so. There is new inspiration from COP 21. And there is even a relationship with TTIP, because it has been discovered in the US and not in Europe.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Commissioner, I think the ball is up to you, it has to be said. The Commission, as the executive, is responsible for ensuring that, in the end , this problem – and this is demonstrably a problem – is now being resolved justly. I think it is undeniable that what came from the technical body, from the expert panel and what you presented was unacceptable. We do not need to debate this. I have two specific questions for you, Mrs Bie-kowska. I would like to know from you: will you include the principle of real driving emissions in your revision of type-approval, which you intend to present at the end of this month – yes or no? My second question is this: why has your House, your institution, namely the European Commission, for years ignored the advice of the national testing centres on this issue? In fact, there is a need for clarification here.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the debate we are conducting in this House sees us all united in a direction that has been the direction we have been working on for a long time, which is to improve air quality. And I believe that there is no doubt about that, that over the decades air quality in Europe has improved enormously, not badly! We must continue along this path because it is not enough? I'm sure so! However, we must combine ecology with the economy, as an interesting columnist said in an Italian newspaper a few days ago, because ecology, on the other hand, which seems to sell health to citizens, actually also harms the health of citizens, because if we followed the reasoning of those who today claim to be the best friend of the environment, the best champion of air quality, we would find ourselves with a huge contradiction. We should vote in favour of this objection and we would therefore have a delay of a couple of years, the negotiations would be reopened and we would not have that improvement in air quality that, by voting yes, we would have immediately applied, immediately applied. Because we are talking here today about voting for a further significant reduction in particulate matter and NOx, nitrogen oxides, two of the most terrible, terrible causes of disease and deaths. So let us face it, honestly and clearly, and vote yes to this, so no to vote yes and then we hope to do better quickly, especially we help the industry to find even stronger and more successful technologies.

name: Massimo PAOLUCCI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, through you I would like to express to the Council our regret and protest at their unjustified absence from this important debate. We need more respect from the Council for Parliament's work.  It is now clear that the measurements made in the laboratory on nitrogen oxide emissions from diesel cars are on average three, four times lower than the actual ones on the road. In order to reduce carbon dioxide emissions, we cannot turn a blind eye to air pollution. For years, the public has been lied to: then the incredible Volkswagen scandal. So road trials are finally welcome, and we have been asking for them for years. None of us wants to strangle the car industry, but we need seriousness. In 2007, the European Union had a limit of 80 milligrams per kilometre; how can we accept that this limit, in 2021, after 15 years, should be increased to 120? No, it's not true that you can't do more. The state of health of our cities needs more courageous action. We're not going to put our heads in the sand.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we all want higher air quality and a better environment, of course, but to reject this regulation is precisely to go against these principles. If this Regulation is rejected, we will waste valuable time to improve the air quality of our cities by preventing the Commission from improving measurement parameters each year.  What we have on the table today are the Euro 5 and Euro 6 standards for homologating the emissions of vehicles under laboratory conditions. But, under real-world conditions, these emissions multiply around 4. Therefore, we are talking about a conformity factor of 4 or so, and what is proposed to us today, and is intended to reject, is a conformity factor of 2.1 in 2017 and 1.5 in 2020. This is the best of the solutions we have right now and we can't turn it down.  The reality is that emissions cannot be measured today under real conditions with greater reliability. Hopefully we don't need new parameters or conformity factors to approve vehicles under real-world conditions! Hopefully technologies would allow us to measure emissions with a hundred percent prediction! But the reality is not that. Therefore, rejecting this regulation would be to delay all two or three years at best, and we are kind of doing to the defence of the environment with these arguments which are probably only intended to condition the conclusions of a committee of inquiry which has not yet begun to function.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: Madam President, doing what we have said and saying what we are doing is a simple code of conduct to maintain the confidence of those we represent. One month after COP 21 and its ambitious objectives, how can we accept the Commission's enforcement act, which falls below the Euro 6 standard on the grounds that it would be too difficult to achieve. Automotive manufacturers are in the news today, because their emissions of pollutants are significantly higher in real-world conditions than in the laboratory, while for the past four years they have been constantly bragging about ever cleaner cars. Customers and simply people in contact with vehicles no longer want to have to suffer such levels of pollution. And we don't live in the lab! So the recognition of tests in real conditions to seriously estimate the pollution rate of a vehicle is fine, but above all do not decrease the level of requirement. Has the maximum speed increase been decided to combat the deaths behind the wheel for speeding? No, it's not. The French Minister of the Environment has committed, in the wake of the decision of the Technical Committee for Motor Vehicles (CTVM), to review this act of implementation at the political level by the relevant ministers in the Council. This would give Member States the opportunity to reach a better compromise that can ensure compliance with European standards. By agreeing to postpone our vote in February, we are giving you an opportunity to demonstrate that you too can do what you say.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in this debate we must ask ourselves the following question: does the objection raised take us forward or delay plans to reduce emissions in Europe? It is good, I believe, that the Commission has committed itself to returning to this House with a clearer, more evaluable package of measures. And it's good because, if commitment becomes a reality, we'll have the guarantees to achieve the ultimate goal we all share: to reduce nitrogen oxide emissions in a real way. And, in this regard, we must maintain a vigilant attitude towards the revision clauses already envisaged. We must be demanding with industry, but without forgetting that the letter of the law cannot go far ahead of technology, because in that case, in the end, the result is never success, but failure. And failure is counted in health and in jobs. In Catalan, we want for New Year's "salut i faina", health and work. We all want a clean Europe, but it wouldn't do us any good to want a Europe, so be it a jobless Europe. From realism we must build a Europe that is a global benchmark in green growth and that is competitive in creating high-value-added jobs. A Europe that, in turn, complies with the agreements we reached a few weeks ago in Paris. This is the Europe we want. And we will be too late for this Europe, we will be wrong if the objection to this debate is adopted. And because we do not want that Europe that we all want to be late and wrong, we are against the objection.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Madam President! I fully agree that we should of course have tests that show what cars actually emit when they are driving on European roads. We know that the tests in the laboratories are not comprehensive. However, it is completely unacceptable that this change in the tests should be used to allow higher levels of emissions of NOx particles. The proposal is also directly counterproductive to the fact that we are currently in the process of legislation, air package legislation, which also aims to reduce air pollution in the European Union. We are all doing this because we know that hundreds of thousands of EU citizens die prematurely every year because we have problems with air pollution. We are protesting against the proposal because it leads precisely to more air pollution, not less. Commissioner, it can and must be done better! Come on, come up with a proposal that provides an effective testing system without loopholes and without compromising the health of citizens.

name: Herbert REUL
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. This is a rather adventurous debate that we are having here. We agreed on limit values, and everyone knew that they would be measured in trial mode, but not in the real way of driving. And then there was this VW scandal, and the Commission had been constantly working to find a new procedure, a test procedure that is better, which measures in real driving. And then the Commission acted so quickly that it immediately agreed a proposal with the Member States. So: reacted very quickly and put a more realistic measurement method on the table. In fact, the Commission should be commended for this. Instead, we just insult them. That is simply completely beside reality, I can only say. We now get a procedure in real test mode. Everyone wanted that, everyone said that a hundred times. We are getting this into values that are now technologically feasible and reasonable, and we are doing so quickly. Those who are actually responsible for making health worse for the citizens of Europe in the future are those who decide this objection here. Let us be clear: the person who rejects this proposal from the Commission and the Council is responsible if we have poorer values on our roads for years. That is the clear facts. Those who are taking part, who are now making sure that a quick solution is found, are improving the quality – not, of course, as you might dream of – but it is getting better.
