And then it goes step by step. The Commission has just indicated that this can be further developed. So people: Choose between practical deeds and concrete help and dream dancing.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: I would also like to contribute to a solution, but I wonder whether the European Commission and the Council can at all demonstrate that this enormous conformity factor of 50% and even 110% overrun is also legally feasible. It also means delay. Professional legal advisers and our own lawyers have pointed out to us that this is inadmissible and legally unfeasible. Is a 30% conformity factor not wiser? This would correspond to the maximum deviation of the new portable emission measurement systems (the PEMS). It is therefore practically feasible and in line with the original Commission proposal, which I have always defended.  This can be done with catalytic converters that are affordable, and in the United States the European car companies are already consulting on the installation of additional catalytic converters as a solution to the environmental conflicts. Matthias Müller of Volkswagen speaks to the EPA. So what are we talking about? Why, according to industry and the Commission, this cannot be done here in Europe? I hear from the top industry in Europe that they want to set an example and be sustainable. Let's try to find a solution here together. I cannot therefore support this proposal.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, Volkswagen's reports of fraudulent emissions have put the automotive sector in a complex situation. Europe has a world leadership position and my country, Spain, is the ninth car producer in the world and two million jobs depend on this sector.  As public leaders, all of this forces us to take measured measures that move in the direction of enhancing global industry leadership, protecting workers, providing guarantees to consumers on the vehicles they buy and being effective in controlling emissions and in their gradual reduction to protect the environment.  I believe that the entry into force of tests under real conditions of movement is not only a legal obligation, but a citizen emergency, and I appeal to the Commission to reconcile this urgency with the need to reduce emissions of polluting gases.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I also greatly appreciate the uniform direction that has emerged from the debate that has taken place here. I miss the Council a little bit in my position, because I think it is disrespectful to the European Parliament if it is not here on such an important issue. However, I think that the basic error occurred when unrealistic tests from laboratory conditions were put into operation or should have been applied to operation. I think that was a fundamental failure. On the contrary, I appreciate the Commission's approach, which has also been expressed here today. I think that approving an objection that we should approve under the petitioners' proposal would have the opposite effect to what they want. That is, I oppose the object that has been tabled here. I, too, of course, value the quality of health, consumer protection, air protection, but it cannot go this way against the interests of sustainable development.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, of course, the first observation I make is on the absence of the Council. I do not think we should have different interests, and we should all be present on this subject: the Council, and the Commission, and we.  I think all colleagues are right; we want to improve air quality, life takes precedence; there must be an ongoing journey, this improvement in air quality and not only in the field of cars, but multisectoral.  Personally, I am very reserved, because if we were to reject now what, behold, for the first time the Commission is introducing, a test system that is carried out to match the emissions to the exhaust pipe during circulation, would mean prolonging it very much. Sometimes, when you want to get too much, you lose. I do not know whether, for citizens, delaying the measurement by years and introducing the test system to measure emissions on the exhaust pipe of vehicles in service would be a solution.  That is why I am very reserved, and I think we need to think very carefully when we vote on this proposal for a regulation. Obviously, the Commission must continue with the improvement of the parameters.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: – Lucky we have good investigative journalism from time to time! Today it came to light that Opel may also be cheating and that they are working to secretly modify polluting models through a so-called upgrade. It has come a long time that a journalist from the Flemish broadcaster has to do the work of official inspection bodies. Trust and transparency are completely lost. It is time for the consumer to be taken seriously. And, frankly, if, as a consumer, I have to choose between a car with a little more power or a year longer life, if I have to choose between a car with more fins or the health of my children, then I know what I choose. I choose health and car manufacturers should not make that choice in people's place.  Ladies and gentlemen, we are the parliament. We owe it to the citizens to ask for more ambition, to demand more ambition and to show more ambition.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Vice-president of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. – Madam President, from this debate this evening, I conclude that we more or less agree from a professional point of view that the conformity factor proposed by the Commission is not realistic. It is a joke. Even the Commission regards it as insufficient to reach our goals. There was a lot of talk about the delay, but let us be frank. The Regulation will come into force in 2019, so I think we have the time to improve this Regulation and to spend some more time getting a better regulation which protects the environment and European citizens. I do not consider this approach of ‘take it or leave it as a proposal’, which is the approach taken by the Commission to Parliament, to be consistent with the democratic decision-making process. I would like to ask you to support this objection and to make the Commission and the Council come back to the table to improve the Regulation. Please, instead of being realistic, be brave in protecting European citizens.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Members very much for their views and opinions again. I fully respect and understand all of their concerns. Let me come back to the most important questions.  First, let me underline again that the Commission did not ignore any signals before: neither in 2006 when we worked on a proposal for Euro 5/6 in order to bring emissions down – although this was for laboratory testing, and that has to be stressed – nor in 2011 and 2012 when it was the JRC, not anybody else, who indicated for the first time that there is a problem with the real driving emissions.  We now have to finish this process with a positive vote. We cannot make any new proposals on conformity factors, firstly because Member States will not change their views, and secondly because it would extremely delay the whole process. To make things very clear: if we do not have rules in place by 2017, we will maintain this situation with 4-5 times higher emissions in real driving – in real life – and have 4-5 times more pollution. Rejection implies that we will not have rules in 2017, and we will have to explain to our citizens why we now have 500 mg/km of NOx emissions and have not done anything to reduce it to 168 mg/km.  I feel, of course, that a consensus can emerge. Let me outline a possible way forward without new proposals on conformity factors: the Commission is ready to make a declaration for the plenary vote next month, outlining the solution that we discussed today, so I can honestly commit to activating the annual revision clause for the second conformity factor as soon as possible next year. This is more or less the same as reducing the second conformity factor. You can take this as my personal commitment too, and the second one is that we will adopt the reinforced type approval system on real driving emissions. I can commit to these two things before you now without making new proposals for conformity factors. I hope that this will allow you – or at least some of you – to cast a positive vote on the proposals on real driving emissions in the next 2 or 3 weeks’ time.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: I have received one motion for a resolution at the end of the debate. The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the first part-session in February.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: – Madam President, we have just listened to the Commissioner with a few commitments about the future. Yet the decision taken on RDE is a Commission and Council decision, so without any commitments from the Council the commitments from the Commission are not very valuable. Can you please send a message to the Council and ask them for a reply to the commitments from the Commission so that we get a written answer from the Council, which is not present here tonight?

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: Mr Gerbrandy, this was not a point of order;  Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: in writing. – The agreement by governments, including the UK, to weaken diesel pollution limits was both legally and morally unjustifiable. This was a political decision with huge implications for public health, so it should been debated publicly and not stitched up behind closed doors. MEPs must veto this shameful stitch-up and demand stricter pollution limits. Accepting weaker limits would mean stifling the transition to cleaner cars and prolonging deadly air pollution in our cities.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: in writing. – Many European countries are currently facing serious air quality problems, particularly in urban centres where there is greater population and traffic density. The European Commission has worked for several years to develop a more reliable process of measuring nitric oxide emissions to reflect those carried out under real driving conditions. This process was based on an appropriate technical and scientific analysis, which is now called into question under the political pressure of member states and industry. This proposal for a delegated act is shameful because it is not based on objective technical criteria and because it has been taken without any transparency, subverting the democratically adopted policy objectives in the basic legislative document. It is particularly ashamed in the wake of the Volkswagen scandal by giving companies that do not comply with, or falsify European emissions standards, a competitive advantage over those that are already complying today. I express my support for the position taken by the ENVI Commission – I consider that this to be the public interest; So I take over your defense!

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – If there are powerful lobbied with the EU institutions, and particularly with the one that holds the power of the legislative initiative – the European Commission – influencing legislative proposals and leaving their indelible mark on them, one of these lobbiies is that of the automotive industry. Developments around the Volkswagen scandal over vehicle emissions manipulation only confirm this fact. A European Commission technical committee proposes authorising Euro 6 diesel cars to issue more than twice the limits previously set between 2017 and 2019, allowing for a 110% discrepancy between laboratory tests (which the industry handles more or less in general issuing) and testing in real-world conditions. From 2020, this discrepancy could be up to 50%, i.e. emissions 50% above the previously set limits. All this without any scientific support.  This is how the European Commission's proclaimed ambition in environmental matters is at the door step of the vast interests of multinationals in the automotive sector. It is essential that measurements in real conditions move forward as soon as possible. But it is essential that they move in a way that ensures adequate protection of the environment and public health, and not the protection of the interests of multinationals, against populations and the environment.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –It is not necessary to have much knowledge of physico-chemistry in order to be able to deduce that excessive energy efficiency of diesel engines in order to significantly reduce CO2 emissions is accompanied by an increase in the fuel combustion temperature. Exceeding a certain threshold, i.e. 1800°C inside the combustion chamber, threatens to generate poisonous endothermic NOx compounds.  I am in favour of setting up an appropriate EP committee to explain who actually made the mistake of imposing environmental targets on the automotive industry, without specifying and strictly specifying how emissions are measured, unrealistic from the point of view of the course of physico-chemical phenomena. This is not the first time that ambitious environmental regulations based on untested technologies, such as CCS or other solutions such as 10% fuel bio-additives and even their entire packages, such as the economically harmful climate package, are being pushed through in the EP.  I believe that the blame for the Volkswagen m.in lies with the European legislators, i.e. the EP and the EC. Nature, as it turned out, is governed by other laws – the laws of physics and chemistry, and the course of processes and whole phenomena is not subject to the excessive ambitions of politicians and their legislative creations.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. – This Parliament will soon debate and vote on the establishment of a commission to examine the possible handling of nitrogen oxide emissions by some motor vehicle companies. It is a complex issue, affecting European industry and the air quality breathed by our citizens and requiring political responsibilities for ensuring non-compliance with European regulations. The Commission's initiative on which we are now discussing does not in any way contribute to clarifying this problem. On the contrary, it generalizes an exception to the emission limit applicable to European regulations that are in force and to which the automotive industry should have already adapted. This initiative is a flight forward, seriously in breach of the Commission's responsibilities and raises more than a reasonable doubt about the EU's willingness to regulate in favour of its citizens. The future of industry and employment is about environmental responsibility and technological innovation: the Commission's message is a step backwards that we cannot allow.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. – The Commission's proposal to increase NOx emission limits is an unprecedented step backwards in the area of health and environmental protection. For the first time in history, the proposal is to increase NOx emissions from diesel engines by 110% compared to the original plan. At a time when the Dieselgate scandal and the Paris agreement are resonating around the world, such a proposal seems like a bad joke. Moreover, the general exemption from the emission limits in force is not compatible with the objective and content of Regulation (EC) No 715/2007 and exceeds the implementing powers laid down there down thereto. It is typical of this Commission that the decision has been approved by the representatives of the Member States in the Technical Committee for Motor Vehicles instead of the ordinary legislative process. Manufacturers always state that they need a long-term outlook and stable conditions. In this case, they had nine years to adapt to the new requirements, and some manufacturers meet the set limits. That is why I say that by changing legislation, honest people cannot be punished for dishonesty. We are now hearing that if we do not accept this Commission proposal, there will be another even weaker one, that it is better to have this proposal than no proposal, because that would have an even greater impact on the environment. I think it's just blackmail. Once set goals must be respected, their implementation and enforcement must be ensured. Parliament has no choice but to veto the whole proposal.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The next item is the report by Julie Ward, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education, on the importance of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting the EU's fundamental values ((2015/2139(INI) – (A8-0373/2015)).

name: Julie WARD
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, recent dramatic events, such as the refugee crisis and the terrorist attacks in Paris, have shown that, more than ever, Europe must tackle these common challenges and promote its fundamental values – not in a divided way, but with unity. My report, therefore, aims to build on the common agreement reached by all 28 EU Education Ministers in the aftermath of the Paris attacks. This ministerial agreement acknowledges that joint efforts are needed in order to prevent and tackle marginalisation, intolerance, racism and extremism, and to preserve a framework of equal opportunities for all. The report identifies opportunities, along with challenges, and makes concrete recommendations for action at all governmental levels, as well as at EU level, including the increased use of culture in external actions and in the development agenda. It recognises the unique role that culture, inclusive learning and active citizenship can play in building strong, confident, resilient and cohesive communities of the future. I decided to take a positive approach, particularly in respect of young people and the potential that they offer to society, and to celebrate that cultural diversity can create empathy, empower marginalised communities and foster more active citizenship. Intercultural dialogues and exchanges also address stereotypes, prejudices and discrimination by the majority. Intercultural practice demonstrates that you can only truly understand yourself when you encounter the other and thus see yourself reflected in another’s eyes. So the other becomes you and you become the other. You develop empathy, compassion and the ability to stand in someone else’s shoes. You see others, not as alien or unequal, but as neighbours, all part of the human family. When we refuse to engage in intercultural dialogue, the phenomenon of ‘othering’ begins and can ultimately lead to the terrible genocides we have witnessed.  My report promotes the need to reinvigorate and promote healthy dialogue between all kinds of communities, leading to a better understanding and acceptance of common fundamental values, thereby laying the foundations for more inclusive and pluralistic societies. Too often in times of crisis, the dominant media narrative is that somebody else is to blame for the world’s problems. This results in scapegoating and a culture of fear. However, when people come together and talk honestly and share in each other’s culture they learn that we are all human beings with common aspirations and concerns. During the recent devastating floods in my north—west region, the much—maligned Muslim community were amongst the first to offer practical aid and moral support to remote rural communities, countering growing Islamophobia through spontaneous intercultural dialogue born out of true compassion and demonstrating a greater degree of sympathy and solidarity than the government did. Formal and informal education and intercultural dialogue are crucial tools for a more harmonious society. Children are not born to hate, so tackling things from an early age is vital. But learning does not hold only one form and have only one purpose, nor does it solely concern children and young people. Learning to be an active and responsible citizen is a lifelong learning process that can take many forms. We are sometimes afraid of otherness, and the best way to address this is to talk to different people, to share different practices and learn from different cultures. In this way we grow as people, gaining confidence, making friends, being surer of ourselves and, incidentally, being more employable and more entrepreneurial. I am proud to represent a region that includes examples of vibrant multicultural cities and towns, such as Manchester, Liverpool, Preston Blackburn, Bury, Bolton, Rochdale, Burnley, Accrington and others. I know, therefore, that cultural diversity is an opportunity, not a threat, and I firmly believe it is a solution, not a problem. My report adopts an integrated approach when addressing this broad and complex topic, not separating culture, education, youth and active citizenship into four different fields of action but building bridges and synergies between all those elements.  So I call on the Commission and Member States to also adopt a cross-cutting and coherent approach between all fields of their actions in and outside Europe. The European Union is at a particular point in history where notions of identity and belonging are contested, reconfigured and defended with strong feelings from a diversity of voices and divergent political perspectives. I look forward to a healthy debate and thank all those who have worked with me on this report.

name: Julie WARD
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission wholeheartedly welcomes the report on the role of intercultural dialogue, cultural diversity and education in promoting EU fundamental values. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur Ms Ward on the excellent result of her work. The terrible terrorist attacks in France and elsewhere in Europe remind us yet again of the importance of building cohesive societies, where everyone can feel safe and valued irrespective of one’s conviction or background.  The richness of the social, linguistic and cultural diversity that the EU represents is indeed held together, as the report says, by the fundamental values that we share: respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. Continuous efforts to promote multiculturalism, integration and social cohesion are needed to guarantee a Union in which pluralism, non-discrimination, tolerance, justice, solidarity and equality prevail.  The Commission welcomes the strong emphasis of the report on the role of intercultural dialogue and education, which helps learners to show an open mind and be active, responsible citizens equipped with a critical mind and committed to our common fundamental values. This is precisely the point of the Paris Declaration which the Education Ministers and myself endorsed in March last year. To follow up on this declaration with concrete actions is a key priority for me. Preventing violent radicalisation by promoting an inclusive society and democratic values is firmly embedded in the European Security Agenda, which recognises the key role of education, youth work and intercultural dialogue in this context. We will also follow up on the European Council’s call to address the factors underlying radicalisation. Such a complex phenomenon cannot be handled in a simplistic manner. Quick fixes and spectacular announcements will not do. We need deeper changes in the social fabric of our societies that can only be achieved through longer—term actions, particularly through formal and non—formal learning. The Ward report identifies several very relevant areas for action: the need for civic education to start from an early age, the creation of common education platforms, the development of quality training programmes promoting diversity, the provision of counselling services at schools, the need to provide teachers with multilingual and intercultural skills, and the creation of rights-based and gender-sensitive learning environments.  Important steps have, in the meantime, already been taken. Firstly, the Education Ministers have agreed to anchor the objectives of the Paris Declaration firmly in the current priorities for European cooperation in the field of education and training. Secondly, we will also use the Erasmus+ programme to its full, in order to put the Paris Declaration into action. Projects linked to equity, inclusion and non-discrimination will be substantially reinforced. In 2016, EUR 400 million will be spent on transnational projects which will enhance, amongst others, the education of disadvantaged learners and promote the integration of newly arrived migrants. In addition, a specific call will soon be released with a budget of EUR 13 million to disseminate good practices in the field of inclusion, anti-radicalisation and integration of migrants.  The report also rightly emphasises the importance of intercultural dialogue in promoting fundamental values. The Commission Work Programme for 2016 stresses the importance for the EU to take advantage of opportunities to advance its values, as well as European history and culture. In line with this idea, I, together with High Representative/Vice-President Mogherini, am currently working on measures to further cultural diplomacy, in particular to enhance intercultural understanding through direct people-to-people contacts and civil society relationships. Again, this is fully in line with the report in front of us, which calls on the EU to include culture and cultural exchanges and to enhance education in EU external relations. Generally speaking, promoting intercultural dialogue, cultural awareness and cultural expression are high up on our working agenda with the Member States and they will be discussed at the European Culture Forum, which will take place in Brussels on 19 and 20 April.  I greatly appreciate the commitment of Parliament to stand behind this important agenda of enhancing fundamental values through culture and education. I am looking forward to working with you on these issues. We have no time to lose and we need to join forces to take concrete action now.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. In view of the millions of European citizens, a number of current social issues are clarified in today's report. One of the initiators– I would also like to thank Mrs Ward for her excellent work – had the main ambition to do nothing but reality. The report clearly points to the unique role and opportunities of the family in conveying our common values. In my current experience, nothing can replace the family when it comes to the transfer of norms and knowledge. I am pleased that, in addition to political camps, we can agree on this fundamental issue.  The social role of religions, if indirectly, remains decisive, contrary to all previous predictions. All this, I would like to stress, is not a matter of faith, but a sociological fact. Interfaith dialogue should be a fundamental element of policies to help young people. Religious communities differ from ngos of all kinds, among other things, by offering an alternative to man from the beginning to the end of life. Religions and their representatives have a sure, important task in creating social cohesion. Cultural diversity has now received attention because of the size of migration that we did not expect before. In today's Situation in Europe, it is almost insurmountable who is the immigrant, who is the refugee. Without responsible communities, there is no dialogue, no peaceful coexistence. That's what we tried to do.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, with this report, Commissioner, by Mrs Ward, whom I thank, we say that the challenge today in Europe and in the Mediterranean is cultural and educational. , sharing of the Union's fundamental values, crossed by migration processes, conflicts and terrorism. One year after Charlie Hebdo and the Paris Declaration of Ministers, we call for all policies, not just educational ones, to take an intercultural approach that goes beyond assimilation or multiculturalism, not privatising religious memberships, but making them meet and dialogue in the public space, with mutual respect.  Strong signals are needed: in foreign security policy, with the initiative of cultural diplomacy; on the economic and social agenda; expanding access to immigrant culture and training, with the educational corridors we have called for for students in refugee camps; promoting inclusion with active citizenship, volunteering, civil service programmes; supporting creative enterprises and sports practice. Commissioner, yes, we welcome the ad hoc calls for Erasmus and Creative Europe, but I believe that at this point we need strong communication along these lines, in order to give a more holistic meaning to this policy.

name: Andrew LEWER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I would not seek to question the largely well-intentioned nature of where this report is coming from. Indeed, it contains positive elements, such as recognising the vital role of education and educators in integration and the importance of media literacy in the digital age. It does nevertheless contain many more aspects that the ECR and its UK delegation are unable to support, and which go way beyond the 17 March declaration. These include calls for stronger EU representations within the UN, appointments of EU cultural attachés, harmonisation of visa procedures, adequate – which I would assume means ‘yet more’ – funding for Europe for citizens, which has many controversial elements, and proposals relating to Member State education policies and other items which are outside EU competences. The report is also full of references to EU citizens and EU citizenship, which many ECR members dislike and may surprise many UK citizens when efforts are being made by Europhiles to persuade them that the EU’s ambitions are limited and have no federalist element to them; clearly not the case judging by elements in this report. As well as learning and understanding other cultures, it is important that we have understanding and pride in our own countries’ values. This is not referenced in this report, and may even be regarded as distasteful by some of its adherents: big mistake. Education and intercultural dialogue are indeed vital tools in the fight against violent extremism. An expanded role for the EU is not. Culture and education are national competences, and if the EU really wants to protect cultural diversity and subsidiarity they should remain so. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question by raising the blue card. – Mr. Lewer, I have listened carefully to what you have been saying and I can understand part of your presentation because I know what political spectrum you come from and how you think. I would like to ask you if you agree with me, as Mr. Commissioner has stated, that apart from these topics you have been talking about, education about our history, European history and everything that has been happening in Europe in the last century is very important for generations to come to know how a disjonited Europe, Europe in war has brought great calamity to all its peoples? Do you agree with me that this should be part of the education of our young people?

name: Andrew LEWER
text: blue-card answer. – An understanding of European history and its culture is vital for everybody who lives in the Member States of the EU to progress, understand one another and cooperate. That does not in any sense translate into an added or statutory role for the EU in that particular area.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, as the Ward report shows, intercultural dialogue is a necessary tool for building a more integrated European society. In these dialogues, the partners must accept each other's differences and particularities, but they must share, above all, a minimum of basic values and principles. Without the recognition of these values and principles, dialogue is born flawed. Intercultural dialogue makes it possible to get to know each other better and can sometimes help you get to know yourself better. In any case, the purpose of dialogue between cultures must always be respectful coexistence. The report refers to violent extremism and links it to social exclusion. We have a challenge before us when we find that this type of violence has also been expressed by young people with university degrees and that they have grown up in educated settings, or people belonging to well-off families and that during their childhood and youth they did not suffer problems of integration, so it is not easy to make these contraposed realities marry. I would like to thank Julie Ward for the importance she attaches in that text to the external cultural action of the European Union. Culture can foster close links between countries and the European Union should always keep it in mind. In conclusion, in the Paris Declaration of 17 March 2015, the Ministers of Education of the Member States undertook to take action to strengthen the role of intercultural dialogue in the education of citizens. The time has come to move from proposals to effective actions. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: blue-card question. – You spoke about intercultural dialogue and the need to accept differences. I am sure that you are aware that, for example, in the Qur’an, it says that Muslims must not take non—believers as their friends, advisers and confidants as they cannot be trusted. The Islamic religion teaches the doctrine of Taqiya, which says that Muslims may lie to non-Muslims in order to further the interests of their religion. Do you think that this is a bar to any meaningful intercultural dialogue and how do we overcome it?

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Batten, I find what you have told me very interesting. If you have heard what I have said, I have insisted very much that it is essential to accept the differences between the different communities, but, of course, respecting all basic principles that are elementary; that is, without these principles there is no coexistence and intercultural dialogue is not possible. In that sense, I could agree with you.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, is the way to promote democracy, tolerance and respect only in education? It will certainly be an important part, but without concrete action, there is nothing more than statements of intent in the abstract. The contradiction with what this report proclaims is that the European Union is the first to stigmatise distant cultures when it erects external borders and swarms those who want to reach the territory of the European Union, fostering the idea of cultural supremacy in a European Union with insurmountable borders.  What does the European Union do when it mixes the problem of migration with threats to people's security? Is the European Union not the first to stigmatise migrants in so many speeches and conclusions, for example from the European Council?  Education, yes. But it is through social inclusion that barriers and prejudices are, in practice, destroyed.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I welcome the agreement with Mrs Ward in this report on intercultural dialogue, for her firm commitment to the European values understood in their genuine significance, consistent with the initial will, but also with the shared social construction project which we are currently under threat. And, for the same reason, I reject Mrs Bilde's proposal for an alternative resolution, which is based on hypotheses that are in the antipodes of what Mrs Ward's report rightly raises to us, with education as a central but not exclusive habit of dialogue, to work with the democratic habits and social cohesion that we would like to see present throughout Europe, enriching and not replacing the historical and cultural diversity of all our peoples. That is why we must refer to the new and necessary approach to many of our urban models, which marginalize rather than connect, to the failure found in the relationship between education and work, the social elevator inaccessible to so many young people in our neighbourhoods and cities. That's where the future of Europe is played, in Moleenbeek, in Saint-Denis, in so many other Spanish, German, Italian or English cities. We have to invest in European citizenship. We must win the battle of respect and real freedom for each and every one of our citizens, whatever their origin, their year of arrival, their cultural or religious difference. Thus, and not with the obsessive protection of supposedly threatened national identities; even less, by building walls or re-recovering borders that we are witnessing today with a certain fatalism. It is not only necessary for Europe to believe in itself, to adopt effectively the stimulating content of this report, to recover the coherence lost between its words, the Paris Declaration, for example, and its facts, which are ashamed or saddening us every day. Let us recover the Europe project, open and free for the circulation of ideas, cultures and people. We'll all win with it.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mrs Ward for her approach in her report. In the current period of bewilderment in the European Union, we have had the courage to indicate that the common values that keep our societies together continue to be: freedom, social justice, fairness, non-discrimination, democracy, human rights, the rule of law and solidarity. Intercultural dialogue, education and cultural diversity are adequately designed to remind the Member States and the institutions of the European Union that their centrality must be accompanied by credible measures of social cohesion. I agree that the action of the EU institutions and the Member States must be geared towards ensuring equality not only formally but also substantively for the real fight against all forms of discrimination and marginalisation. I therefore hope and pray that the institutions will be able to take advantage of these suggestions.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, obviously you must not like this European Union, which you always claim to save at all costs, since this text is nothing but a real disregard for the European treaties. Indeed, I would like to point out that Article 6 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union makes education and culture the exclusive competence of the Member States. However, this report, under the guise of good feelings, seeks to put educational and cultural policies in the fold of Brussels, whose failures, although long recognised by many European leaders, Mrs Merkel and Mr Cameron to name but a few, are now taking a most barbaric form. Apparently, it does matter to you, that women are being raped on New Year's Eve, that thousands of people are victims of bloody terrorist attacks, you still believe that by forcing the peoples of Europe to deny their culture and tradition, living it together will be saved.  Colleagues, I cannot say whether voting on such a report is a matter of despair or total irresponsibility. Those who love Europe and the cultural diversity of its member states will inevitably vote against this text. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Blue card question. I would just like to remind Mrs Bilde that Article 167 of the Treaty actually states that the European Union, on the basis of the UNESCO Convention on Cultural Diversity and the Unesco Commission on the Common Cultural Heritage, has the right and the duty to intervene, naturally with due regard for the subsidiarity of the Member States, in the cultural field and by promoting and enhancing both cultural diversity, intercultural dialogue and also cultural diversity. , of course, both material and intangible assets. And so also in the educational part there is an open method of coordination between Europe's educational policies and recommendations on educational lines.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, yes, of course, I understand that there may eventually be examples of things that are a little less complicated than those we are seeing at the moment, particularly in our country. You can see that at this hour, we have a lot of problems. We have had disasters that have occurred in the last few months and we cannot pretend that they did not happen. We tried to do that with the monuments that are destroyed. Look, no matter which side you turn to, you can't put in place a cultural exchange that works. We must therefore use what is wrong to try to find solutions and not to act systematically because we have the right to do so. I think we really need to think.

name: Sabine VERHEYEN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Promoting intercultural dialogue is now more important than ever.  Mutual understanding and respect between different cultures must be the basis of our coexistence, so that our society can continue to exist in diversity and freedom. In this report, we call on the Commission and – Mrs Bilde and Mr Lewer – also the Member States to promote cultural exchanges and cultural education and to regard and develop it as an important part of eu foreign policy, but also of European domestic policy in particular. Education in particular plays a very important role. An intercultural and value-based approach should be taken here at an early stage. Educational institutions of all kinds should not only impart knowledge, but also ethical and civil society values in order to educate their students to be tolerant and responsible members of society. The role of teachers is also essential in value education. The EU's ERASMUS+ programme has already enabled many young people to exchange ideas with other cultures. The refugee crisis is one of the European Union's biggest challenges today. We must work together to prevent extremism and xenophobia and to combat all forms of discrimination and exclusion.  To this end, the communication of common social values is indispensable. However, we also need an enhanced dialogue between different cultures, but also religions. Religions influence the actions and thinking of people in our society. That is why it is important that we work out similarities through dialogue between religions and minimise contradictions.  It is essential that all religious communities find ways of being in line with our common European values. Only in this way can we live together in peace and freedom in the future.

name: Giorgos GRAMMATIKAKIS
text: S&D). Madam President, as many colleagues have said earlier and as Mrs Merkel's report rightly points out. Ward, intercultural dialogue does indeed reflect some of the fundamental values of the European Union. These values reached their apotheosis both with the reception of migrants by the German public and with the heroic efforts of the islanders in Greece to save the refugees. But these values are losing their importance without political will and action, and that is where we have come. So how can values be strengthened through education, culture, the arts and sport? For religions I have second thoughts, because they are often contrary to the enlightening notions of humanity. Unfortunately, however, the resources of the European programmes which can promote these objectives remain insufficient, despite what the Commissioner said. I hope that the report will be the beginning of another, more generous, European approach to these crucial issues.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: I do not know if you are aware - otherwise there is always the ENF Group to remind you - but your report is dreamy and shaky in the light of the recent migration invasion that has resulted from your European Union and its Schengen Treaty and your open borders policy, which, by the way, has led to disastrous and almost chaotic results in the past year 2015. In the light of what happened in Cologne, your report is naïve and worldly.  To see cultural diversity as a value in itself is misplaced. Europe, not the European Union - that is something else - Europe as a cultural area and as a continent of civilisation needs a sense of its own identity and open defending it, rather than having it watered down and opened up to incompatible values from all over the world. That's not the point.

name: Milan ZVER
text: – Intercultural and interfaith dialogue are important at a time when Europe is facing a number of challenges related to immigration, religious and intercultural conflicts and the rise of radicalism. As I have already pointed out in the adoption of the report on preventing radicalisation, education has an extremely important role to play in regulating this challenge.  However, I would like to stress that the adoption of different cultures and practices must not go to the fundamental value of the European Union, such as respect for human rights, dignity, freedom, democracy, equality between women and men and the rule of law enshilarged in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union. Tolerance for specific cultural orientations cannot be more important than respect for universal fundamental values.  I am not happy with the whole report, but I will support it tomorrow, also because it emphasises the importance of family in the whole process and the importance of educating disadvantaged children. I also consider it important to point out that it is important to respond appropriately to practices that are not in line with the fundamental values of the environment in which we live. (The speaker agreed to accept the question raised by raising the blue card (Rule 162(8)).

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: question by raising the blue card – I thank the chairman and thank my colleague Zver for accepting the question. A discussion is under way on the revision of the multiannual financial framework, so I would like to know if you believe that better implementation of intercultural dialogue can be achieved through stronger changes to the budget at European level and greater allocation of funds for the activities you discussed and which are also explained in the report?

name: Milan ZVER
text: answer to the question raised by raising the blue card. – I think that this is a key issue, that is, financial support for all of our wishes and projects, which we have written down, among other things, in this latest report. There will have to be an audit of the financial budget for the current financial period. Without additional resources, Europe will not be up to the task that new and new migrant waves have put before us.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – I thank my colleague Julie Ward for the constructive work on this report. The terrorist attacks in Paris over the past year have shown the importance of strengthening intercultural dialogue with third countries and investing in inclusive education from an early age.  In order to overcome the identity crisis that Europe is currently crossing and from which nationalists feed, we need to focus on developing appropriate education policies. The Paris Declaration of 17 March 2015 clearly showed the political will of the European Union's education ministers with a common effort to combat marginalisation, intolerance and racism.  As we know well, the economic, social and cultural exclusion of certain groups from the social community is one of the root causes of violence. It is therefore essential, by promoting cultural diversity and social inclusion, to counter these processes. I am extremely proud of the Erasmus+ programme because it plays a key role in the fight against prejudice and intolerance among adolescents.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I would like to stress that the European Parliament's report, which focuses on intercultural dialogue precisely because of the threat of radicalism and conflict, is not just important for its topicality. So it cannot only be a response to this current threat, but it must be systematic work, which is the best prevention against national conflicts and intolerance and against the increase in violence.  European values, that's not artificial. These are naturally general human values, which is why it is important that we, the citizens of the countries of the European Union, understand them and be able to share them. The European Union grows out of the roots of Judaism, Christianity and antiquity, but it is made up of very different peoples and cultures, it is influenced by globalisation, migration, and therefore it is necessary to work on better understanding and sharing these values with each other. The report includes many important knowledge and proposals, which is why I have decided to support the report because it emphasises the need for ethical education and ethical values, citizenship education, knowledge of foreign languages, which is necessary for joint activities and dialogue and must be supported. Teaching must be guided not only to rights, but also to accountability. I think that the solidarity shown by hundreds of volunteers today is proof that European human values in general are alive and worth supporting.

name: Damian DRĂGHICI
text: – Madam President, I would first of all like to congratulate Ms Ward for her great work on this very important topic in the current context of increasing concern over radicalisation and extremism in Europe and around the world.  More than ever, we need to focus on the high potential of intercultural dialogue and on the EU dimension in education to promote and develop a deeper inclusivity and sense of belonging, respect for cultural diversity, community spirit and acceptance of multicultural and multinational societies. As education has a central role to play in transmitting the principle of active citizenship and multicultural respect to younger generations, we need to fully engage all education stakeholders in this respect and ensure that culture, education and intercultural dialogue receive a central position in European policies. It is essential that we increase investment in education and create more inclusive learning environments, by ensuring equal access to high quality education and lifelong learning opportunities for all learners, especially for those coming from disadvantaged or vulnerable groups.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – Europe's cultural diversity is our common asset. We only have it as long as european nations share a vision of one European community and try to fulfil it. We are still learning to exploit this wealth, and it has to be said that here I see the contribution of the present report, which details both the potential and the shortcomings in the management of spiritual wealth, which is our common heritage. I consider many of the proposals in this report to be correct. However, as a matter of principle, I do not agree that so-called gender ideology and gender perspectives should be assigned to common European values such as solidarity, subsidiarity or the dignity of the human person. Neither the Treaties nor the Charter of Fundamental Rights know the term gender or gender, they know only equality between women and men. Of course, these terms undoubtedly enrich European diversity today. However, they may at most be the subject of intercultural dialogue. They are by no means one of its preconditions or objectives. Unfortunately, the report presented in paragraphs 20 and 27 says the exact opposite, and I find this very unfortunate. Nevertheless, I will support the report.

name: Stefano MAULLU
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that this report is part of a very special historical moment, which defines in detail the need for intercultural dialogue that puts the values of the European Union at the centre, particularly towards all those who see our cultural dimension as a moment of arrival and hope.  The values we represent must be accompanied by a moment in which civil society is the protagonist through dedicated financial instruments and programmes that allow this extraordinary network that each country makes available, to bring together cultural diversity and religious diversity, at a time when religious fundamentalism becomes the fundamental element through which terrorism accompanies and creates the conditions for the younger generations to be watered. This report completely effectively counteracts this dreamlike dimension that is being proposed to young people on the other side of the Mediterranean and therefore deserves our full support.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank my colleague Julie Word for her report, which highlights the fact that intercultural dialogue is one of the cornerstones of the very idea of Europe. And at a time like this, I believe it is more necessary than ever to reaffirm this concept, through concrete interventions in the daily life of our society. Education, education, training and culture are the keys to such interventions. To this end, Europe must focus on schools, stressing once again and forcefully their fundamental role as a place for the dissemination and exchange of cultures. The lack of social inclusion and the marginalisation of the suburbs of our cities, as we now know, prevent real intercultural dialogue, with the risk of encouraging the innuendo of radicalisation. It is therefore necessary, so that certain tragedies do not happen again, to intervene above all on young people, all young people, which we must welcome and educate in the values of tolerance and respect for the different cultures, values that are proper to the European Union.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Madam President, migration has marked the history of mankind and has happened for various reasons. Whether it was occupation, fleeing danger or economic migration, the large influx of new populations has always been a trauma of sorts – for the home population, the migrants themselves or both. Even today we are witnessing mass migration to Europe and we must acknowledge that they are the cause of trauma, both for those who come in search of safety and a better life, and for the domicile population. I have no doubt that modern Europe is more than tolerant of diversity. Witnesses to our hospitality are the millions of migrants that Member States have received in the past few decades and given them a chance at a better life. But such an opportunity must not come unconditionally, and one of the main preconditions must be full integration – acceptance of democracy, the rule of law and our Christian values, of course, with the guarantee of retaining our own peculiarness. Those who are not ready for this should not be welcome!

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and all the shadow rapporteurs for their contribution to this report. Europe’s cultural, ethnic and religious diversity is rooted in the history of our continent, and it is significantly increasing in a transformative way. Today, according to statistical data provided by Eurostat, around 7% of the European Union’s population was born outside the EU. This cultural diversity is the core of the European project and ‘unity in diversity’ is the motto of our Union. Lately we have witnessed intolerance, racism and discrimination threatening Europe’s stability and development. This requires urgent action and there is no doubt that the most effective tool for tackling intolerance, racism and discrimination is education. Actions to promote an intercultural approach in education are highly needed in order to support multiculturalism, integration, social inclusion and cohesion.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – Multicultural dialogue is a broad and complex concept that is widely used today and basically means communication between people who come from different walks of life, religious, social, cultural, generational. And also multicultural dialogue means thinking, reflecting and embracing diversity with a view to cooperation and constructive dialogue. It means, in a way, a great individual and a social challenge of modern times, and right now, of course, we are in these moments when we have to give special attention to it. This migration cycle will last, this is a long-term process, and that is why I agree with my colleagues who have said that we also need to devote much more resources to education, to raise and understand the importance of multicultural dialogue.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, as a Eurosceptic, I am all for respecting national culture. I do not want the homogenised amorphous blob that comes when people try to promote a sterile pan-European culture. But you can bet your bottom euro that calls for more taxpayers’ cash to be splashed on EU culture, on white elephants like the LUX prize, and on more EU at the United Nations, are going to end up promoting the ring of stars without doing the blindest thing to strengthen those precious national cultures that we should be holding so dear.  As for our education system promoting the EU, we need to remember that the Education Act of 1996 requires schools to be impartial on political issues. It is time to actually enforce that, not to have more and more EU pushed into our schools. Let’s be neutral.  If you want to know what is wrong with the Labour Party in this place, you need look no further than this report.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – In our common mother tongue, In Hungarian, I would like to ask Commissioner Navracsics about: do you agree that there are certain things where cultural diversity, relativism and there are things in which there is no such thing, because they are of an absolute and universal nature. At least in Europe. Such are European human rights. I also ask Commissioner Navracsics and, by the way, my colleagues and the reporter what category women's equality, equal dignity and the right to physical integrity and safety are categorised in. I am very confident that you see this as a European human rights issue and, for example, what happened in Cologne on New Year's Eve, which I would call the black night of Europe, is seen as a mass and gross violation of human rights. If so, why is this issue not on the European Parliament's agenda, commissioner and dear European Parliament.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, beginning with the question, I am really sorry that the honourable Member of the European Parliament, Krisztina Morvai, missed my first intervention because I was just talking about the importance of human rights and the importance of the rule of law among European values. The European Union is based on human rights and the rule of law, so I think that when we talk about intercultural dialogue and when we talk about the role of education in democratic socialisation, we have to take into account those values as well, which means the universal validity of human rights in the European civilisation. I think there is a consensus that education plays an enormous role in democratic socialisation, and there is a consensus that if we want to make our democracies more cohesive and more efficient then we have to go beyond formal educational institutions and we have to map out all the opportunities in non-formal and informal education and in intercultural and inter—religious dialogue , and we have to map out the role of the family in democratic socialisation, in teaching democratic soft skills for our children, for the next generations.  The Ward report is a very important element and step in this long and pretty complex road. We are just at the start of that road and I am looking forward to working with you efficiently and, hopefully, successfully on this project.

name: Julie WARD
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner and colleagues for participating in the process of creating this report and in debating what is an extremely emotional subject. I thought I would just finish by telling you a story because to participate in intercultural dialogue does not mean giving up anything, it means engaging in a wider conversation with people from around the world, from different cultures, different places, different demographic areas, different ages, different religions, people of different skin colour, people from different walks of life, from different industrial areas and rural areas. It means a richness, not a giving up of anything. I was brought up in a family that every week went to dance English country dancing. My father is a Morris man, and ‘Morris dancing’ probably comes from ‘Moorish dancing’. It comes from Africa, it comes from Islam. And it is important that people understand that our culture is not fixed; it is always changing. It needs to be open, because the richness of the past meeting with the present to create the future is what is so exciting about being human, about having conversations with other people. So this report is about openness and about welcoming, inclusive conversations with everybody. It is not about closing down society, and I look forward to working with you.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 19 January 2016. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. – In a Union constantly subject to challenges, it is extremely important for the younger generation to have access to programmes enabling it to acquire life skills and competences essential for personal development in the light of a future career and an active European citizenship. I consider it beneficial for children, regardless of their cultural and social environment, to other cultures through programmes that enable them to create a sense of common belonging and a culture of intercultural dialogue. In this context, the inclusion of special study visits to various Member States and the transnational mobility of young children through trans-regional and cross-border cooperation are a necessary means to build the foundations of European cultures, arts, languages and values. On the other hand, the mobility of young people and teachers, all forms of cooperation between schools and universities, for example through common educational platforms, programmes and joint study projects, are essential elements aimed at supporting the understanding and appreciation of cultural diversity, as well as the acquisition by young people of social, civic and intercultural skills.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: in writing. – Dear Mr President, honourable Members, the fundamental principles and values on which a united Europe is built are what makes it an attractive force for thousands of people around the world. Europe as it is today is built precisely on the basis of intercultural dialogue, on cultural diversity, diversity of ethnicities, languages and traditions.  However, in order for Europe to continue to exist as an example of tolerance, justice and peaceful coexistence, all of us, regardless of our background and differences, owe each other mutual understanding and respect. Here, the role of education is crucial. I believe that educating us in understanding cultural differences will be a much longer-term, effective and even cost-effective measure than building walls between us.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: in writing. – The development of an intercultural and interreligious dialogue with all stakeholders is a first step in the effective approach to the social-cultural conflicts that have been triggered in recent times within the EU, and beyond. Just as important is education in the training of young people, of new generations, of accepting cultural diversity, of free thinking and of respecting each other. These two instruments are essential for combating some increasingly widespread social phenomena, such as discrimination, violence, radicalism, racism and xenophobia.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: PPE), in writing. – In recent times, the EU has been struggling to respond to the critical situation it is experiencing amid the uncontrolled flow of migrants to Europe, the increasing influx of recruited religious terrorism fighters and the spread of cross-border organised crime aimed primarily at Europe. Among other things, we were shocked by the recent allegations of numerous sexual assaults against women in Cologne by foreigners, which once again triggered the spread of extreme racist anti-European messages, with the main aim being immigrants and content of intolerance to diversity of any kind within the EU. In the Europe of 28, strengthening intercultural dialogue is a catalyst, especially in the area of fundamental rights, with the aim of promoting European values, as set out in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, and respecting cultural, religious and humanitarian diversity, not only of European populations but also of those who are justifiably seeking a free environment of equality and social cohesion, in order to work and raise their children, hunted by the people of war. Under the pressure of the migration/refugee issue, it is necessary to understand that it is inconceivable that refugees, irregular migrants, criminals of common criminal law and terrorists should be socially assimilated and treated in a generalised way.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – In a multicultural society, dialogue is a desirable alternative to antagonistic relations between representatives of different cultures, the way in which they are educated, and the dissemination of fundamental values. Attitudes of mutual respect and recognition therefore become a condition for fruitful cooperation between peoples. Intercultural dialogue is essentially a two-way process in which both sides experience benefits. Eu Member States' programmes (Tempus III, Mundus) promoting the mobility of young people, including academics, are therefore a valuable initiative. Through common educational platforms, we experience a process of synergies between generations. In addition, by participating in volunteering, sports and arts initiatives, there is a process of separation of individuals, whose activities increase the closer relationship, which consequently facilitates the establishment of team cooperation. This cooperation allows for a much faster fight against social phenomena, i.e. violence, radicalism, racism, xenophobia.  Another flagship project is the Partnership of European Cities, i.e. 'Europe for Citizens'. Its aim is to disseminate cultural, information, economic and economic exchanges in order to be able to co-create international activities at the root. The role of dialogue thus becomes the so-called "window to the world", the strength of which stems from its diversity.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Motto of the European Union "United in Diversity" highlights the great richness of Europe's cultural, social, linguistic and religious diversity. Intercultural dialogue plays a huge role in the coexisting of different cultural identities and beliefs in Europe. This dialogue must not only involve public authorities, it requires the involvement of society as a whole, including representatives of social life, religious leaders, but above all of the family, which is the fundamental cell of our social life. It is in the family that each of us has become acquainted with the culture, values and norms of society, which is why the family plays such an important role in promoting dialogue between cultures.  Intercultural dialogue brings peoples and peoples together, effectively counteracts conflicts and helps to resolve them, promotes reconciliation. It allows us to better understand the differences between us. This is important, especially in the context of recent tragic and worrying events in Europe and around the world. Every step needs to be taken to promote this dialogue, using new technologies, including social media. In this way, we will reach young people, who are particularly vulnerable to the distorted image of other cultures.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The next item is the report by Mr Balz, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on stocktaking and challenges of the EU Financial Services Regulation [2015/2016(INI)] (A3-0360/2015).

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her As rapporteur, I am pleased that Lord Hill is taking part in our debate on financial regulation today. Our committee, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, has voted by a large majority in favour of a comprehensive review of financial market legislation over the past five years. This does not mean deregulation. This means that, for the first time, we will receive an overall overview of the existing banking, insurance, fund and market regulations and their interaction. This also means that vulnerabilities are discovered and fixed. It also means that the effects of regulation become transparent. When the financial market and debt crisis erupted in 2007/2008, the legislator was unheard of being called upon to act. We have operated financial market regulations in crisis mode, and I think we have been successful in it. No stone has remained on the other. We quickly rebuilt the whole building, rebuilt it quickly, with new supervisory authorities, with binding EU-wide standards and a far-reaching banking union. But as we continue to build, we should look at where gaps are, where are crooked, where inaccurate and where construction was too fast.  That is why, as rapporteur, I call for the Commission to draw up a comprehensive impact study across all financial market sectors by the end of this year. In doing so, we list the following points for the examination. Firstly, the consistency and accuracy of the existing laws, because the rules should not contradict each other or call each other into question. They must be comprehensible and also practicable for the user. Secondly, the proportionality of legislation, because we want to preserve the diversity of the market for consumers and we do not want to overwhelm small and medium-sized enterprises.  Thirdly, the complexity and complexity of European and international requirements, because we want to continue to be competitive internationally with our European financial service providers. We want to have a strong voice when a decision is taken at the Banking or Insurance Committee in Basel or at IOSCO in Madrid. Fourthly, the added value for consumers and investors, because we want legislation not only to produce information material, but also to meet the needs of consumers and investors. We also want barriers to product access to be reduced and the internal market for financial services really being lived. Fifthly, the economic effects, because we are calling for the financial sector to return to the strongest where it can have a positive effect, namely by serving the real economy. The legislator must create the possibilities for this. For me, as rapporteur, and for the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats as a whole, these are essential points that we want to improve. Here we are calling for a quantitative and qualitative analysis, by the Commission itself in cooperation with the European supervisory authorities.  Financial market regulation must meet the objective of financial stability and consumer protection, and that remains a top priority. But the success and design of financial market regulation is also a location card for the European financial industry. If, Commissioner, you want to boost the investment strength of the European economy through the Capital Markets Union, then you must include all financial market sectors, including banks and insurance companies, and that is why, Commissioner Hill, we are counting on us to see us again in a year's time on this very issue, on the occasion of the presentation of the impact studies that are due.

name: Nathan GILL
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for giving me the chance to come along this evening. I want to congratulate Mr Balz for this excellent report and for setting out the issues at stake so clearly. I share 100% his goal of creating an effective legislative framework for financial services. For that to happen, people need to know that it will be implemented. But they also need to know that it will be proportionate and that it can respond to changing circumstances, and that is the logic that sits behind the call for evidence that forms part of the Capital Markets Union (CMU) action plan. I therefore see this report and the call for evidence as being consistent, the one with the other. I would like briefly to focus on two issues raised by the report: the need for a regulatory framework that supports growth, and the need to make sure that smaller businesses have access to finance. It is clear that the major reforms we have introduced in recent years have made the financial system stronger, and now it is time to check whether, looked at in the round, those 40 separate pieces of legislation that we passed have had any unintended consequences. As Mr Balz said, it is part of good law making to check that our rules are doing what they set out to do. The call for evidence will close at the end of this month. I hope it will give us a better understanding of the impact of our legislation. It will help determine our approach to over 100 reviews of existing legislation planned over the next five years. It will inform how we monitor the effectiveness of legislation in the future, and I know that your report makes a number of interesting recommendations in this area. We need legislation that is proportionate if we are going to create an environment that supports investment. If legislation can be streamlined, if it can be simplified and yet achieve the same prudential objective, let us be ready to change it. I am looking forward to reporting back to you when we have been through the ‘call for evidence’ responses and completed our analysis. Improving access to finance for smaller companies is also one of the priorities in the report that I strongly support. If we need companies, if we want companies to start up and grow and create jobs here in Europe, we have to improve the funding conveyor belt. That is what lies behind the work to build a Capital Markets Union. I am grateful for the support that you have given it in this report. As you know, we have made a quick start. Among the initiatives relevant to the report, we have proposed to overhaul the Prospectus Directive. We are looking forward to working with you on our proposal to relaunch simple, transparent and standardised securitisation, and that is to free up lending capacity in the banking sector and increased lending to the wider economy. The Council reached an agreement on that in record time. I hope we can keep up the same kind of pace. Those were just two of the main areas in your report, but there is a wealth of recommendations in there. It has strengthened my belief that, by continuing to work closely together, we have a real opportunity to refine our legislation, to make sure it strikes the right balance between maintaining financial stability, giving consumers confidence, and supporting investment and growth across Europe.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: draft opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The natural consequence of the deep financial crisis, which began with the financial markets, is the comprehensive regulation of financial services, the priority of which must be product safety, of course also banking security and macroeconomic stability, which means costs and, in general, increased regulatory complexity. That is why it is time to clear and diversify the non-bank financing channels of the real economy – without the illusion that we will achieve the right proportions on the other side of the Atlantic. We welcome the European Commission's Green Paper on the Capital Markets Union. However, we suggest that the global context, international competitiveness, access to finance for small and medium-sized enterprises and, above all, listening to the market be taken into account very seriously in further studies, because sometimes removing barriers is more important than new regulations.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, congratulations to Mr Balz and all the colleagues who have worked on this very good report.  Indeed, over the last 7 years, we have adopted a multitude of European regulations on financial services as a result of the crisis. What we have wanted: to restore and preserve financial stability, to strengthen consumer protection and to avoid, in the future, the excesses in financial markets being covered by European taxpayers' money. Now is the time to see how these regulations are implemented, what the impact is, what the results are, let us see where corrections to this European legislation are needed.  I particularly appreciate the proposals in the report on the assessment of small and medium-sized enterprises' access to finance, as well as the obstacles that still exist in terms of long-term financing of projects.

name: Paul TANG
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – There is sand in the wheels of the European economy. Investment is lagging behind and growth is therefore fragile. Banks, and SMEs in particular, find it difficult to find each other. Capital markets are underdeveloped.  The capital market union can therefore be an opportunity to stimulate financial innovation, to break down barriers between Member States and to deploy capital efficiently. The Commission took a close look at the United States. It has often been said that capital markets there provide 80% of the loans and only 20% here. But to speak to David Bowie: "This is not America".  From the 80/20 ratio, it can be concluded that capital markets need to be better developed, but also that bank financing needs to be better achieved. It's important to fix banks. It is good to look again at the United States. There, a separation between savings and investment banking has been established. According to OECD research, the categorisation of banks is better regulated there.  The burkhard Balz report - my congratulations to the rapporteur - is based on the premise that the financial sector should serve the real economy. Regulation is a means of doing so. It's not an end in itself, it's not an ailment in itself, it's a means. It is through this balanced approach that the S&D Group can endorse this report. The aim of regulation must always be to serve the financial sector. Then it is also good to periodically check the servitude of the financial sector. In the end, the capital market union can only work if the European context is recognised. That means stimulating innovation and fixing banks.
