This way we get the sand out of the machine and we can move towards new growth and jobs.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, firstly I would like to thank Mr Balz for all his hard work on this file and the Commissioner for extending the deadline for his consultation. As others have stated, over the past five years the EU has put in place an unprecedented amount of financial services legislation. Therefore it is right that we take a step back and look at the overlaps and crossovers at this time.  Mr Balz’s report clearly emphasises that this review needs to go beyond value judgements and qualitative statements and stresses that any meaningful review should have a strongly quantitative aspect to it. For me the key areas of this report refer to the overlaps between files, particularly the crossover between MiFID and CRD IV, where we have brought new firms into markets legislation without adequately tailoring the capital standards to suit these new types of firms as yet. A similar issue of scope is seen with the clearing obligation in EMIR: the arrangements for non-financial firms that were intended to prevent financial firms from misusing a justified exemption have led to huge amounts of red tape for businesses that were never meant to be included. I hope to work with the Commission on solutions via the formal consultation and review, where possible by issuing level two standards to solve these issues and give practical weight to better regulation.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I am pleased with the outcome of this report. It comes at a key moment where we move from a regulation designed primarily to repair the legislative holes which were so evident in the crisis, towards the Capital Markets Union, which aims to encourage more investment and growth in Europe. The key aspect of the stocktaking report is the call for the Commission to undertake cumulative impact assessments and, at regular intervals, of all of the new legislation enacted in the aftermath of the crisis. I fully support this call. In my view it is imperative that the impact assessment looks at how different pieces of European legislation in the area of financial services interact with each other. Are there any gaps or loopholes? Are there any unintended consequences? How has Europe’s competitiveness been affected globally? We must gain a full understanding of the new legislation, at which point we can focus on building a robust and competitive Capital Markets Union. There are a number of points which I have pushed during the negotiation. Firstly, in order to ensure Europe’s competitiveness on a global level, we must have a coherent framework in place with regard to dealing with third countries, for example in UCITs. Secondly, access to finance for SMEs is key in order to bring Europe back to sustained growth. We must ensure that the regulation in place does not hinder this process, and must reduce as much as possible any barriers for SMEs’ financing which are due to excessive regulation.

name: Fabio DE MASI
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Commissioner Hill, Mr Balz, I would like to thank mr Balz for his work on this The signs in the EU are once again on deregulation of the financial markets. The financial lobbyists in Brussels have therefore cold-called the shampoo for better regulation in order to eliminate unwelcome regulation. Smart regulation of financial markets does not have to be complex. The US Glass Steagall Act, which separates investment banks and credit banks, was 37 pages long, and the much weaker EU banking regulation covers 1000 pages. In the EU, the problem of banks, which are too big, too networked and, indeed, too powerful to fail and therefore live at taxpayers' expense, has not been solved at all. Democratic US presidential candidate and old bone Bernie Sanders said the right thing to do: split them up! Burkhard Balz has worked seriously and has also taken up some of our concerns. I would like to thank him for that. However, the EU Commission wants to respond to the investment weakness and credit crunch with the Capital Markets Union and the synthetic securitisation of the packaging of scrap loans. The weakness of investment is linked to the policy of cuts and the insufficient disengagement of bank balance sheets. Mr Hill said in a speech in the United States last year that the fairytale that small and medium-sized enterprises in particular would benefit from the Capital Markets Union is above all a PR gag. Europe would need a genuine public investment programme, a decentralised banking system under public control and strict regulation of financial markets with a financial TÜV. Unfortunately, the former President of the Federal Reserve, Paul Volcker, is right: the only meaningful financial innovation in recent years has been the ATM.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Commissioner, Burkhard Balz, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. First of all, in my view, this report sets the right priorities. Contrary to what Mrs Swinburne said, it is not a call for unilateral deregulation. It is aimed at both double regulation and gaps, it aims at reducing unnecessary complexity, but not at unilateral deregulation, and should not be misunderstood in this way. The report rightly emphasises that we have not done enough in some areas, while in others we have not acted proportionately. This must play a role in the revision. It is also true that this financial system must be thought of from the user's intake. Hence the question: are financial products not far too expensive compared to what is generated in terms of income? Isn't too much going into the pockets of intermediaries and too little in savers' pockets? These questions are very legitimate and belong in a review. However, i would also like to say, in order to avoid misunderstandings, that I believe that there are two gaps in the report. Firstly, the financial crisis is not over, it is simply buried. If you look at interest rates at the long end, you see that we have too much capital in the market that doesn't know where to go. I agree with Fabio De Masi: this cannot be solved by turning a few scorisks in the financial sector, but by a policy that directs this surplus capital into sustainable investment. That is why I also ask you, and the report also calls on you to look at the macro-prudential side of the financial system and, in particular, to ensure that new risks do not arise from the fact that unsustainable investments in the bank and insurance balance sheets pose new future risks. The climate conference should also have arrived at DG FISMA, including you, Lord Hill. We look forward to hearing your suggestions and measures.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, John Maynard Keynes stated that if you owe a bank 100 pounds you have a problem, but if you owe the bank a million, they do. In the EU financial regulation crisis the banks were owed billions, but it was the taxpayers and citizens of Europe who had the problem. This report states that EU Financial Services regulations will prevent that happening again, but it also stresses the need to reduce the burden of financial regulation, because it recognises it increases costs and makes EU financial services businesses uncompetitive. But the idea that the EU will reduce regulation is as fanciful as the idea that Britain needs to be a member of the EU to trade with it, or indeed that Lord Hill will support a vote for Brexit. It is inherent in the EU’s DNA to create more regulation – more Europe – and more costs. That is why, increasingly, so many more UK and US financial services companies understand that, in order to be really free from the shackles of EU regulation, the UK needs to vote to leave the EU.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I regret that this report on the issues of financial regulation is ignoring a number of major issues. The first major issue is bank separation. I am talking about the real bank separation, a project that has been stalled since the 2008 crisis. Indeed, all regulatory regulations are futile if risk activities are not separated from bank deposit activities. In other words, it would be an end to the universal banking scheme that takes depositors and savers hostage to play speculative market roulette with other people's money. This is the ultraliberalism that patriots denounce: to make a profit with risk-taking on the backs of others. And here the EPP and the Socialists are in favour of the status quo in private banks. Worse, as the European Union is in a state of financial emergency, it not only does not protect citizens, but, since 1 January 2016, it has even done the opposite, with the disastrous banking union, which legalises the disposing of savings and then deposits. The last example in December: the banking scandal in Italy. It is the duty of responsible political leaders to protect household savings and corporate cash in banks and life insurance companies. The second major issue is the relaunch of securitisation. You should be concerned about the risks of a mechanism that caused social damage and financial losses during the 2008 subprime crisis. Watch out for Pandora's box. The aim is to lend to the productive economy and not to further promote the affairism of the banks.  Finally, on the union of capital markets, yes to the way out-of-bank economies are financed, but the chances of success are very small, in the absence of domestic demand in Europe and real economic opportunities in companies, underfunded European companies, which suffer too much from global unfair competition, charges and taxes to risk investing.  Beyond that, Lord Hill, I am very concerned that your European Commission is opening up the juicy debt market, mainly to Us banks based in the City of London. We will therefore be very attentive to the issues at stake in these issues.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – I would like to ask the European Commissioner here a question on this subject. This new regulation requires three things that are relevant to consumers. One is to inform consumers very thoroughly, the other is the responsibility of bank managers, bankers and the strength and determination of banking supervision. I ask you, Commissioner, whether you are aware that the most serious social problem in my country, Hungary, is not only in Hungary, but also in many other EU Member States, the tragedy of foreign currency creditors. The large crowds of so-called foreign currency loans. I ask you, where were those expectations then? Why are these new requirements so that the borrower must be properly informed that the banker has a responsibility to provide banking supervision? What is your position on this and what do you think the European Union could do for the hundreds of thousands of families with foreign currency loans who are in a tragic situation?

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate Mr Balz on the work he has done so that we can have this document that we are discussing here today, and I would also like to thank Jonathan Hill for his presence in this debate which should somehow help us guide the financial policies of the European Commission and the work of this Parliament for the coming months.  I believe that on the agenda we have two very important big projects: the banking union, which we have to finish and which we have to close with that deposit insurance; and capital union, which should somehow help improve that European capital market in the euro area, but also from countries outside the euro area, and help mobilize savings and mobilize capital in new investment projects.  And I think there are two great ideas that are on the table, two proposals that are in some debates and that make me too uncomfortable. The first is the idea that it is necessary to review that public debt is a risk-free asset. I believe that this initiative, in the absence of genuine risk-free assets in the euro area, could lead to the fragmentation of the euro area and take steps back on what we have achieved with the banking union and what we want to do with capital union. And the second issue that is somehow in the atmosphere is that we have gone too far in regulating the financial sector. I don't think this is true. What we have to do is regulate better, see where there are duplications, see how we can re-regulate the financial market, but we are a long way from supposed over-regulation.

name: Sander LOONES
text: – I want to focus on a theme that will become increasingly important in the coming months, namely our savings, our savings. If a bank gets into trouble now, our savings are protected up to 100 000 euros. The government is in a state of emergency today. In the future, however, the banks are expected to take on that responsibility, that they will pay for that protection. The question is: will these banks use our savings more wisely? Especially since we know what Europe's plans are.  Europe's plans are for all banks in the European Union to do this together from now on. Let us also make it clear what that means: that banks in the north of Europe will guarantee banks in the south, banks of Flanders for banks in Greece, banks that might go over the top.  So the question is: how can we prevent this from happening? I am therefore very pleased that, as shadow rapporteur for my group, I will be able to monitor this.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Madam President, by blaming the 2007 crisis on a supposed lack of regulation, we are making a mistake in the diagnosis. At the same time, we are creating an illusion, implying that the financial system can be disciplined. We are creating the illusion that it is possible to align the interests of banking and investment funds with the interests of people and workers. The single supervisory mechanism, as well as the single resolution mechanism, do not work and do not solve the problems of the financial system, as we have recently observed in Portugal, where information has been systematically hidden and manipulated with the consent of supervisors.  The problem of large financial institutions, said tobe too big to fail, is not solved with mere palliatives, which are only intended to try to give the idea that something is being done, staying all the same. The problem is solved by bank separation and public control of the financial system, as time will soon be in charge of giving us reason.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, firstly, I would like to offer my congratulations to the rapporteur on this report. I believe it strikes the right balance between improving channels of funding to the real economy and at the same time undertaking a comprehensive assessment of the cumulative impact of the EU Financial Services Regulation – identifying shortcomings and loopholes, but not deregulating. The ongoing crisis in China demonstrates the importance for us not to forget the lessons that we learned from the financial crisis and the need for a robust financial regulatory framework. It is important to keep this perspective. Also this initiative, the Capital Markets Union, is not going to be a panacea. It is not a miracle solution that will solve the level of growth. However, it can deliver alternative sources of finance to companies in the whole of the EU, and not just to the ones in the handful of Member States where we have developed capital markets. The challenge in front of you, Commissioner, is this: can we really speak about a financial services union, a place where capital can circulate freely, unhindered by extra layers of national legislation? Not really. It is critical that you address this, otherwise the EU investment funds will remain a drop in the ocean compared with the American ones. The Commission must tackle national fragmentation urgently. Alongside action on this, it is important that mid-caps are able to maximise their potential. Therefore, the prospectus proposal has to be a real gateway to the capital markets for this group. It has to be short, effective and affordable and, at the same time, an instrument that truly informs investors about securities.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Mr. President, I greet the Commissioner and congratulate the rapporteur on his excellent report. I welcome the efforts made to define measures to establish a Capital Markets Union. I expect these measures, in particular the development of the securitisation market and the revision of the Prospectus Directive, to meet the objective of easier access for SMEs to capital on the market.  It is important that our efforts to develop financial markets at European level contribute to further convergence in such a way that countries and their entrepreneurs with poorly developed capital markets can take full advantage of the enhanced European financial markets. Of course, we must not forget that at the same time Member States must do their job, which is to implement structural reforms aimed at improving the entrepreneurial climate, and the banking system must give stronger support to SMEs through an expanded choice of funding models.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I would very much like to support this report that has been presented to us, because, after a thorough study, I believe that it really reflects the real situation in which European financial services find themselves. I think this also reflects how different the situation is in the European Union and in the US. We really need to ensure access to finance, to investment, to ensure innovation for our industry, for our services, for our financial sector. Of course, it is essential that this policy that we want to implement is not only an instrument, but also target effects, that is, where to actually go in deregulation of markets. I quite contradict the idea put to me by one of my colleagues on the left side of the spectrum, who does not support deregulation of the markets and at the same time misses the fact that a decentralised banking system is not achieved. I think it goes hand in hand.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the issue of interbank and other transaction charges plays a key role for consumers, especially in Greece, where banks have often been recapitalised with the sweat of the Greek people and where capital controls are still in place. The increased charges imposed by banks on interbank transactions place an excessive burden on Greeks. Charges of between 2 and over 10 euros are charged for simple electronic money transfer for amounts up to 1000 euros, commissions from EUR 1 to EUR 1.25 for credit cards, commission to the bank of 2 to 2.5% for small and medium-sized shops, while in contrast for very large shops the commission is less than 1%, although Regulation (EU) 2015/751 provides, inter alia, for maximum charges for credit and debit cards of EUR 0.30 and EUR 0.20 respectively. At the same time, banks are taking too long to issue the necessary certificates and documents that borrowers with red loans had and still need in order to join the katselis law and to save their homes from the crows. These banking practices must stop and you, Commissioner, must take immediate action.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, the goal is well set. We want a Capital Markets Union. Well, the bruises are well placed, too. We want good consumer access to credit, we want more investment, we want to make it easier for medium and small businesses to access the financial services of all financial institutions in the European Union. So the goals and many other underglows, not just the ones I listed, are well placed.  But we have to learn from our mistakes, we have to learn from what the financial crisis caused and especially we have to learn from what banks have done to citizens in terms of classic financial fraud. Read: what banks have done to citizens who have taken out swiss franc loans in their time in many Countries of the European Union.  It's a classic scam, please take that into account and worry about it in the future.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – So, of course, the financial crisis has not yet been fully resolved, and the negative effects of this crisis have not yet been resolved. Perhaps the recovery indicators are encouraging somewhere, somewhere more, somewhere less, but we hear that these indicators are not directly reflected, both for the benefit of citizens, consumers and not investors, even small and medium-sized enterprises. I think that, of course, in what follows, that is also in financial or changes in the regulation of financial markets, and in the new legislative frameworks, of course, we must be careful, we must take into account the world's the world that we learned in the last crisis, because otherwise we will not take a step forward. Above all, the key question, of course, is who is following whom and to whom these measures will be targeted.  I think that, of course, when we talk about capital, when we talk about markets, we must not forget the man, the consumer, because, after all, we are here mainly because of them, and that is why I think we need to answer who these policies, whether banks or consumers or the real sector, are intended.

name: Nathan GILL
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Members very much for that wide range of interventions. If we concentrate on the report, I think a lot of the comments point to the unique position that the financial sector holds in Europe’s economy. As was said, it is a means to an end, and we should think of it as that and not an end in itself. We need a strong financial sector at the heart of Europe’s recovery – and indeed of our wider society – providing funding for businesses to grow and create jobs and to give citizens the certainty that they need to plan ahead to prepare for their old age and to protect against ill health. It is for that reason that, after introducing the range of legislation in response to the financial crisis, it is so important – as Mr Balz’s report makes clear – that we should check that it is working as intended. It is not to question the fundamental architecture of the reforms that we put in place, but it is to ask whether, in maintaining financial stability, we do not stand in the way of the investment Europe needs to remain competitive and to create jobs. In other words, as so often in financial regulation, it is a question of balance. As was said, we need to think about our competitiveness at a global level and, of course, how we can build consumer confidence in markets. The first stage of our call for evidence, which I think has been inspired by the thinking behind this report, ends in a fortnight. We are not approaching it with preconceptions but in the hope that it will give us detailed information – as many colleagues have said – to understand exactly how the legislation is working, what the connections are between it, whether there are overlaps or, indeed, whether there are any gaps that need to be addressed. I hope it will give us that detailed information on which we can build our analysis and recommendations. When we have got those, I look forward to discussing them with you and to continue working closely with Parliament to overcome these national barriers and obstacles that were raised here again tonight and to build a genuine single market for capital in Europe.

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to thank all my colleagues for the contributions they have made here this evening. They have been very helpful and have shown in detail what is important to each of us. After five years of intensive legislative work, the restructuring of the financial supervisory authority and the Capital Markets Union in prospect, it is now time to look at the impact so far and to examine possible improvements. I therefore welcome the fact that the Commission has already taken the first steps in the right direction, and I also welcome the ongoing consultation with financial market participants. It should be made clear that the consultation takes full account of the points in Parliament's report. I also see that the revision of the CRD IV Capital Requirements Directive offers great potential for simplification and greater proportionality, especially for smaller and medium-sized credit institutions. Progress is also certainly to be welcomed here. As The ECON, we are right to call for regular, at least annual proportionality checks. At the same time, however, I would also like to stress, Commissioner, that we and the impact study are not a single piecemeal piece, but, in the end, an overall picture. The puzzle of existing legislation must finally be brought together so that the interactions are clearer and the requirements are less complex and the objectives can be better achieved. To do this, we also need better regulation in financial market regulation. In particular, we are taking on the responsibility of the European Commission as the legislator of initiative, and here we are also taking on the responsibility of the European supervisory authorities and the ECB's banking supervision: coordination, transparency and cooperation in legislation must be improved. The technical requirements must remain proportionate and also practicable. Quality and compliance with the legislative will must once again take precedence. I am counting on you in particular, Commissioner Hill!

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow Tuesday, January 19, 2016. Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulation)

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. – Financial sector regulation and the Capital Markets Union is one of the priorities following the financial and debt crisis. I would like to congratulate my colleague Balzo, who has produced an excellent report which includes all the important points that we still have to discuss.  A successful Capital Markets Union, which should not restrict individuals and businesses, should be a priority. It must also give everyone access to THE EU's capital markets in a friendly, efficient and cost-accessible way. Legislation in the field of financial services must become less complex, and we must ensure that the Member States implement the legislation in full and rigorously.  We can no longer afford the various slips that put the most on the risk of small businesses and consumers in the long run. At the same time, I would also like to appeal to the Member States, which are key to the success of the models we are talking about. They are the ones that should ensure that directives are transposed within certain time limits. More importantly, member states apply the directives consistently.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. – Since the crisis began, we have undertaken numerous initiatives in the field of financial services in the European Union with the aim of restoring financial stability, strengthening consumer protection and applying lessons learned during the crisis. This report is a first step in assessing our legislative work, in order to assess the work done so far, but there are also challenges facing this legislature. It is time to look forward and one of our priorities must be the Capital Markets Union, which must be based on appropriate and effective legislation harmonising capital markets. The CMU should not be based on a greater legislative burden, but on the harmonization of existing legislation. Thanks to the CMU we will move forward with greater integration, as well as grouping and simplifying several ongoing initiatives; this will achieve greater coherence in financial services legislation.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. – The ancient Latins said that erring is human, but persevering (in error) is diabolical: this quote would suffice to sum up what is the Capital Markets Union, a dangerous continuation and worsening of the perverse characteristics and ideals that led us to the crisis in which we have been stuck for many years. Handing over the keys to the economy to finance is the most wrong thing i can imagine, and this is unfortunately precisely what the European Union wants to do through this project (of capital market union): at this point it must be admitted that there is a clear responsibility in all this on the part of the Union, and it is a malicious responsibility, because it is done with the knowledge that it wants to further destroy the already battered European economic fabric. Our businesses do not need sophisticated or risky financial instruments, but a secure, stable and effective credit system, as it was from the post-war period until the bursting of the financial bubble. The CMU is only of interest to those who want to speculate, apparently with the support and support of the European Union.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on barbara Matera's report, on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, on external factors representing obstacles to the entrepreneurship of European women (2015/2111(INI)) (A8-0369/2015)

name: Barbara MATERA
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are now at the final stage of a work that has seen me engaged for many months. The subject of women's entrepreneurship is extremely topical in a Europe that is struggling to recover from one of the most acute economic and financial crises in its history. I thank the shadow rapporteurs for their constructive spirit, which has accompanied the text at all stages. I have adopted a strategy that has involved the other political forces since the beginning of my report. We have managed to come up with a cross-cutting position that has not seen any divisions. We didn't need to have a shadow meeting. I would like to thank all of you, ladies and gentlemen, for the desire that has united us to make women protagonists of economic recovery. I have investigated, studied and researched the reasons for the external factors which represent obstacles to female entrepreneurship, which in the European Union stands at 30%. The process of women's emancipation, which over the centuries has seen women fight hard to achieve equal treatment, has not yet achieved its ultimate goal, equality in all areas. Among the major obstacles that we find and which have given rise to the need to draw up this report, we find social, economic and psychological reasons. Women are all too often victims of archaic stereotypes, which see them marginalised in second-hand roles and too little often in command. Women need to think about family, children and the elderly. As if motherhood were considered an obstacle and not the crowning achievement of one's life.  Despite the many directives that oblige people not to discriminate on the basis of gender in terms of access to services and equal treatment, women are often discriminated against when accessing credit. That is why I believe that we need to educate our young women in the spirit of enterprise, in the risk and also in the will for independence and to do business.  The text on which we will vote tomorrow focuses on 5 fundamental thematic areas: 1. Firstly, the main issue is the work-life balance, which is, unfortunately, one of the main obstacles that European women encounter when doing business. In this respect, I have proposed that there should be a real rationalisation of the possibility that European funds make available to provide care for the elderly and babysitting for children; 2. Secondly, in the second chapter, I am convinced that the exchange of good practices, networking and entrepreneurial education are important elements, hence the development of a European platform for female entrepreneurship; 3. The real barrier in Chapter 3 for women is access to credit and I am convinced that greater implementation of the Equal Access to Services Directive has become indispensable. Banks must treat everyone in the same way and not prefer male investment projects; 4. Penultimate chapter: I am convinced that an entrepreneurial culture must be instiled in the minds of our boys and therefore encourage girls and women to consider careers in the world of finance; 5. Last chapter, women must be inclined not only to work in the social sector but, as I said, also to open up to new technologies and also to the green economy. So, Mr President, the minutes available to me have ended, I invite all my fellow Members tomorrow to vote positively for this report, for a more inclusive Europe, and I will end with the words of Oriana Fallaci, an Italian writer who I really like, "Being a woman is very fascinating. It is an adventure that requires courage, a challenge that never bores". I ask all colleagues never to get bored like I do.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: – Firstly, I would like to congratulate Mrs Barbara Matera on her excellent report. This issue is very important, and I also care about helping women to do business. Not only because it has hidden potential for economic growth and development, but also because it can be an important tool for women's development, for female self-realisation. It is also important to encourage and support women in building entrepreneurship careers.  However, there are impediments, as the report has excellently said. One of these, for example, which should be of particular importance, is the creation of financing opportunities, better access to business opportunities. I support the development of the network because I think it is a good idea. It's a know-how that needs to be used.  A few words about social enterprises. Although these businesses are undoubtedly important, I do not believe that they should be the only means of female entrepreneurship and should be the only option for female entrepreneurs. Not only because you have asked, Congresswoman, but because the report is important, I support this, and I will confirm it tomorrow with my vote.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: – Mr President, addressing gender equality does not only involve efforts to promote equality as a principle, but requires the implementation of specific measures to promote multiple actions by the Member States to provide assistance and advice to women who decide to become entrepreneurs. To do this, women need facilities and simplified access to finance and other types of support, reducing red tape and removing other obstacles to newly established companies.  In this context, Member States should systematically examine measures and policies to promote an entrepreneurial culture in education and training programmes, raise women's awareness of opportunities for entrepreneurial training and ensure them equal opportunities for men in the field, as well as the opportunity to have a successful career; last but not least, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on her approach.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. President, we must encourage entrepreneurship and entrepreneurial mentality through both home education and the education system, among all ages and members of both sexes. Only in this way can the European economy expect future growth and stay at the top of the world. Entrepreneurship is somewhat less widespread among women than among men and therein lies huge potential. However, I cannot support any recommendations calling for dialogue between institutions to identify the best ways to implement work-life balance policies, as well as the equal distribution of family responsibilities. It's not the job of institutions or politicians. Family is the most intimate human sphere in which decisions must be made by a woman and a man in consultation with their children, not politics. The limit of political interference in citizens' lives must be known, and it has been crossed in this report.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Mrs Matera for the work she has done and I would like to say that entrepreneurship, self-employment, the activity of so-called autonomous women are another aspect of economic activity marked by inequality. Women consider these options less attractive than men, developing them in worse funding conditions and, in general, in lower value-added sectors. They must also overcome more problems of conciliation and personality, so that the female contribution in this field does not take advantage of all existing potentials and we lose talent and opportunities. That's why we need objective data to enable us to better diagnose, specific policies in education, funding, conciliation and guidance, address the most obvious problems, and continue to combat stereotypes. First, to think that inequality only harms women. And that is the first mistake, because with inequality, Commissioner, we all lose. I hope, therefore, that we will act accordingly.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Mr President, as a consequence of liberal policies, the painful reality shows that unemployment, poverty and inequality have female faces. In all these indicators, women appear systematically ahead of men. To try to combat this reality with this new and modern panacea of entrepreneurship is totally illusory – it aims to cure the disease with the agent responsible for the same disease. The problem of gender discrimination in employment is combating progressive legislation that promotes quality, stable and well-paid employment. We cannot promote precariousness, which generates female unemployment, and then come here to defend female entrepreneurship. If we want gender equality, we must create conditions for all women for full citizenship. This involves job security, combating all gender discrimination practices and quality public services that can ensure health and education for all children. Unfortunately, it is not the current course of European Union policy, but it will one day be the struggle of women and all workers.

name: Nathan GILL
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to start by thanking Ms Matera for the work that she has done with this report. As we have heard, and as we know, it is SMEs which will be the engine for job creation in Europe, and to unlock the full potential of our economy we need to unlock the creativity and entrepreneurial potential of our whole workforce of women and men – and yet we know that entrepreneurship is less popular among women than men. Sixty-three percent of women say that it has never crossed their mind to start a business, compared to 52% for men, and as we heard, among the key barriers that hinder women there are stereotypes, sometimes lack of confidence, and difficulties in accessing finance and business networks. That is why the role of education is so important and why it makes sense for Member States to include entrepreneurial learning at all levels of education. Studies show that women are different not only in the motivations that drive them into business but also in the way that they manage an enterprise. In particular, women take more calculated business risks than men, and usually, of course, such economic behaviour leads to a lower rate of failure and to more sustainable enterprises. Yet despite that, women find problems in getting hold of the financing that they need. One way forward could be specific programmes for investors to understand women’s entrepreneurship, and also the use of role models has been shown to produce great results, especially when it is linked to tailor-made mentoring and support services. To encourage women to enter the entrepreneurial world, the Commission has already taken a number of steps, such as the European Network of female entrepreneurship ambassadors and the creation of a network of mentors. But we want to do more, so this year we will launch an online platform for women of all ages who want to start, run and grow a business. The platform will provide training, mentoring, advice and business networking opportunities for women. It is meant to be a one-stop shop for female entrepreneurs. It will enable them to get in touch with other organisations, to enter into existing networks and to find information on funding. Thanks to a pilot project from Parliament, we also want to increase access to alternative sources of funding by creating a network of women business angels. In addition, as we have heard, women can play an important role in social entrepreneurship, and the Commission, via its expert group on social entrepreneurship, is working with interested parties to improve the situation of social enterprises in Europe. Finally we all know that, to support female entrepreneurs, we need to create an environment within which they can make the most of their potential. That is why we work together with Member States to ensure that issues like childcare and facilities for care of the elderly are addressed across Europe. Europe needs all of its talent, and I can assure you that the Commission will continue to work hard to promote and support female entrepreneurship and that this report from Parliament will help guide us in that task.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow Tuesday, January 19, 2016. Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulation)

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – To restore growth and achieve a high level of employment, the EU needs more entrepreneurs and, above all, more entrepreneurs, because the differences between men and women are huge: women account for only 31% of all employed people in the EU. The two main obstacles faced by women entrepreneurs are the difficulty of reconciling family and work life and the problems of access to finance, which in some cases involve gender discrimination and often follow sexist stereotypes that regard leadership as an exclusively male quality. Once again we must emphasize the importance of more and better conciliation policies that facilitate the incorporation of women into the world of work. It is also essential that access to finance is facilitated and simplified. It is also necessary to create European networks for women entrepreneurs, exchange best practices and promote an entrepreneurial culture in education and training that combats sexist stereotypes and encourages women to choose careers in the field of science, new technologies and finance.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. – A lot of activities have been undertaken with the aim of strengthening female entrepreneurship, reducing unemployment and self-employment, but they have not proved effective and we cannot be satisfied with what has been achieved because women's employment remains below 60%, far from the 75% target. Of the total number of self-employed in the EU, only 34.4% are women and their income remains lower than men. With the same measures, we cannot come up with new solutions. One-off financial support and relief is not enough, but long-term social support and support is necessary so that women can build a career in entrepreneurship and balance private and business life. Ensuring quality childcare and the education system are essential for this, and it is also important for women to have easier access to financial resources and the realisation of business ideas.  I supported Barbara Matera's report, which seeks a new, holistic, approach to fostering women's entrepreneurship. It is important to swiftly adopt concrete measures and an appropriate legislative framework that will result in an increase in the share of women on the market as well as the effective use of appropriate instruments and incentives, including EU funds, to provide quality care for children and other dependers, flexible working hours, full protection of social rights and measures to achieve real balance and equality in the coordination of family and business obligations.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. – Female entrepreneurship in EU Member States is characterised by fairly low rates compared to entrepreneurship in men. Recently, the self-employment rates of women in Europe were only 31%, while the part-time rates of women were 30% compared to 10% of men. In countries affected by mercelian austerity, such as Greece, the unemployment rate for women in the first quarter of 2015 reached 30.6% compared to 23.5% for men, with women paid 16% lower wages than men. In addition, the new anti-insurance bill promoted by the troika closes all prospects for women's entrepreneurship since women self-employed people will have more than 80% of their annual income for insurance contributions and taxes. So thousands of women took to the streets to protest against the troika. In addition, rural women take the baton after insurance and tax break up agricultural production, wipe out agricultural income, exclude rural women from the labour market and reduce their pensions.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. – Today we discussed the obstacles to women's entrepreneurship. While this is an interesting topic, I do not consider it to be crucial. The situation of women, who are most at risk of poverty, have greater problems in the labour market than men, and the problem of combining personal, family and professional life are certainly more pressing problems that women "burn" much more than the question of the possibility of their business. I am sceptical about the content of this report from the outset, as I do not think it represents any solution to the problems outlined. Nor do I think that the solution to strengthening women's rights should be their increased involvement in private entrepreneurship. I don't think that's the answer.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Concrete strategies must be put in place at the national and regional level to encourage women's entrepreneurial culture. I am concerned about the unusually low rate of entrepreneurship among women: in 2012 women accounted for just 31% of entrepreneurs (10.3 million) in the EU-28 and female entrepreneurship was more likely to focus on sectors considered less profitable.  In this context, I call on the Commission and the Member States to remove barriers to female entrepreneurship, whether social or economic; and I call on the Commission to propose, before the end of 2016, concrete measures (including legislative proposals) to increase women's participation in the labour market through improved work-life balance.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. – Gender equality is one of the important principles of a modern democratic society. It enables women and men to participate equally in all areas of public and private life.  As in recent years, we are introducing a gender balance in the field of political engagement, so we also need gender balance in the economic field. A number of research in this field shows that gender-balanced boards achieve better results with significantly more comprehensive decisions, taking into account the wishes and expectations of both the female and male populations.  I welcome the report calling on the Commission to ensure full mainstreaming of gender mainstreaming in all future policies in the field of entrepreneurship.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Marek Plura, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on competition policies to combat youth unemployment (2015/2088(INI)) (A8-0366/2015)

name: Marek PLURA
text: Rapporteur. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by At the outset, I would like to express my sincere thanks to all the shadow rapporteurs for their excellent cooperation, their contribution to the report presented and their full commitment to work on the compromise amendments.  I thank Professor Krasnodębek for preparing a balanced opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education, as well as all the colleagues who tabled amendments. Your comments have contributed to the development and completion of this report.  A key element of the report on skills acquisition strategies to combat youth unemployment is to highlight the importance of better preparing graduates for labour market requirements. There is a need for a real partnership between the education sector and business, as well as for young people themselves to be involved in all measures to improve their situation on the labour market. There are good practices in this area, but they need to be disseminated.  My report also highlights the role of small and medium-sized enterprises in creating new jobs and the fundamental importance of educating entrepreneurial skills from an early age and promoting entrepreneurship. In addition, the report highlights the role of key skills, including those related to new technologies, and the importance of combining theoretical education with traineeships and traineeships. The report also stresses the importance of greater flexibility in education and lifelong learning systems and of removing barriers to education completion and re-certification. It draws attention to the under-util exploitation of skills training opportunities in the workplace. Another important aspect is equal opportunities by supporting young people from disadvantaged groups, including families affected by poverty, expatriates and young people with disabilities, to acquire the right professional and social skills and to make full use of their own opportunities.  Finally, I drew attention to the fact that the potential, talents and values and priorities of young people brought up in an era of rapid technological progress are very different from those of the previous generation. In my opinion, this is one of the reasons why the potential of the younger generation is still not fully understood and exploited. Therefore, it is worth investing in programmes that make it easier for employers and employment services to better understand the qualities, opportunities and potentials of the younger generation.  Tomorrow we will vote on this report. I am convinced that our joint work will contribute to better targeting measures to support young people's chances in the labour market, and that the report's conclusions will inspire further work. Today, the dramatic level of youth unemployment is one of the most serious threats to Europe's social and economic future.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: – Whenever we talk about youth unemployment, we hear the same thing: young people have to do "this" or young people have to do "that". The truth is, young people don't need any more advice. They need strong support and willpower.  I believe that the European Union is narrow for talented young entrepreneurs. Erasmus for Entrepreneurs must therefore work at European level at global level. Erasmus for Entrepreneurs must become a global programme. Only then will those born in Bulgaria, Croatia or Germany be competitive with those in America or Russia, Brazil or China. Advertising for youth programs should be done in the language of young people and where they are: on social media, on YouTube, Facebook or Tweeter, not on dusty boards at labour offices. I hear all the time that we, my generation, are a lost generation. It's not true, and stop repeating it, because young people are the backbone of our "tomorrow," a spine, not a tail.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Mr President, youth unemployment across Europe is a long-term time bomb, damaging individuals and society for years to come. Eradicating youth unemployment should be at the heart of our economic and industrial policies, and there is no excuse for sacrificing our young people. My home region, the North-East of England, has some of the highest youth unemployment figures in the UK, and as a result we qualify for extra funds from the EU Youth Employment Initiative. EU funds and the ideas in this report can support falling youth unemployment by creating opportunities for our young people, and certainly training, good apprenticeships and investment in education are crucial. But we should avoid demonising our young. It is a lack of decent jobs which needs to be addressed. For many more young people, it is not skills but breaking the cycle of precarious temporary jobs that is needed. Youth employment measures should create good jobs. Low pay, exploitation and zero hours contracts are creating a new social time bomb. We must act to deactivate it if we want to activate our young for the future.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, since the Troika began to implement the Memorandum policies, the rate of total unemployment and youth unemployment in Greece has become the highest in the European Union. Also, recent OECD reports put Greece at the top of the world in the world in the jobless rate of graduates with 19.4%, while the country is on the list of the world's ten smartest in terms of the number of graduates in the fields of technology and science. Unsurprisingly, this situation is pushing thousands of young people to seek work abroad, particularly in the countries of lenders such as Germany, which find a cheap and highly skilled workforce without having spent a single euro on their education. These unprecedented phenomena of colonial brain drain will only be combated by the abolition of the memorandums that put the economies of the European region hostage by the lenders after absorbing their main source of wealth, namely their people.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, I want to emphasize from this report the part that speaks to the need to partnership the education system and the economy. There is talk of industry, and what I want to give special emphasis to is certainly tourism, where young people can be hired very easily or much more easily even with small qualifications. Of course, the issue of employment in small and medium-sized entrepreneurship is particularly attractive.  However, what I wanted to take my word for was precisely to emphasize two possible elements. The first is self-employment of young people. I think that's where we should do everything we can to encourage young people to self-employment and thus to have one kind of responsibility in our lives. Another issue is microfinance, i.e. the possibility of financing young people and entrepreneurial projects for young people with small loans. I think those are two elements that can get into this report and contribute to youth employment.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, everyone is in sight of unemployment rates of around 30 % or even higher, what young people can expect from this European Union. The Policies and Impositions of the European Union, particularly in recent years, in the troika-intervened countries, have condemned young people to unemployment, precariousness and forced emigration.  The policies of labor deregulation, low wages, the de-responsibility of the State for employment policies, the commodification of education, with the increase in its frequency costs, and the prevalence of said acquisition of skills and market orientation to the detriment of the integral training of the individual: all this contributes to the dramatic situation experienced today by millions of young workers.  So do not sell false solutions, such as entrepreneurship, this new bath of the snake of neoliberalism, or so-called mobility, another name for forced emigration. The solution is to break with these policies, break with those who impose them. This depends on the present and the future of young people.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – It is therefore an issue that has been a difficult issue for Europe for many years before the crisis, between the crisis itself and also in the current time.  In the last year and a half of this parliament's composition, we have spoken a lot about young people's difficulties in employment, and the facts speak for themselves: a lot of young people are unemployed all over Europe, the European Commission is working on its own programmes, it is deo-determining certain resources, but all of this is clearly not enough.  Because, of course, it is not enough just to give resources, but to put them in quality, permanent jobs.  Unfortunately, too few young people are involved in these processes of creating programmes to reduce unemployment and, of course, what colleagues have said before is precarity, dependent jobs, in some countries there is a precarity rate between 15th and 25th year of young people over 40, 50, 60%, and this creates insecurity for young people in creating a family, providing housing and, of course, certain entrepreneurial initiatives.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: – Mr President, youth unemployment in Europe has reached scandalous levels, and this has two main causes. One is the European single currency, and the other is over-regulation on business. Britain is not in the euro, but we do get the over-regulation. We also get large numbers of EU migrant workers fleeing their own floundering economies. Recently I had a conversation with a young Englishman in London. He was doing low—paid casual work on building sites. He told me that he was told to take a pay cut or he would be replaced by a cheaper Eastern European. Those at the bottom end of the economic scale cannot compete with cheap labour that will work for next to nothing per hour and live many to a house. Britain’s young people should defend their future by voting to leave the European Union in the coming referendum.

name: Nathan GILL
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to start by thanking Mr Plura for his report. As we have heard, youth unemployment is obviously one of the biggest challenges that we face in Europe, and if we are going to fight it effectively, we clearly need to get better at matching young people’s skills to what employers need. The Commission agrees that better cooperation – better partnership, as was said – between businesses, between education and training providers and local authorities, could help make skills training more relevant to what employers actually need. And with that in mind, increasing apprenticeships and workplace training is key. High-quality traineeships can help smooth the transition from education to employment, and we need to find ways that, for skills acquired outside traditional education, for example through volunteering or on-line learning, can themselves be better recognised. The youth guarantee remains a priority for the Commission, and the Commission will report on its implementation in October, and this will include an assessment of how well Member States have met the requirements of a quality framework for traineeships. To help Member States speed up the fight against youth unemployment, the Commission has proposed to increase the pre-financing for the Youth Employment Initiative from 1%-15% to 30%, and this was quickly accepted by the Council and Parliament and represents an advance payment to Member States of around EUR 1 billion. Other concerns set out in the report include the importance of promoting equal opportunities, of entrepreneurship and flexibility in education and training provision. These are all areas and concerns that the Commission shares, and work here is in progress. Last year we set priorities to improve cooperation on vocational education and training, and in the education and training 2020 framework. In November the Commission launched a cooperation initiative with businesses and other interested parties on a pact for youth. With business help, over the next two years this pact will deliver 10 000 business education partnerships and 100 000 new opportunities for young people: entry-level jobs, good quality apprenticeships and traineeship opportunities. And this comes on top of what has been achieved through the European Alliance for Apprenticeships that in June led to employers promising an additional 140 000 apprenticeships. The Commission is working on a new skills agenda for Europe that my colleague intends to publish this year. We want this agenda to include tangible actions to improve the relevance of education and training across Europe, and your report will be a great help to frame our work in this area.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, January 19, 2016. Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulation)

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Currently, more than 7 million young people aged 15 to 24 are not working, studying or training. For many of them, victims of the banking and liberal crisis, the lack of skills is a structural obstacle to access to sustainable employment that will enable them to lead a life project. Extremely involved in this struggle for jobs for Farciennes, I see every day the human consequences that this can engender. I have therefore supported this report, which stresses that the development of individual skills and the dissemination of knowledge and skills are one of the elements of integrated social and employment policies. It is clear that schools, training organizations and, of course, businesses must make this fight for employment a priority. But the overall socio-economic context is also essential. The Commission has launched Operation Youth Guarantee, it is worth noting. But it cannot take back with one hand what it gives with the other and must engage in a genuine policy of recovery based on investment that will reduce unemployment and poverty and finally give millions of young Europeans prospects for the future.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. – In addition to migration, the alarmingly high youth unemployment is currently one of the EU's Hungary problems (higher than the EU average (22%) 1.5%), affecting around 5 million young people. At the same time, there are 2 million vacancies in Europe. This situation poses a serious risk to social cohesion and economic development in the EU. The aim of the report adopted today is to provide the European Union with an even more effective response so that these five million young people can find jobs as soon as possible. The report urges Member States to implement urgent structural reforms in the field of education in order to facilitate the transition from school to labour market.  Changes in the labour market require more flexible education systems that enable knowledge and skills to be complemented and developed at all stages of a professional career. It is important to acquire general, basic competences and transversal skills and abilities, such as information and communication technology, mathematics, critical thinking, knowledge of foreign languages, mobility, teamwork skills, communication that allow young people to adapt more quickly in a changing social and economic environment.  I believe that, in today's Europe, there is a great need for an approach that supports young people, for example in terms of their creativity, risk-taking capacity, failure management and responsible behaviour. At present, education organisation in Europe needs an approach that supports young people's creativity, risk-taking and failure-management skills and responsible behaviour.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: in writing. – I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Plura, for his excellent report. The report focuses on key issues that seek to improve skills policies in Europe with a view to fighting youth unemployment. Youth are affected by unemployment more than any other age group – approximately 7.5 million young Europeans are currently neither in employment nor in training. To reduce youth unemployment, several actions should be taken.  First, we need to build stronger partnerships between authorities, educational institutions and businesses to better forecast future skills needs. Second, a new impetus should be given to STEM skills and vocational education. Best practices should be exchanged between Member States. Third, young people’s employability can be further improved by adopting new teaching and training methods. Schools should put more focus on soft skills to prepare youngsters for real ‘work-life’. Also, entrepreneurship education should be fostered from an early age. Last but not least, it should be the young people themselves who take their future in their hands. The biggest skill that a young man or a woman can have is the sense of initiative and self-responsibility. Only like this can we really strive for the dreams we all have!

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – One of the most important problems of the European Union for many years has been the huge unemployment of young people. The current problems have been explained by the fact that more than 4.5 million people aged 15-24 are out of work and in some Member States the unemployment rate in this age group is approaching 50%. Given the current refugee crisis, it should be assumed that the problem of youth unemployment is likely to increase. If we want to avoid the build-up of problems and a kind of ghettoisation, member states' education and training systems need to adapt very quickly to this situation. On the other hand, we should also bear in mind that young Citizens of the Union will gain new competition on the labour market and will require even stronger support. Therefore, the coming years will certainly be a huge challenge for both education systems and public employment services.  In order to combat youth unemployment, the focus must be on three pillars: formal education, career guidance and lifelong learning programmes. Only by effectively combining these three systems and adapting them to europe's situation will help us, on the one hand, to reduce unemployment among young Europeans and, on the other hand, to effectively integrate and integrate hundreds of thousands of young refugees into the labour market.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – The European Union and the Member States must understand that the solution to combating youth unemployment is to work with young people. To do this, the mechanisms by which they are supported must be created to pursue their desired career. Too often we got stuck in templates and didn't adapt to structural changes. We need to start innovating. We need more than a programme, we need a coherent strategy that involves young people in particular. As a young Mep, I can say on behalf of my generation that we want more from the EU. We don't just want a job, we want decent jobs. We don't want to be a statistic in the budgets of big companies that benefit from tax deductions. The 7.5 million unemployed Young Europeans are in this situation because our states and the EU have forgotten to protect their citizens. I believe that education and training are the solution, but we need more than that, we need to give real hope to young people. Unfortunately, I do not think that, by what it has done, the European Commission has achieved this.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: Written. – Youth unemployment in the EU has fallen over the past year. However, 4.5 million young people are still without a job or a place to study. It's too much. In Spain, almost half of young people are unemployed. In Germany, the corresponding figure is 7%. Such large differences are not explained solely by the economic situation of the countries.  We must therefore find out why certain Member States are more successful in mobilising young people and share this information among the Member States.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Writing. Combating the still alarmingly high level of youth unemployment in some European Member States is and remains a priority for us Socialists and Democrats. We must not risk losing an entire generation. The correct implementation and further strengthening of the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative is a first step. Training and training must be adapted to the new challenges of the labour market. Companies, trade unions and youth organisations must be involved in the design of the programmes.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - Youth unemployment remains one of the European Union's biggest problems. Youth entrepreneurship has progressed, but we still need to work to strengthen it and reduce administrative barriers. Market trends are changing rapidly and must be followed by an education policy that needs to respond adequately to change and organise educational programmes according to market needs and align with technological advances.  Youth entrepreneurship should, above all, be encouraged and supported through various support schemes, from the promotion of self-employment to financial support. Young people are entering the labour market late and great efforts are needed to reduce the unemployment rate. On several occasions, I have sought the Commission's help in tackling this problem, as young people are the new strength the Union needs, so we should do our best to enable young people to integrate into the labour market as easily, better and faster as possible.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – Young Europeans still need our help. 7.5 million. This is the figure that demonstrates, without a doubt, that the problem of youth unemployment is far from solved. These young people do not have a waiting horizon in the European Union. 7.5 million young people between the ages of 15 and 24 are not included in any form of education and have no occupation whatsoever. The solutions have been in place and implemented for years and yet we do not see a sufficient improvement in the situation of young people.  The message of the resolution is correct and the debate welcome. We need to invest more now, not next year or in the next period, now, in educational programmes for young people, in programmes that develop the entrepreneurial spirit of young people, in retraining programmes.  We need to turn our attention to the age groups over 24. By the age of 30 at least, young Europeans need guidance and support. We must remain constantly connected to the evolution of youth unemployment, because we see, including from the reports submitted by the European Commission, that there are enough situations where European resources have not produced the expected result.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. – The EU directly confronts youth unemployment in two ways: financial assistance and policies to acquire the necessary skills. This Parliament has already adopted many financial frameworks that facilitate the position of young people in employment. It is not only the Youth Guarantee scheme, but also many other projects, including those in the field of education and training, which are now coming together under Erasmus+, which I follow as the EP's permanent rapporteur. In addition to financial assistance, we are working to improve the employability of young people in the EU by modernising and adapting education. My colleague Plure's report calls for partnerships between educational institutions and businesses. The report underlines the important issues we have been talking about in the EP for many years: better response of education systems to the needs of the labour market, the importance of STEM skills, the importance of quality vocational training and the importance of effective absorption of European funds by the Member States. It also mentions helping young people set up their own businesses. The self-employment of young people has a particular value.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item is one-minute interventions on matters of political importance (Article 163 of the Regulation).

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: On New Year's Eve, a few hundred migrants mingled among the celebratory in public spaces in several cities in Germany attacked, sexually molested and looted other EU citizens. So it was an organized operation. For days, the police, and especially liberal news outlets and media outlets, have been hiding the fact of the insult and trying to hide who the perpetrators really are. Such and similar acts cannot be tolerated in Europe. Our rules and laws apply equally to everyone. The existence of the rule of law is our common European value. Whether you are a migrant or a European, non-compliance with the law has serious legal consequences. The responsibility of the perpetrators should not be called into question for a moment, and it is also necessary to examine whether law enforcement measures could have prevented crimes. Why were the police on the ground unable to control the situation or, under pressure from the media, dared not prevent migrants from committing the crimes. Don't be taboo, and we shouldn't be blind.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: – Mr President, romanian public opinion, as well as the Romanian press, have repeatedly expressed concern in recent months about the fate of the Bodnariu family, whose children were taken from their parents by the specialised protection services in Norway.  The reasons for the decision of the Norwegian authorities are unclear. To date, there is no official information on the motivation for this action. The lack of information comes from the lack of transparency of the Norwegian authorities, which do not provide the data requested either to the press or to the Bodnariu family. Although Norway is not a Member State of the Union, Marius Bodnariu, the father of the children, is a citizen of the European Union, and I believe it is important that he and his family are protected from European rules and institutions, beyond the efforts made by the Romanian authorities.  I also call on my fellow EURO Members to support our requests for direct involvement of the representatives of the European institutions in clarifying this situation for the benefit of the five children of the Bodnariu family.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Mr President, two EU institutions decided to put Poland under scrutiny for breaching EU principles. Internal rules were used as legal background instead of the sound EU primary and secondary law. This procedural double fault seems very repressive as well as applying double standards vis-à-vis various EU Member States and their respective nations, as well as vis-à-vis different cabinets of Poland in dealing with the same issues.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, the installation of razor wire on the border line between Croatia and Slovenia has caused great outrage among the citizens of Croatia and Slovenia. Unreasonable politics is opposed to friendship and a good neighborhood, opposed to playing volleyball over that razor wire. The wire is placed where no one has ever crossed the border and where no immigrants can be expected: in Istria and on Kupa and gorski kotar. It is a provocation, it is an irresponsible policy against Europe, against Croatia and against Slovenia.  Today, quite the opposite of expected, this same razor wire has turned into a great danger to the life and safety of the inhabitants of the border regions of Slovenia and Croatia. That is why I am asking the European Commission to urgently ask the Republic of Slovenia to move this dangerous razor wire, dangerous for the citizens of Slovenia and Croatia, and I ask the Slovenian government to come to its senses and finally start moving this razor wire on its own, because it directly endangers the safety of citizens and the nature of Croatia and Slovenia.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, still under the cover of the dense propaganda surrounding the so-called banking union, this is another banking scandal – that of Banif – in Portugal, revealing the intrinsic capacity of the banking regulation and supervision system, concepts which, as is well in sight, are nothing more than a busted scam. In what is a genuine economic crime, after €1 billion of public funds poured into Banif in 2013, now, in practice, the Portuguese is financing at least €2.5 billion from a large foreign bank to acquire Banif and thus strengthen its presence on the domestic market.  The State functions as a depositary of losses and cleaning agent to deliver the risk-free and loss-free bank to Grupo Santander, when it could and should take public control of Banif, ensuring its management at the service of national interests. It is important to fully clarify and to ascertain the european Commission's responsibilities in this process to the last consequences. To this end, we have already come forward with a written question to the European Commission, which we hope can be answered quickly.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: – Mr President, the Volkswagen company's fraud in cheating hundreds of thousands of vehicles to distort its pollution rates is probably the largest in the history of the European Union. It's a monstrous attack on the environment and public health. It's a scam for buyers, who thought they bought a model vehicle. And it's a big scam against public administrations. In the Spanish state alone, fifty thousand of these raced cars were sold and, as they were supposed to be clean vehicles, they were exempted from various taxes. The amount lost by management has not yet been determined, but will be multimillion-dollar. Volkswagen has received, for its two plants in Navarra and Catalonia, three hundred million euros of direct public aid. Money from citizens, who suffer cuts in fundamental services, for a scamming company. This Parliament's committee of inquiry must go all the way to the last consequences and demand responsibility. We are not worth apologising, because our credibility with the public is at stake.

name: Petr MACH
text: – Mr President, when the Czech Republic entered the European Union, many of my fellow citizens believe that membership of the European Union will reduce corruption, that it will consolidate democracy in our country, that it will bring prosperity. Now everyone needs to see that this false dream is totally falling apart.  Everyone in the Czech Republic sees that European funds have only increased corruption. The vote against the Czech Republic on migration quotas showed the true undemocratic nature of the European Union and showed the complete detachment of the European Commission from what ordinary people in the Czech Republic think. Moreover, we can now see that the quota decision is not working either. The European Parliament has been completely left out of this, that it is urgent, and yet the European Commission has not been able to do anything and it is only a good thing. Most citizens in the UK seem to want to speak now, and I am not surprised at all.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thousands of signatures are being collected in Italy following the scandal of the bankruptcy of four local banks at the bottom of a petition addressed to the European Parliament. I would like to draw the attention of the President of the European Parliament to the need to urge the Italian Government to compensate the victims of this, which is in fact a scam, because these bondholders who have invested all their savings, starting with a tragic figure, that of the saver Luigino D'Angelo, who has even taken his own life in the face of this tragic situation. Thousands of small savers have to be compensated 100%, because they have been scammed, because they have been sold securities that were guaranteed, they were sold by bank staff claiming that they were safe securities and hiding the reality that is emerging; among other things of this Banca Etruria, behind which hide really un cleaner characters.
