I strongly recommend that the President consider this petition which is coming and which is also made in memory of this victim, the first victim of bail in, Mr Luigino D'Angelo and also a thought for his family.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). Mr President, the SYRIZA/ANEL government in Greece, having undertaken the dirty work of implementing memorandums and EU Treaties, now meets the capital requirement for further demolition of social security, relieves employers and the state of their responsibility and offers cheaper labour, billions in savings and capital support. No one escapes – old and young workers and pensioners, farmers, the self-employed, women and young people in particular who, due to a wandering between unemployment and flexible working relationships, will be content, like the vast majority, with a pension–hunger allowance at an old age. Citing the viability of the empty insurance funds that all governments have stolen to support businesses, it sends new customers to private insurers and, with the Solvency II Directive, strengthens them with funds to once again cut off insurance reserves in business investments and stock exchanges. The government is seeking, as for its memorandum, democratic legitimacy of its crime by the European Parliament, bringing to light its own reactionary role. The people deny their slaughter by the government, organize and fight with demonstrations and general strikes to keep the anti-insurance abomination from reaching the Parliament.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: – Tax policy significantly affects the environment for job creation and I believe that preserving tax sovereignty and tax competition within the Union is the right solution. But we can do much more in standardization. I am thinking in particular of the introduction of uniform registration of value added tax. Such an arrangement would help not only the development of e-commerce, but especially small entrepreneurs who employ the most people. It is also our duty to help them at European level. The best way is to simplify administration, the same rules and make consistent use of the common European market. I believe that the single registration of value added tax, as well as the facilitation of the creation of a new company for one euro via the Internet throughout the European market, will help those who need it most, namely small entrepreneurs, those who set up new firms and, consequently, the citizens for whom they create the most jobs.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, in my country, family is very important and, traditionally, children and parents remain a close-knit family even after children have their own family. A recent study in the UK shows that the country where children are happiest is Romania, with Norway ranking 6th.  The case of the Bodnariu family - and other families, not only its own - went around the world because of the way the Norwegian authorities understood to take the children out of the Bodnariu family and the other families. The parents did not receive any warning and the supervision procedure was not followed without first removing the children from the family.  The rights of the child are regulated in detail in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. The best interests of the child must take precedence in all actions relating to children. Romania and Norway are signatory states to the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and these rights must be respected.  I wonder: what do we do to defend our European citizens living outside the European Union? I want to ask: can we be a united Europe? Can the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Commissioner on these matters intervene to make the whole family? I'm a mother and I can't accept that children can be loved more than natural parents, whoever the authorities are.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: – Mr President, tomorrow, Tuesday 19 January, the trial against photojournalist Raúl Capín begins in Madrid. The DA asks for two years in prison for him. Clearly we are facing persecution, a criminalization that is part of a strategy that is being followed by the Spanish state against media and journalists who are critical.  The same repression that social activists and trade unionists are experiencing; it is an attack on the right to information and press freedom that adds to the attacks on freedom of manifestation and expression that we are experiencing, with the "gag law" as the greatest exponent.  Raúl Capín is tried because, with his photos, he has highlighted the police repression that has been experienced in the Spanish state in recent years. A brutal crackdown that has tried to silence protests and demonstrations against unjust and cruel policies. Raúl Capín is judged because she has posted photos like these (she shows several photos). Because reporting is not a crime, because without photographers you do not see it, we demand an end to repression and the end also of the persecution of those who denounce this repression.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – Of course, I must respond to mr Jakovčić's words. I am, of course, not a fan of the wire fences on the borders, and I have also looked at the Kolpa Valley and seen the damage this fence does to the locals, of course, the animal population, and what consequences it will have for the future. However, Slovenia did not, of course, set up this fence for some particular pleasure, but was also forced into this because of an ineffective common European policy for securing so-called external borders. And, of course, I would point out that this will, of course, be a domino effect, and as we have heard from the future Croatian Foreign Minister, if this can, of course, continue then in Croatia and further throughout the Balkan route. But, of course, I would like to say that where, of course, there is no real danger to these migrant routes, there is, of course, better not, at least temporarily.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: – Mr President, I have had much constituent correspondence about the proposed Firearms Directive amendment, most notably from the Imperial War Museum, the National Army Museum and the Royal Armouries. The proposed amendment would require museums to deactivate or destroy their historical collections, and it would prevent them making further acquisitions. This amendment is a panic reaction to the Paris massacre. How many criminal and terrorist acts have been carried out using antique weapons, we may ask? None, I would guess. These museums asked for an exemption, but any exemption should equally apply to all collectors of antique weapons. UKIP MEPs will certainly support that. This is just the latest example of my constituents’ legitimate interests being damaged by ill-considered and unnecessary legislation. If they do not like it, then I advise them to take up arms – metaphorically, of course – and campaign to leave the European Union in the coming referendum.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, the Brussels Commission has launched an investigation against several French farmers' unions, including the National Federation of Farmers' Trade Unions (FNSEA). It suspects them of violating Article 101 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which prohibits distorting competition. They may be hit by very heavy fines. This Commission initiative is an outlier on the economic front and scandalous on a human level. In France, thousands of milk producers and farmers are dying because of catastrophic EU decisions: the end of milk quotas, the Russian embargo or the creation of low-cost seconded workers, which German slaughterhouses have massively recruited. Last summer, their unions obtained emergency measures from the French state that allowed many breeders to hold on. It is unacceptable for the Commission to grieve them today. Like the monarchy under the Old Regime, the European Union will be swept away by the wrath of the French people. In Brittany, the revolt has already begun with the "pink hats". "A revolt? No, sire, a revolution."

name: Claude ROLIN
text: Mr President, the President of the Commission here has denounced the existence of a 29th State: that of those who are unemployed. We cannot accept this reality. We cannot allow more than seven million young people to be unemployed and not in education or training. We cannot accept that more than 10% of young people leave school early. There are systems that facilitate the transition from school to employment. These systems have worked and are working in some Member States. This is alternating training. It is unanimous, including at the level of the social partners. Erasmus is also a real success story in terms of training and mobility. This programme is a veritable incubator of Europeans for the future. Let us build on this success to meet the challenge of youth employment, by launching a genuine European system of alternation, by setting up a European framework for the mobility of apprentices. When solutions exist, we have a duty to implement them.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: – Mr President, more than 1660 children were taken from their parents in Norway in 2014. Between 3 and 4 children per day are separated from their parents on the grounds of ill-treatment. How many of them are children of the European Union?  I bring before you a case that expresses the problem of the Norwegian child protection system. The Bodnariu family lost their five children on insufficiently reasoned and subjective grounds, invoked by Barnevernet. Without a court decision, without decision-making transparency and without respecting the presumption of innocence of the parents, the five children are abducted from the family. The case is not an isolated one. It is an example of an abusive modus operandi used by the Norwegian authorities.  I use this minute to demand the involvement of the European Parliament, the European Commission, all the European institutions and each individual colleague in support of the fundamental rights of the European family. The European citizenship of all immigrants who go through such situations demands our attention. The European Union has a duty to protect its citizens from any form of abuse.

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, the legitimacy of the European Union to act as honest brokers in the Middle East peace process has again been brought into question. I was struck by a recent Israeli press article about a prominent NGO, B’Tselem, that campaigns, supposedly, on behalf of Palestinians. It reported that B’Tselem had set up a fake land agency, trapping Palestinians wanting to sell their land to Israelis. They were then reported to Palestinian security services, well knowing that they would likely be killed. That this NGO behaves in such a manner is reprehensible. That this NGO receives EU funding is unforgivable. Last month B’Tselem received EUR 30 000 from the European Endowment for Democracy, whose chair of Board of Governors is Elmar Brok, Chairman of the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET), who sits alongside another nine MEPs. I wonder whether EU money is simply being funnelled through the EED to avoid parliamentary scrutiny. Either way, the European Union has blood on its hands.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Mr President, Parliament and the European institutions must guarantee the security of the citizens of the European Union, thus appreciating that they cannot remain passive to the Norwegian child protection system. Through this system, families who dare to raise their children are disintegrating according to their own moral values.  Thus, believing in God is a crime of opinion that must be punished by removing children from their families. This is also the case for the Bodnariu family from which the 5 children were taken, one of whom was 3 months old, who were in the period of breastfeeding. Its sudden interruption will seriously and irreparably affect its growth and development! There are today more than 3,000 children whose parents seek justice in a complex legal system, including the ECHR, and when they find it, the Norwegian State often refuses to recognise it, for reasons that are beyond stood.  I therefore believe that, at European Union level, mechanisms must be found to have the Norwegian authorities determined to review their policy in this area.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Mr President, I wanted to draw this House's attention to the terrible fires that ravaged northern Spain in December and, in essence, my constituency, Asturias. More than 453 fires, most of them caused – on the night of December 19 to 20 there were 150 active fires in the territory of Asturias – which had a great effect on the whole region. I was able to see from the ground, on my visit to the municipality of El Franco, the situation after the end of these fires, but I do not want to particularize in El Franco, because the east, the west, the center of Asturias, the whole region was ravaged by hundreds of fires , as I say – to a large extent, many of them, provoked. The Government of the Principality of Asturias is trying to find ways to compensate people, the homes that have seen their homes, their lands, their livestock destroyed. And I am convinced that the Government of the nation, which is responsible for processing these aid from the European Union, will do the same. And I, from the European Parliament, hope to help in any way I can to at least alleviate to some extent the effects of these terrible fires in Asturias.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – I apologise for earlier, but I would also like to speak, like my colleague Gall-Pelcz, about how unacceptable the violence we have witnessed in Europe in recent times is. There's never an excuse for any violence, none of them. I am very disappointed and sad to read on online networks that some such acts of violence against women and children even justify it.  In some Member States, the authorities have introduced specific courses aimed at educating migrants about European culture. I welcome this, of course, but much more will be needed than that, integrated integration. However, one more important thing seems to me to be: those who come to our area will get all our help as far as we can provide them, but at the same time we also expect them to respect our culture, our customs, and, of course, we will not tolerate any violence against Europeans.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, you have listened to my colleagues, we are all public opinion in Romania, outraged by the cases of the seven Romanian families, the most well-known being the case of the Bodnariu family, the Romanian father, the Norwegian mother, whose five children were taken from the family by the Child Protection Service, without a court order, by an abusive interpretation of what would be the best interests of the child and by a disproportionate action towards the situation in fact , in violation of the principles of the International Convention on the Rights of the Child. This is not the first time it has happened, with Norway already being sentenced to the ECHR for similar cases. I hope that public opinion in European states and capitals will raise awareness and react and call for the involvement of the European institutions, the European Commission and, in particular, the European External Action Service in order to remedy these situations and to persuade the Norwegian authorities to improve the legislative framework so that such cases do not exist in the future.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Spanish authorities decided unilaterally ten days ago to put more than five hundred species of birds and fish at risk, as well as the economy of approximately 60,000 inhabitants living in the Ebro Delta.  The approval of out-of-time watershed hydrological plans is an affront to the authority of the European Commission, which has already repeatedly warned of the repeated problems incurred by the Spanish authorities with the implementation of the Water Framework Directive. In the light of the approved hydrological plans, we are faced with a case of recidivism with premeditation since despite the Commission's warning that the expected ecological flows do not meet the needs of protected areas such as the Delta, the government keeps them in the new plans. In our view, the Commission should act immediately, returning the projects to the Spanish authorities. The survival not only of an ecosystem but also the day-to-day life of 60,000 European citizens is at risk, as I said at the outset. That's why we must act now.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – I would like to express my solidarity with women who have been subjected to violence, threats and harassment in Cologne and other German cities. We will not tolerate such behaviour in Europe. We have a duty to protect the dignity of every woman. It is therefore not important whether those who attacked women in Cologne were immigrants or citizens of the European Union. What matters is action that is inexcusable. When assessing such acts, we must apply the same standard to everyone. The events of Cologne have shown that the challenges ahead are not easy. Let us treat them with all seriousness, but let us not be snatched away from superficial courts, which are often based on prejudice.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
